PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed national ID Card and numbering system threatens the privacy of law-abiding Australians opening the door to computer matching of personal information, will cause inconvenience to rural people in particular, and will result in massive compliance costs for private business.

That the Joint Parliamentary Select Committee Report of 1986 showed that the Australia Card will not be effective in combating taxation and social security fraud and illegal immigration, as its cost savings are based on faulty estimates.
That accordingly the Senate and Parliament should reject the Australia Card Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gambling Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth; We ask that the Federal Government abandon its proposal to establish a gambling casino in the Australian Capital Territory for the following reasons:
1. It would detract from the unique status of the National Capital-a status recognised and maintained by every preceding Government.
2. All sources of information including Justice Connor's report to the Victorian Government suggest that no method of control can prevent the infiltration of organised crime, and
3. It would be likely to exacerbate existing social problems and create new ones.

We urge you to recognise the devastating effects of gambling in the community and the opposition of the majority of voters in the ACT to the establishment of a casino; and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As honourable senators will, I hope, be aware, we have had an extremely long debate on the Appropriation Bills. Up until Tuesday night, we had debated the Bills for more than 28 hours, with 14 hours spent to that point in the Committee of the Whole. Add approximately another 3 1/2 hours, not yet precisely tabulated, yesterday, and that gets up to a total of 31 1/2 hours so far on the appropriations. That compares with an entire debate for 1986-87 of 22 1/2 hours, of which the committee stage took 14 1/2 hours. The Senate will recall that we have already spent 17 1/2 hours on the committee stage this year. The total of 31 1/2 hours so far compares not only with the 22 1/2 hours last year, but in 1985-86, 22 hours 55 minutes; in 1984-85, 10 hours 52 minutes and going back earlier than that, in 1983, 23 hours 29 minutes; in 1982, 17 hours 49 minutes; in 1981, 20 hours 57 minutes; in 1980, 9 hours 39 minutes; and in 1979, 15 hours 11 minutes. I think that the point will be sufficiently clearly established that this is the longest appropriations debate already in living memory. No doubt, the figures would confirm that if we went back further.

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, I am obliged to tell the Senate that it is absolutely imperative that the debate on the Appropriation Bills be concluded this week-I would hope it would be rather earlier than the last possible moment this week. It is imperative that it be concluded this week. Let me explain why. If Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 is not passed by the end of this week the Government will be faced with a serious overspending situation. Supply will run out, in other words. The funds for the Commonwealth pay day--

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

—I will explain. The funds for the Commonwealth pay day of 10 December are charged to the system in the previous week. This covers all civil and defence salaries. Although there is some reserve in the Advance to the Minister for Finance, it is not sufficient to meet that payment and there will be a shortfall of $160m. To avoid this situation the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) must be passed and have royal assent. The Department of Finance advises that four days are required after the Senate passes the Appropriation Bills in order to have the necessary warrant in place. Clearly, this will not occur if the Senate continues consideration of the Appropriation Bills at its next sitting on 7 December.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other examples of payments for which moneys will not be available in time if the Appropriation Bills are not passed this week. These include moneys for the payment of the family assistance supplement commencing on 1 December. Accordingly, I wish to make it clear that if debate is not concluded tonight on these matters I will be moving, at a later hour this day, a motion that we sit tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition notes what has been said by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). With respect to the temporal problem he has described, let me remind the Minister that it was of this Government's making that this legislation was introduced rather later than usual. It was, of course, not of the Opposition's making that we had an unusual mid-year election and started the debate rather later than usual. The result is that we are now considering the Appropriation Bills rather later than usual. I simply want to put on record at this stage that the Opposition certainly does not regard itself as responsible for the Government's problems, as those problems were of its making.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have to say that the need for debate on the Appropriation Bills is becoming ever more evident as the sorry mess left by this Government unfolds. We have just had the rather unedifying report of the Auditor-General put down before us. We know that there are a number of areas in which the Government seems to be impeding the proper scrutiny of its financial actions. I simply want to put the Government on notice that the Opposition will not be a party to the inadequate scrutiny of governmental action, whether it is by the Senate, parliamentary committees, the Auditor-General or the Committee of the Whole in considering these Appropriation Bills. I hear what the Minister has had to say. We have the day before us now and I look forward to our continued consideration of the Appropriation Bills on this splendid Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 25 November.
GROUP D
Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs
Proposed expenditure, $196,653,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the appropriations for increased funding for the adult migrant education program. It is very pleasing to note that there is an increase of $8.5m or 17 per cent over the figure for last year. It is also pleasing to note that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) said that the Government recognises that it has a major responsibility to ensure that new migrants are given the opportunity to learn English. Of course, it is recognised also that migrants who have been here for a great number of years, even those who came in the period following the Second World War, continue to need training in the English language. The Minister said that the funding in the adult migrant education program:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . will also complement initiatives in the English as a Second Language Program for children, being undertaken as part of the Government's National Language Policy.

My question relates directly to this. A year ago, in the 1986 Budget, direct Federal funding for the English as a second language (ESL) program for schools was removed by the Federal Government on the understanding that the States would pick up the initiative and cover the funding for this program. I quote from the West Australian newspaper of 31 October 1986, where Mr Pearce, the Minister for Education, stated:
The State Government would not be picking up the tab for the ESL programme. We're looking to reorganise it and salvage what we can.
I asked Senator Ryan, the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, in the Senate on 21 October 1987:
What steps will the Government take to ensure that the States maintain the English as a second language program as a high priority?

That question has not yet been answered. I would like now to address this question to Senator Reynolds, the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. We know that funding has been set aside in the national language policy for a number of areas which include the English as a second language program both for adults and schoolchildren. To the best of my knowledge, although that money has been allocated on a 1987-88 basis, it has not yet been appropriated to the States, as such. If it has been, have the States started using that funding? The education year always starts in January. Are we therefore to use all that funding in the six months of 1988 up to 30 June? I would like to continue on these lines but perhaps I could have an answer from the Minister thus far.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Ryan is seeking an answer to that question. As the honourable senator knows, in relation to national language policy funding, funds are the responsibility of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). I hope we can have an answer on that item before too much later in the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Continuing along those lines, I would like to point out that it has been a false economy to drop that program-and the program has effectively been dropped this year in a great number of States. This has been a great mistake because, as was stated in the Ethnos magazine of September 1986:

SPEECH.PARA: English language proficiency among children of non-English-speaking background and young people will increase the need for ESL components in labour market and other training programs and will place additional demand on services for persons with English language difficulties.

The Government must realise this. There has been a lot of debate this week on whether migrants should be able to speak English before they get to Australia and to what extent the Government should be spending money on English language programs. Whatever tuition migrants may or may not have in the English language before they come to Australia, that would certainly not enable them to fully take part in Australian society without further extensive programs.

It is all very well to be able to go to the greengrocer to buy one's vegetables for the week and so on; but it is another matter if a migrant, or a person whose first language is not English, is involved in a consultation with a doctor or in a medical situation or in a court, which is often difficult enough for people whose first language is English. If the programs in schools are to be dropped to any extent, as they have been this year-so there is a great backlog to make up-it will hit us further along the line. We have only to go into a workers compensation court to see the proportion of people claiming workers compensation who are non-native English speakers. So to put any argument about the spending of money on English language programs in schools, on the workshop floor or in any other situation is really to talk about a false economy. I certainly recommend that this be looked at very closely.

I would like to ask one further question along the same lines. When the financing for the ESL funding in schools was removed in last year's Budget, there was an uproar all over the country but especially in New South Wales, where there was a big rally and a great noise about the whole thing. Under pressure, the New South Wales Government set aside funding so that the ESL program in schools in New South Wales could continue, but that was achieved only by taking money from elsewhere, making further cuts in the New South Wales education budget.

I realise that the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) has taken my first question on notice, but we clearly need answers as to whether from the start of 1988 the money set aside for the national language policy can be put directly into schools and as to how this will be done. It is now nearly the end of November. What arrangements have been made to set this in motion?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to take Senator Jenkins's last question on notice together with her earlier question. I take this opportunity to give a response to a question asked by Senator Walters yesterday. She asked about the screening guidelines for refugees from Chile. I am now able to provide the answer. Australia operates an in-country special humanitarian program for people who are experiencing severe discrimination in Chile. Under the United Nations definition of a refugee, which is accepted by Australia, a person is not a refugee unless he is outside his country of origin. Under this definition, Australia took about 500 people from Chile in both 1985-86 and 1986-87. The planning figure for 1987-88 is about 600. The criteria used for selecting people under this program are the same as those that apply in other countries around the world; namely, assessment on a case by case basis that the person has a well-founded fear of experiencing severe discrimination and some connection with Australia, such as sponsorship or a family member residing here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make one brief point in response to an assertion made last night by Senator Reynolds just before the Senate rose in which she seemed to me to be accusing me of not being concerned about humanitarian needs. I began my remarks yesterday by quoting to Senator Reynolds her own words, which clearly stated that the migration program at the moment was predicated on economic considerations. I certainly would have no difficulty with a program being predicated on compassionate and humanitarian grounds. I point out that one could substantially increase the numbers of people coming to Australia under that category and still conform with the idea of a steady state population. I simply want to make the point that it was the economic considerations about which I was raising the question. The humanitarian needs of refugees and other such people certainly need to be taken into account, but they are not being adequately taken into account within the present program.

GROUP E
Attorney-General's Department
Proposed expenditure-$419,525,000-agreed to.
Department of Aboriginal Affairs Proposed expenditure, $317,510,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of comments I want to make in relation to matters I raised in Senate Estimates Committee E. I wish to put something on the record at this stage with respect to the answers that I received. I do so because I think the handling of Aboriginal affairs over the next 12 months will require great sensitivity if we are to see an advance in this area. I think there is great potential for the exacerbation of the difficulties that we are experiencing in community relations. The resentment against Aboriginal people which I believe has grown over recent years I very deeply regret.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the decline in public support for Aboriginal affairs, for the advancement of Australian Aboriginals, is a matter on which I think the Government would not disagree with me because I noted that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), early in the life of this Government, indicated that in part the change of approach which had been adopted with respect to national land rights related to what he described-I quote from memory-as `a less compassionate community'. I think that remark is a reflection of the Government's concern that there was less support for Aboriginal programs. I note the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) nodding. I think there is a good deal of agreement on that matter among those members of the Government and, indeed, the Opposition who have taken an interest in this area of Government policy. It is in that context that I raise my concern about the way in which the proposal for a treaty was re-raised by the Prime Minister in September of this year during his visit to the Northern Territory. I will quote from a report that appeared in the Australian at the time, on 3 September. I do so for the purpose of brevity to make the point. That newspaper said:
It is understood Mr Hawke's announcement took by surprise even the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, who is accompanying him on a visit to the Northern Territory.
Later it said:
Mr Hawke made the unexpected announcement during an interview at an Aboriginal radio station in Alice Spring.
Afterwards, Mr Hawke said he wanted to see the agreement in place before the Bicentenary.

That suggests really an extraordinarily short timetable because, of course, at the end of December we will reach the Bicentenary. Therefore, the Prime Minister was suggesting what I would regard as a very rapid timetable on a potentially very contentious issue. I note again, without referring to specific comments made by Mr Hand, that it appears clear that Mr Hand has pulled back expectations in this area and has taken a more cautious approach. He has made a number of public comments suggesting that he would not wish to move until there had been adequate consultation and so on. I support the spirit of those remarks. I think that any action in this area should be preceded by careful consultation, which is very time consuming.

The matters which I raised during the Estimates committee hearings related to this point of the Government appearing to have moved in a way which surprised even the responsible Minister. During the Estimates committee hearing I asked the Department of Aboriginal Affairs how much departmental time had gone into the preparation of the proposal that there be a single commission, which is the new proposal for the restructuring of the administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I also asked for an identification of what departmental resources went into the preparation of the very substantial proposal that was announced within a few days of the election and what resources were budgeted for the current year for the continuance of that proposal. I asked exactly the same question with respect to what work was done in the last financial year in the preparation of any proposal for anything which could be described as a treaty or compact, or in the nature of an agreement, and what resources had been budgeted for. I said that I would like to know the number of officials involved and, if possible, their classification, their positions and the amount of their time that went into that proposal. I also said:

I am seeking to find out what amounts of departmental time and resources, if any, were devoted to considering the very complex issues that arose, both through the departmental reorganisation and the proposal for some form of agreement.

I want to quote the answer which has been provided by the Department and which is contained in the document containing written replies to questions asked during hearings by Estimates Committee E, which was tabled in the Senate and which is dated November 1987. The Department stated:
No departmental resources were involved last year in preparatory work for the new Commission or the proposed compact with the Aboriginal people.

That is a pretty straightforward statement: nothing. In an area which many of us take very seriously, it is totally unsatisfactory to have clear evidence that we were dealing with things off the top of the prime ministerial head. It is evidence of utter irresponsibility.

This is a very sensitive issue. Senator McKiernan, who is in the chamber, knows what a sensitive issue it is in our State of Western Australia, and how easy it is to excite public feeling. Public feeling is already very strong on many of these issues. I am not at all happy about appropriating funds for the administration of a department which is not involved in the preparation of such a major initiative. It seems to me to be an absolute absurdity that this matter could be launched in this way. In fact, I regard it as a quite disgraceful bit of self-indulgence on the part of the Prime Minister. I trust that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) will get the matter into some sort of working order.

I want to express in this committee debate my very deep concern about this sort of approach to Aboriginal affairs. The history of the last 10 years is not a very cheerful one. The Aboriginal people describe it in terms which are offensive to many white Australians-in terms of white Australia generally having a black history. I think it is an unhelpful comment in terms of reducing the sort of white backlash which is a very important part of current difficulties. But the reality is that the last 10 years has been a period during which excessive promises have been made to Aboriginal people which clearly the present Government, once in government, felt unable to keep. The promises of the Australian Labor Party in opposition raised Aboriginal expectations and Aboriginal demands. Those Aboriginal demands were a part of the process of reducing public support.

I ask in this debate for some commitment from the Government to avoid raising expectations which cannot be met. It is fundamentally damaging to the Aboriginal community and to attitudes of the rest of the community to the Aboriginal community. I note that the present Minister has expressed caution in a number of public statements. I welcome that, but I think it is terribly important that his actions reflect the caution that he has expressed. When he visited Rudall River in Western Australia it seemed to me that he raised the possibility of Federal intervention there, albeit in a fairly muted way. He has proposals, which no doubt we will hear more about, for substantial departmental reorganisation. We have some proposal for some form of compact, but we do not really know what the Government has in mind. If the Government does not make the most careful assessment of what in fact is achievable and acceptable, it will be behaving quite irresponsibly. It is very important that that assessment includes what is acceptable to the community generally. There is absolutely no gain to be made for Aboriginal people in pursuing lines of progress or policy which will increase community ill-will. The Government has to make a very careful assessment of what it believes it can achieve and it should not hold out any more than that to the Aboriginal community.

I believe that the Government needs to note very carefully the finding of the sub-committee of the Constitutional Commission which has reported to the Australian people that it has not found in the Aboriginal community a sufficient understanding of what the Government is talking about in terms of the idea of a compact or treaty on which to base any proposal for constitutional change. My own experience from the extensive consultations which were undertaken with respect to the Aboriginal Development Commission, which was established during my period as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, is that we have to accept that a very long period is involved in any genuine consultation with the extraordinarily disparate groups which make up the Aboriginal community of Australia.

I want to take the opportunity in this debate to make a series of pleas to the Government. The Opposition is not in a position to impose its will in these matters. Since we do not expect an election to be held for a couple of years, the reality is that the administration of these matters is going to remain in Labor Party hands for the next two years at least. Therefore, the success or failure of policy lies squarely in the Government's hands. I would have to say that the record of the last few years is not one which gives me a great sense of optimism. So, fundamentally I am saying to the Government that the reports that the Prime Minister's statement was something which took the Minister by surprise are really borne out by the answers that were given to the Estimates Committee. Those answers show that no departmental time went into these matters during the financial year. There could not be clearer proof of the fact that this is not a matter which has received the sort of attention which I think it so obviously requires if we are to get any initiatives in this area.

I do not wish to make a long speech about what the Opposition's view is. We have always clearly, in government and in opposition, said that the idea of a treaty is a very dangerous one that we will not support because it raises all sorts of spectres about a divided nation and so on. It is a very dangerous proposal. I think the Prime Minister and the Government have backed off this idea. They are now pursuing some form of understanding with the Aboriginal community. My point to the Government fundamentally is that, if it is to do that, it must avoid raising expectations. It must make a realistic assessment of the constitutional, legal, administrative, political and community relations realities within which it has to work so that it does not hold out false promises to the Aboriginal community. It must then be prepared to be extremely patient. It must examine whether it is to have a truly representative Aboriginal body with which it will try to reach some sort of understanding about the future lines of policy. Alternatively, is the Government going to go on a community-wide, Australia-wide, process of consultation of the sort that we undertook with respect to the Aboriginal Development Commission? All of these things need to be worked out and talked about with the Aboriginal community, brought into this Parliament and exposed for comment and debate if we are to have any hope of proceeding in the way which will advance the Aboriginal people.

Too many people have agreed with me in conversations that I have had over the last couple of years when I have put to them the proposition that in fact the position of Australian Aboriginals is going backwards in many areas. Many people within the Labor Party, as well as in the general community, have agreed with that proposition when I have raised it with them. I say to the Government that, if we are to avoid continuing to go backwards in this area, we must show a far greater degree of sensitivity than this Government has exhibited so far.

I remind the Government that the Minister held out the prospect of national Aboriginal land rights right up to the death-knock. Year after year the possibility of that was held out to the Aboriginal community. It was never a goer. There was never the real possibility that that would happen. I ask the Government not to repeat the very obvious errors of the last 10 years of the Australian Labor Party in government and opposition. I could make a very cross speech about this, as I have in this place in the past, but I think that the Labor members who are here are as genuinely concerned to solve this problem as any member on my side. I contribute to the debate in the hope that, within the Government, there will be a far more cautious and careful approach to this matter than there has been in the past.

I think that the Minister will fail if he allows himself to become the prisoner of the radical minority of Aboriginals. There is an enormous danger in that. I do not believe that the land councils and some of the more high profile spokesmen for the Aboriginal community genuinely represent Aboriginal opinion in Australia. I do not believe that many of the things they advocate are in the interests of the Aboriginal community of Australia. It is fundamentally important that Mr Hand look over the heads of some of those who are closest to him and who are the most noisy and engage in a very long and careful consultation with the Aboriginal community generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will resist the very strong temptation to debate the issue. I will refer Senator Chaney's comments to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Local Government. I do not seek to engage her in debate because, quite frankly, I do not think that that would advance the matter now. The final point that I made is of critical importance. A substantial number of Aboriginal people have already said to me that they are deeply concerned that there is too narrow a group which appears to have influence with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). I concede publicly that in his conversations with me and in many of his public statements the Minister appears to me to be disavowing that possibility, but I think that if that does occur his ministry will not achieve the success which he wants for it, and which indeed the Opposition wants for it, in terms of results for Aboriginal Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for Local Government for her very brief response. I ask her to refer my comments to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. If, over the next few months, there is a holding out of promises on which the Government cannot deliver, the debates in this place will not be of a reasonable nature because we cannot afford to see Aboriginal people pushed down in public regard any further than they have been pushed over recent years. The cell deaths matter that is of such concern to honourable senators throughout the chamber is but the tip of the iceberg of the difficulties about which I am talking. Those cell deaths in part reflect the attitudes that Aboriginals have to put up with in their daily lives in the community. We in politics have contributed to that in a way which I think has been extremely destructive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we approach the Bicentenary year-the year marking the settlement of white Australians in this country 200 years ago-I point out yet again the great amount of damage that has been wreaked on this country in 200 years, not least on the Aboriginal people and the Aboriginal culture. I express the hope that in the next year we will do something to redress that very sorry record, that we will recognise what has happened in the past and put in place far better ways of managing both race relations in this country and the Australian environment. If we do not do so, this will not be a country which Australians will be able to enjoy 200 years from now.

SPEECH.PARA: Part of the mechanism which needs to be put in place relates to the recognition by white European Australians that the Aboriginal culture has a very positive contribution to make to a totally new, integrated and caring Australian culture. That will be done only when white Europeans recognise that contribution and give value to those elements of Aboriginal culture, contained in traditional lifestyles of caring for and belonging to the land, rather than of the land belonging to people for exploitative purposes. Until that is done, it is difficult to see how Aboriginal people themselves will take pride in their culture and how the so-called Aboriginal problem will be solved. It is not an Aboriginal problem; it is not a white problem. It is a problem of a cultural clash. It is a problem which will be solved only when there is a recognition of the unique contribution both sides can make to a truly Australian culture.

With that in mind, I note that there is at the moment no national Aboriginal body which is funded by the Commonwealth Government. I ask whether the Government is indeed committed to the establishment of a national Aboriginal body that is elected by the Aborigines themselves. If so, why does there appear to be no funding for the establishment of such a body?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a number of issues on this particular section of the consideration of the appropriations, particularly with regard to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I would like to reinforce the comments that were made by Senator Chaney with regard to the compact. The debate about the proposed treaty or compact will create both support and division within the community. I note in particular that the appropriations make available some $2.4m in this financial year for the consultative process. During the Estimates it was ascertained that that $2.4m was provided to enable a full consultation process with the Aboriginal people to take place. I would like to highlight the fact that the $2.4m on its own is not enough, because the consultation cannot be one-sided and totally restricted to the Aboriginal community within our society.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not support the need for a specific compact or a specific treaty. I believe that, in effect, we already have in place-in this very Budget that we are debating, in the various State Budgets around Australia and in the Budget of the Northern Territory Parliament-eight compacts with the Aboriginal people. There is a parliamentary process through which those budgets are developed. The total provision of funds on a national basis must be somewhere between $1,000m and $1,200m per annum in current terms. During this year's Estimates I pursued many questions in the area of what I termed accountability. I asked about the accountability, performance requirements, and checks and balances that had to be applied to all of these various government programs. I ascertained at that point that we needed to establish the Aboriginal vote in accounting terms-in terms of the contribution of the Australian taxpayer and expenditure in and for the Aboriginal community-and that this meant that there had to be a full acceptance of responsibility and accountability when accepting the tremendous amounts of funds that are applied nationally.

The officers of the Department argued very strongly that there needed to be special provisions and special types of considerations in the accounting provisions to allow for processes whereby Aboriginals can properly participate. I would argue just as strongly that the auditing, efficiency checking and accountability procedures must at all times be fully accountable in the due processes of this Parliament to all Australian people. Mr Brownbill, an officer of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, in his comments at the Estimates hearings, also highlighted the point that there were very strong differences in the roles played by men and women in Aboriginal society. He stressed that these roles are different in what one might call the tribal and the detribalised or urbanised Aboriginal societies. We need to be very cautious and careful, in assessing all of these appropriations, that due regard is had to the competing interests within the Aboriginal community between tribalised and detribalised needs as they exist in society today. This again brings me back to how we ensure that this Parliament makes the proper provisions, allocates the funds properly and sees that the programs are efficiently carried out and that the recipients, whether they be Aboriginals or communities in which Aboriginals reside, are fully accountable.

Several other issues arise. It was highlighted during Estimates committee hearings that many Department of Aboriginal Affairs officers were acting in positions higher than their substantive positions. An answer indicated that in the Department's Central Office some 111 people were on higher duties, 50 of whom had been on higher duties for over 12 months. That matter needs to be addressed very carefully by the administrators of the Department. It is not an efficient or proper system for a department.

The acquisition of pastoral properties in the Northern Territory, which I represent, will always create community debate. In the course of Estimates hearings this year particular issues were highlighted in regard to acquisitions. This concerned not only the acquisition of the pastoral properties themselves but also the necessity for the Government to deal with existing pastoral lessees on the matter of land claims that have been lodged over stock routes, and excision provisions to provide reasonable living areas for Aboriginals on pastoral properties. It was ascertained from the Aboriginal Development Commission that an Aboriginal land register is maintained. I believe that further detail should be provided in this regard. The supplementary information provided to Estimates Committee E does not fully give the information that I believe I sought on that occasion. It has not been forthcoming. I believe that should be public information and made well known.

The charts that show the various land that has now been set aside for Aboriginal purposes throughout Australia were highlighted yesterday when the report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs was tabled. They show clearly that as at 30 June last year Aboriginal title was held over some 34 per cent of the total area of the Northern Territory. Of course other large tracts of land are under claim and it is anticipated that finally some 40 per cent of the land mass of the Territory will end up under Aboriginal ownership. That certainly creates advantages for Aboriginal communities but also creates a problem for non-Aboriginal communities which have to adapt to this situation. They have to ensure that government and non-government structures in the community and the community itself can deal with such a large and dramatic change in land administration. This problem does not exist in any other part of Australia. The Department's report, which shows provisions made in all of the States, demonstrates that there are many more competing interests in the Territory, and this certainly highlights the difference whereby the Commonwealth Government is able to walk in and apply provisions not applicable, constitutionally, in the States.

As the Northern Territory marches towards statehood, which is an inevitable constitutional consequence of development in this country, I accept that the issues of Aboriginal residents of the Northern Territory must be fully accommodated. As we develop a legal constitution for the Northern Territory, it is quite apparent that there will have to be a major and different change on title land administration, and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act of this Parliament will, in effect, have to be abrogated or repatriated to the Northern Territory and incorporated in some form of provision under the Territory's State Constitution when it evolves. That means that this Parliament will have to be prepared, as it is in accepting the role of all States, to give up that form of control that it currently has.

As to living areas excisions, I do not believe that the Government has yet come clean on where it currently stands. The answers given during the Estimates committees concerned the stage that the negotiations had reached. While I appreciate that the discussions with the Northern Territory Government and the various inte-rests in the Northern Territory such as the Northern Territory Pastoralists Association have to be fully accommodated, the time span seems to be too long and drawn out. There needs to be certainty for the Aboriginal community and for the people who will be affected by living area excisions as they apply.

There are also a number of allocations in the Budget that deal with heritage and culture, and Senator Coulter referred to this earlier. I accept that there are many areas where we must ensure that adequate provision is made for the preservation, particularly, of the tribalised Aboriginal in the community. I am concerned that the provisions in this area do not draw sufficient delineation between the provision of cultural and ceremonial rights for tribal Aboriginals. Many of these programs tend to be applied for cultural things in the detribalised areas elsewhere in Australia, which have a different significance. It was also brought out in the Estimates Committee that a large provision of over $3m is made by a separate department through the Aboriginal Arts Board. Again, I believe that the Budget should carefully define where the provisions for Aboriginal culture are going, as between those for areas that are traditional in nature and those that are supporting the programs in the de-tribalised Aboriginal areas elsewhere in Australia.

Let me refer to another provision that seems to have emerged for the first time this year in the appropriations for the Department, and that is the provision of over $800,000 in a specific area of the creation of an office of Aboriginal women within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The figures and answers given in the Estimates Committee were extremely vague about what this $800,000-odd was to be spent on. There is provision for some $680,000 for capital items for Aboriginal women's resources centres. In most capital works planning and programming there is an established order of priorities, and there are places and named areas as to where the money is to be spent, but we were not able to ascertain in the Estimates Committee where this money is to go. I accept that, particularly in the urban communities and detribalised areas, Aboriginal women are playing a very emerging role in society. They have a strong leadership role in many areas of the community. They certainly need support, but I would hope that this is not just a provision for another equal opportunities push under another fancy name. When we get expenditure in the order of $800,000 in one year in an area like that, I believe that there has to be more information provided, and more detailed planning should be available.

In the area of law and justice, it was highlighted that there were certain provisions made to Tasmanian interests, and we have all heard the debate surrounding Mr Mansell's activities in Australia. I believe that this is a most unproductive area, and needs to be carefully reviewed, and we certainly need to watch carefully where Aboriginal leaders in certain communities develop interests that are not necessarily in accord with the constituency that they are seeking to represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously Senator Tambling is going to pursue a few more matters, so I will not respond to the points that he has made so far, but I will speak to give him an opportunity to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter raised mostly policy matters, not specifically related to the Bicentenary. We can only agree with him that, in the Bicentennial year, a lot of sensitivity is required and a lot of thought has to be given to the relationship between the white European community and the cultural traditions of this country prior to that. Senator Coulter raised the question of an elected Aboriginal body in the country and what funding is necessary. As far as I know, none is allocated in this particular set of estimates. It is a policy area that Senator Coulter might like to pursue, and the Government will have to respond to that point. However, at this stage, it is not related to the estimates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we look at a number of the other provisional areas, there appears to be a fundamental shift in policy between the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and his predecessor, Mr Holding, particularly with regard to the provision of funds for what is called the Aboriginal lands movement program, or where there is funding for homelands and outstations. I asked the following question on notice about this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has recently written to the Northern Territory Government seeking to have the Commonwealth State review accelerated and suggests the basis for assessment be:
(a) all Commonwealth funding activity including direct grant funding as well as grants to the States should be similarly included;
(b) all States delivered or funded activity should be similarly included; and
(c) that in the event that savings are identified in Commonwealth funding, that such funds should be retained within the State for further agreed initiatives.
The third point seems to be a fundamental shift as the Minister's predecessor was looking to identify duplication and savings to the Commonwealth advantage. Is this to be the accepted policy?
The answer was:

The approach does represent a fundamental policy shift. It should be noted, however, that any funds saved would be available for direct grants programs or grants to the State (Territory) for agreed initiatives.

I welcome that answer, because it highlights that where homelands and outstations are created, automatic additional costs are incurred to either the State governments or the Northern Territory Government. There must be a provision, and we must guarantee that those State governments are not disadvantaged where new outstations are created by a Commonwealth initiative, and then it is expected that the State governments or the Northern Territory Government will pick up the particular cost.

The only other two points that I would wish to make relate to business funding. Yesterday, Senator Brownhill asked a question in this place in regard to the adequacy of checking of funds to commercial activities to ensure not only that the provision of funds are properly audited, but that the management of commercial and business enterprises that are specifically Aboriginal should be measured by conventional, professional checks and balances. We ascertained yesterday that an amount of, I think, some $900,000 had been invested in a hotel in northern New South Wales and that that project had failed. The Department and the Aboriginal Development Commission have admitted that there is a high bad debts ratio in the recovery of these types of funds. I think that that needs to be very carefully kept under review and addressed.

My final point relates to an associated matter, that of the counselling of staff in areas in which it has been ascertained that poor standards of supervision apply. I refer specifically to the Bird case in Alice Springs where over a period an officer of the Aboriginal Development Commission defrauded the Commission of in excess of $2m. An unusual accounting arrangement was made and this was manipulated within the Commission. It was very apparent in the court case on this matter that the defrauding had happened over an extended period and that the person found guilty had been engaged in very extensive gambling activities which would have been known to his fellow employees, his superiors and to officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The fact that there was no mechanism adequately to counsel for antisocial behaviour I believe highlights a point of risk that needs to be addressed. We need to guarantee that in future the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission give very special regard to programs that ensure that, as part of staff development, training and supervision, there is adequate counselling and training within the Department and the Commission to counter areas of antisocial behaviour which are apparent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling has raised a number of questions. He started off by giving us his views on an Aboriginal compact. They are interesting views. He made the point that if the Northern Territory is granted statehood there should be a repatriation of land rights coverage to the Northern Territory. I do not think that there is a Government policy specifically on that at this stage; we are not anticipating statehood immediately. Everyone in the Northern Territory is in favour of statehood but, of course, the details of that and the funding to the Northern Territory that would result have by no means been finalised. So we will not postulate as to what may happen in the future there.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling raised the question of a grant for the establishment of an office of Aboriginal women. In fact, the $800,000 he mentioned is not for that; it is for multipurpose centres for Aboriginal women. Senator Tambling complained that there was no specific detail on this. It is quite obvious why there is no specific detail-because certain consultations always need to occur in these areas and they have not yet occurred. The details of each project will be provided to this Parliament following the consultations and Government decisions.

Senator Tambling raised the matter of Mr Mansell and complained that he did not really represent the views of his constituency. If that is a crime then Senator Tambling is probably also guilty from time to time. Senator Tambling, however, made a very valid point in his next area of concern-the failure of Aboriginal commercial enterprises. It is true that there have been failures. Some Aboriginal enterprises have failed under the Whitlam Government, the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government. Whether Senator Tambling thinks that price is too high, I am not sure. However, I think we have to persist in these areas. But we also have to put a lot of stress on training. I refer him to the announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a week or so ago on that particular matter.

Senator Tambling also referred to accountability and raised the case of Mr Bird, who, I understand, has been charged and convicted for misappropriating money. These things happen from time to time everywhere. It was only about 15 years ago that an officer of the Rural Bank of New South Wales lost a few million dollars to the bookmakers. No one has dismissed that particular bank. He has proved at least one thing: that even with the Rural Bank of New South Wales one cannot win on the punt. These things occur. Of course, we do not endorse them. Senator Tambling raised the matter as a serious concern; it is of concern. However, this is not the first time such a thing has happened and I doubt whether there is any method to prevent it occurring occasionally in the future. The main thing is that the matter was discovered, prosecuted and brought to a conclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct the attention of the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) to the type of financial management which takes place amongst the Aboriginal communities. I refer him, for instance, to Oombulgurri, which, of course-I am certain he knows-is in the Cambridge Gulf in the north-west of Western Australia, where last year there was a shortfall of hundreds of thousands of dollars in funds. My last inquiries indicated that there was an investigation taking place and that it appeared either that a white bookkeeper had misappropriated funds or that his management was so bad that the money had been lost as a result of poor financial and business transactions. I ask what the status of that community is now in respect of the discipline of the financial management of the group.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Minister more particularly now to the Kalumburu group, also in the north-west of Western Australia-further to the north of the Oombulgurri group. As I understand it, that community simply is unable to pay its debts. It has a number of significant creditors outstanding. The indications are that those creditors can look forward to carrying the responsibility of those very substantial debts for some months into the future.

The Kalumburu group and the Oombulgurri group, I suspect, both use business houses in Wyndham as their suppliers. Of course, those suppliers are not major operators, so when they are carrying debts of tens of thousands of dollars for many months that seriously jeopardises their capacity to function. It might properly be said that those business houses in Wyndham, Derby, Broome, Kununurra or wherever, ought to conduct their business with Aboriginal communities on a commercial footing. I am sure they do. Also, I think we all understand, credit is provided to these communities on the basis of fair needs mixed with commercial considerations.

As I said, I understand that Kalumburu is unable to pay its creditors; probably technically, it is insolvent. I understand that now the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is investigating the prospect of purchasing aircraft for the Kalumburu group to travel between Kalumburu and Wyndham. That is notwithstanding the fact that a regular charter flies between Wyndham and Kalumburu and has low passenger volume. I submit, with respect, that if the Department were to go ahead with the purchase of this aircraft it would be delinquent in terms of financial management and the use of taxpayers' funds, in the same way that the purchase of a barge by the Oombulgurri group recently cost the taxpayer hundreds of thousands of unrecovered dollars in debts.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been some problems in the community to which Senator Crichton-Browne referred. I think the rough estimate is that $100,000 is owing and creditors have taken action to recover that money. I understand that investigations are under way to establish the causes of that. I am not able to help the honourable senator with any information as to the results of those inquiries because I do not think that they are yet complete.

—I understand why the Mi-nister personally does not know about these communities. I mentioned Oombulgurri, the community that had a problem last year. Now Kalumburu has significant problems. I ask the Minister whether it is not a fact that the Department is in the process of examining the prospect of that community purchasing an aircraft, which I think would not be a priority, given the regular charter service's low passenger volumes.
—Senator Crichton-Browne is correct. It is under consideration. However, no final decision has been made in relation to that purchase.

—Given the dire financial circumstances of the community and its incapacity to pay modest debts to modest creditors, why is it now investigating the prospect of purchasing an aircraft to transport members of the community from Kalumburu to Wyndham, when there is already a charter aircraft with very considerable seating available on each flight, almost without exception?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that no decision has been made but an application has been made and it will be considered on its me-rits. No doubt the views the honourable senator has put today and other people have put will be taken into consideration before a final decision is made.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
GROUP D
Department of Community Services and Health
Proposed expenditure $1,251,369,000

TALK.START.PARA: —Some information is to be given. Is Senator Ryan coming to the chamber?
—Very shortly.
—My next question is directed specifically to Senator Ryan. I would like to wait until she arrives.

—I thank Senator Walters for her courtesy in awaiting Senator Ryan's arrival. I am sure that at this moment she is gathering a number of papers to answer some of the questions left unanswered yesterday. I do not know whether any other honourable senators would feel motivated to raise more general issues. This is such an interesting area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the annual report of the Health Insurance Commission, the costs of Medibank Private were revealed to have increased, as a management expense ratio, from 11.6 per cent of funds to 14.2 per cent, an increase of 22 per cent. We are told that this substantial increase in management expenses is largely due to the marked growth in the membership of Medibank Private and the associated growth in processing volumes. I was under the impression that when volumes increased average costs were reduced because there were so many fixed overheads that there would be economies of scale.

SPEECH.PARA: Why does this golden rule not apply in this case and why does increasing business mean a substantial increase in the associated costs of running the business? If it involves a once-off increase in computer capacity, which it may well do, or an increase in other facilities which have enormous scope for further use-in other words, if there has had to be a very lumpy increase in facilities-can the Minister tell what additional scope is now available in Medibank for the utilisation of what now would be unused capacity? If there has been a sudden jump in the amount of major equipment or space, what is the scope for additions to the numbers capable of being handled by Medibank Private without further cost increases?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that this matter involves one of those funny conundrums. Because Medicare and Medibank Private are run by the same operation, and since the membership of Medibank Private has increased, more of the administrative costs have been transferred from one side to the other. That happened towards the end of the year. I think that is the explanation. The way those sorts of costs are divided-in accounting terms, I assume-means that once the membership of one side goes up more of the administrative expenses are transferred. I think it is almost a book figure. I hope that satisfies the honourable senator.

—It is certainly an adequate explanation. Whether it is a good explanation is another matter. This matter certainly seems to raise very serious questions about the distribution of costs between Medibank Private and Medicare. We are compulsorily required to be members of Medicare. It is a matter of choice whether one wants to be a member of Medibank Private. What the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has just told me seems to raise serious questions about whether Medibank Private may well have been getting some advantage not available to competing private funds because some sort of arbitrary rule is used in apportioning costs. I do not know of a similar situation where the prospect of increased efficiency through increased numbers is offset by some formula which applies exactly to the contrary. I know that various other health funds have expressed concern about the manner in which costs are apportioned between Medibank and Medicare.
—Grave concerns.

—As Senator Walters says, they are very grave concerns. I ask the Minister whether, to his knowledge, Medibank Private is moving more closely towards being a fair competitor with the private funds in that it is now at last being required to carry a fairer proportion of the costs as split up between Medibank Private and Medicare. If this is not so, can the Minister arrange for the Health Insurance Commission to provide a proper explanation for the increase?

—Senator Michael Baume asked whether Medibank Private has an unfair advantage. There is a whole set of criteria by which he might care to measure that. I am satisfied that it does not, because the accounting method has been approved by the Auditor- General. As the Audit Office is a fairly independent body measuring government performance, I am satisfied with that as an explanation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters yesterday was seeking specific details of the payments available to consultant physicians after the first three consultations. The initial consultation fee for the consultant physician is $87. The initial consultation fee for specialists, including all surgeons, obstetricians, gynaecologists and so on, is $50. The fee for the second and third subsequent consultations at the consultant physician level is $43 and the fee for the fourth or other subsequent consultations is $25. Senator Walters wanted to know the difference between the consultant physician rate and the general practitioner (GP) rate. The GP standard consultation fee is $17.60. So once the consultant physician goes on to long term management his fee is 40 per cent greater than that for the GP standard consultation. I hope that satisfies Senator Walters's request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have another question. I have received from a constituent a letter that the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health (Senator Ryan) has written to her. I would prefer her name to remain unknown. The Minister said in her letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for your recent note to His Excellency, the Governor-General about the Australia Card.
I am glad you took the time to write about this important issue.

Then the letter went on with the normal Labor propaganda about the ID card. My constituent said that she did not want her name on a computer and that she had not written a note to His Excellency the Governor-General. She was extremely concerned about this matter, and wondered why she got such a letter from the Minister when she certainly had not written a note to His Excellency the Governor-General about the Australia Card.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —This clearly does not pertain in any way at all to the estimates which are being considered by the Committee. If Senator Walters would like to make that letter available to me, I can offer her an explanation outside the conduct of the business of the Committee of the Whole.

—The Minister, as I understand her portfolio, is the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. I imagine that the cost of this letter and any other letters of this type would come under the estimates for the Department of Community Services and Health. I would be most surprised if I were out of order in light of her portfolio and the fact that we are looking at the estimates for the Department of Community Services and Health.
—What is your question, Senator Walters?
—I thank the Minister. My question is appropriate. This letter was obviously a mistake. I would like to know how taxpayers' money has been used in making such a mistake.
—Well, what is the question?

—Why did my constituent receive a letter from the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health when my constituent had written no such letter to His Excellency the Governor-General? How many similar letters, whether in error or otherwise, were sent out by the Minister, and what was the cost?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot possibly answer that question now. As I said, if Senator Walters would like to make that letter available to me, I will have it examined and explain what led to that reply being prepared. It does not pertain to the matters before the Committee at the moment. I will be very happy to look at the letter and get whatever information I can for Senator Walters.
—Senator Walters, I think that is a reasonable response from the Minister.

—I will certainly make the letter available to the Minister and find out how she made the mistake. It is no use saying that the letter was prepared by someone else. It was signed by the Minister. The buck stops with the Minister's signature. The question I asked was: How many such letters have been sent out by the Minister and what was the cost? I think that comes within the estimates.
—I think the Minister has already indicated that that will be part of the answer.
—No, Mr Temporary Chairman, she has not.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will get that information.
—Senator Walters, that information will be sent to you.

—I would like to support Senator Walters's remarks because I have had a number of complaints in Queensland. One of my own staff, whose loyalty is beyond reproach, got a letter from the Minister on this business of the Australia Card. On Sunday I went to an air show at Archerfield. One of my old friends there, an ex-fighter pilot who was decorated for his service in the Second World War, gave me such a letter. He said, `I am not going to be intimidated. I find this letter one of the most intimidating exercises I have had in my life. You can tell the Minister from me that she will not frighten me by writing this sort of nonsense'.

—On a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman: I must ask at this stage that members of the Committee conduct the business of the Committee, which is the examination of the estimates. If honourable senators have questions that they want to ask about ex-fighter pilots' letters and so forth, this is not the place to do it.

—I would like to follow up the remarks of my colleagues by asking a question about the number of replies that have been made by the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health (Senator Ryan) on the issue of the Australia Card, and the categories in which various people made responses to the Government on this issue. Last night in the adjournment debate I tabled a letter addressed to the Speaker of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. It was very obviously a roneoed prepared pat letter from the Department of Community Services and Health in response to a motion of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a most important matter with regard to the Australia Card. The Speaker received in reply a letter that did not recognise his position and authority or the representations that had been made by the Northern Territory Parliament. He received a letter very similar to those received by the constituents of Senator Walters and Senator MacGibbon, obviously as part of a series of letters. I wonder whether the Minister signed them personally or whether they were done by machine. I would like to see the statistics on how many replies were made by Government Ministers through this Department and how they were categorised as to importance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will provide that information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal briefly with a matter which was raised yesterday with the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health (Senator Ryan) in Question Time about the establishment of a private hospital within the public hospital in Darwin. I refer the Minister particularly to a response from the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, who said, that the prospect of having a private hospital within a public hospital area raised the problem as to whether the Northern Territory Government could continue to guarantee unrestricted access to free public hospital treatment for uninsured people as a result of giving away a whole floor. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is also the question of whether an agreement has been made between the Northern Territory Government and the operators of the proposed private hospital to redirect all privately insured patients from the public hospital to the private beds. It is important that we get an answer to that. Whilst some of the newspapers in the Northern Territory have been pretending that Territorians were disadvantaged by not having this provision, people in the Northern Territory should understand the full implications of this proposal.
He went on to say:

. . . a serious social problem arises if one decides within a public hospital to have a special floor set aside as a private hospital in that one may well develop special first class treatment for that one floor compared with the rest, so the result in the future will be that people in the public hospital-the poor, the Aborigines and others-will get second class treatment while those insured will get first class treatment on a special floor.

A point was made here yesterday about Calvary Hospital in Canberra. I wonder whether the Minister would like to say whether the Go-vernment has a fundamental objection to allowing private hospital structures or floors within public hospital complexes. The point was made yesterday about Campbelltown, St George, and Lismore hospitals-I think North Shore is talking about it-and whether there is also a fundamental objection to attempting to direct the private hospital insured in Australia to self-supporting private hospitals, which I understand is what the situation is all about. I ask that in the context that basic private health insurance will pay $200 a day for private hospital care but the public hospitals, whose daily operating costs are, I understand, on average about $300, use taxpayer funded subsidies in order to charge only $120 a day for privately insured patients. In other words, the revenue in particular stands significantly to gain from people using private hospitals instead of using public hospitals. In the light of this apparent tax subsidy of health insurance funds and the undoubted fact that privately insured patients are adding significantly to public hospital queues, what is the Government's objection to this in principle and on what basis? Or was it simply a cheap political stunt to have a go at the Northern Territory Government? On what basis can it object to this?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume, of course, knows a great deal about cheap political stunts. What he is asking now is a policy question. If he wants to ask a policy question, I suggest that he ask it at Question Time or put it on notice.

—I ask a question to follow up that of Senator Michael Baume. In the estimates before us what provisions are specifically being made this year, or what disadvantages are being made, with regard to Calvary Hospital and to any other provisions that will affect this area in the coming Budget?
—I will take it on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things that became apparent in Senate Estimates Committee E during consideration of the estimates for the Department of Defence was that the high resignation rates that the Government euphemistically refers to as separation rates are continuing at record levels and the Government is doing very little to stem the flow. We now live in an area of very much increased instability. The regions around Australia have changed demonstrably from what they were 20 years ago and the need for a higher level of preparedness and a much higher level of capability for the Australian Defence Force is apparent to everyone except members of the Australian Labor Party. The capability gravely to harm Australia's interests is now possessed by a number of nations in our region. The Government does not recognise this. It still persists with the old `no threat for 10 years' doctrine and when it talks about threats it talks about the invasion of Australia. The invasion of Australia is the very least of the probabilities that face us in the defence area. We are an island and we are surrounded by nations which do have the capability, if they are so minded, to cause Australia a great deal of trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: The limited capabilities that we have are being destroyed by the lack of concern of this Government for the men and women who form the Australian defence forces. As I have said over the years since the Labor Government came into power, this is not simply a matter of recruiting more people, as the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) fatuously tells the Parliament-`We have to do better; we have to recruit more'. It is far more serious than that. When we lose the experienced people that we are losing, we lose capability and we lose that capability for a generation. In other words, the situation that the Australian defence forces are in today will take at least 10 years to recover, to get back to the position we had when the Labor Party came into power. So we have to hope and we have to pray that we do not have to use those services seriously within the next 10 years. But if something is not done to correct the haemorrhage occurring in experienced personnel, that capability loss will be extended well beyond the 10 years.

What has the Government done about it? Precisely nothing, except to appoint a Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. In the 10 years that I have been in the Parliament I have seen some bad Ministers, in the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Labor Party, but I have never seen a Minister with less ministerial competence in her portfolio than the present incumbent-a Minister whose approach to her portfolio is one of patronising superficiality. This patronising superficiality is seen by everyone-every man and every woman in the Australian defence forces. I commend to the Senate an article by the defence reporter Peter Young in the Australian newspaper yesterday. He very accurately and in a very restrained article outlined the shortcomings of this Minister. I would like to quote a few points from it:

To put it in non-military terms, she was howled down by service families who simply were no longer prepared to take Mrs Kelly's promises seriously when both she and they knew that the money was not available for anything beyond the cheapest cosmetic reforms.
Later on the article stated:
All of this is very true of course, but we are dealing with a Minister who, so far, has been little short of a disaster in her handling of the portfolio.

The next paragraph refers to the issue of the behavioural code of the Chief of the Defence Force. I will come back to the wisdom or lack of wisdom of the Chief of the Defence Force in trying to suborn the wives of his servicemen in this way. Later on, Mr Young says:

No one will deny the need for the normal courtesies that always have been extended in the services, but these guidelines go a long way to denying the political rights of defence families. They also reinforce the fear of retribution felt by many service wives for speaking out-a major factor identified in the Hamilton report on problems facing service families.

Put bluntly, if ministers do not perform-as Mrs Kelly and Mr Beazley are demonstrably not performing in the area of defence conditions of service-then they and their hired help should be open to the full brunt of political opprobrium the same as every other politician.

I think that puts very succinctly the Government's contempt for the service men and women of Australia. In a speech here a couple of weeks ago I said that one of the fundamental problems with the defence forces in Australia was the management system which has been the legacy of the Tange reforms and until that is completely restructured we will never get to the root of the problems that we have. It is true that the problems in relation to the conditions of service go back many years. But under a Liberal government, in which the party collectively and the Minister in particular took an interest in defence and had a real feeling and understanding for the needs of the defence forces, the inadequacies in the management system could be coped with in some way. But when we have a Mr Beazley and a Mrs Kelly who have never worn a uniform in their lives, never served in any branch of the defence forces for even a short time, when we have a party committed to the socialist-pacifist doctrines, the inadequacies of the management system that we have in the Department of Defence mean a complete breakdown in the operation.

A good management system does not necessarily of itself guarantee success; the corollary is alway's true: if we have a bad management system we simply cannot be successful. Until the system that we have of civilian operation of what is a specialised professional field is changed, we will go on with the sorts of problems that we have in relation to the services.

The lack of personnel at present means that we have to pull back people who should be in operational roles, who are trained for operational roles, into a training role to train new recruits. That means a lack of capability in the operational arm and a very much increased budgetary cost in re-training people that should not be necessary. But the crucial thing, as I said at the beginning of my remarks, is this lack of capability which we have now lost for a generation-for at least 10 years.

I am very much indebted to Senator Newman for the tabling of a paper earlier in the week from the Department of Defence on officer resignations between the period mid-February 1987 to 31 August 1987. In that paper 163 officers in the Army who had resigned were interviewed by the Psychological Research Unit. The reasons why those people resigned have been analysed. The officer in charge of the Psychological Research Unit commented:
The data appear to be of very good quality, with good variability between items and good internal consistency. On the basis of this preliminary analysis there are no internal contradictions.

It lists the general reasons for resignation as being family stability issues, leadership and career management issues, erosion of conditions of service, and a variety of lesser concerns. The first table deals with the reasons for leaving. More important, or of more interest to me, is the second table which analyses what the officers said would have to be improved in the Department of Defence for them to stay. Family events is one of the common themes-the family retained in one location during critical years of each child's education. But very high on the list-151 officers out of 163 said this-was: `A more positive commitment shown by senior officers towards service conditions'. Also, 151 officers said that they required better leadership by their superiors, and 152 said that they required greater loyalty from senior officers.

That leads me to the point that I wish to raise. There is apparent in the Services today a great deal of unrest about senior officers. There is a feeling that the chiefs of staff are not looking after the men and women in the service in the way in which the men and women think they ought to. The issuance of a code of conduct by the Chief of the Defence Force at the request of Mrs Kelly, Mr Beazley or someone in the Department, further degrades that trust and respect that the service people have for their leaders. Things like the defence supplement in the Australian of 13 November, in which the Chief of the Defence Force claimed that all is the best of all possible worlds are, in my judgment, acts of gross irresponsibility. The article is entitled `Forces capable of meeting credible contingencies'. Everyone knows we could not defeat a bunch of boy scouts landing in Botany Bay on a Saturday afternoon. The whole tenor of the article by the man responsible for the defence of Australia is misleading.

The problem we face here is that the senior ranks of the Australian defence forces have now become so politicised that we are not getting the objective professional advice from the service personnel at the top that the Australian public and this Parliament are entitled to.
