It comes back to the system that is in place, whereby the Secretary and the civilian component of the Department of Defence approve every promotion to one star and above in the Department. Senior officers are chosen not because of their forthright intellect and their ability to pursue a professional career but because they fit in well with the club that exists in Canberra. The club exists in Canberra because the Tange committee has such bloated headquarters on Russell Hill, with officers who serve so much of their lives in Canberra that they are divorced from the affairs of the men and women in the three Services. Their faces have to fit within the Russell Hill environment or their careers are not advanced. Officers are appointed to one star who are keen to become two-star officers. They will say nothing to anyone around them. They will not offend the politicians: they will not offend the Public Service. When they become a two-star officer, they want to be chief of staff. When they are chief of staff, they want to be Chief of the Defence Force. When they become CDF they want to be Governor. The only thing I can say is that if we have senior serving officers who are frightened of offending politicians, thank God they do not have a real enemy outside Australia to fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address comments and questions to three areas of Defence appropriation. The first relates to failure to appropriate funds in relation to some of the recommendations of the report of Mr Hogg to Cabinet. I seek leave to table a copy of the Hogg report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the recommendations of that report incorporated in Hansard. The document comprises about 12 pages.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I requested leave to incorporate the recommendations in Hansard to save me reading them, considering the time constraints which were explained to us earlier.

—I make one comment: the normal procedure, if one wants something incorporated in Hansard, is to bring it to the Minister's desk. It is nearly always cleared. Our only objection on this occasion may be to the size of the document because of the enormous cost of incorporating this sort of thing in publications such as Hansard. I just wanted to explain what the normal modus operandi is.
—I think the only way I can deal with these recommendations, Mr Temporary Chairman, is to read them.
—That is your prerogative.

—In view of the time constraints, I will think about that a little further and address more general comments to the Hogg report. I think everybody is aware that a fairly controversial process has been occurring in recent weeks under the direction of Mr Hogg. The process relates to an assessment of the adequacy or otherwise of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. I think everyone is also aware that the Australian Democrats believe that, in the public interest, the findings of Mr Hogg in relation to the Evatt Royal Commission and the recommendations thereto warrant public disclosure because they concern three areas, particularly veterans' affairs, which we, have discussed previously. The findings also relate to defence and areas of public health.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hogg has drawn attention to the fact that the Evatt Royal Commission made a number of recommendations 2 1/2 years ago in relation to the Department of Defence. I will read from the Hogg report which I have just tabled:
The Commission's findings-
he is referring to the Evatt Royal Commission's findings and recommendations-
included a number to be acted upon by the Defence Department or the Department of Veterans' Affairs relating to-
there are several which relate specifically to defence-
. . . the proper co-ordination, control, storing, recording and usage of chemicals.

I direct a question to the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) in relation to appropriations which will effect that recommendation for the proper co-ordination, control, storing, recording and usage of chemicals. I am seeking clarification from the Minister as to whether, since that recommendation was made 2 1/2 years ago, money has been appropriated to put that recommendation into effect, since we believe it interfaces with major issues of public health. The next recommendation which specifically relates to the Department of Defence-and I am quoting from the Hogg report, which presumably is quoting from the recommendations of the Evatt Royal Commission-reads as follows:
the improvement of psychological and psychiatric testing and services supplied to members of the armed forces;
A third and possibly more significant recommendation states:
the improvement of the quality of assistance given in the transition from service to civilian life particularly at the conclusion of combat experience;

This, of course, was the primary focus in relation to Vietnam veterans. Mr Temporary Chairman, you will observe that the recommendation relating to `the improvement of the quality of assistance given in the transition from service to civilian life' is of a general nature. My questions in relation to the Hogg report are twofold. Can we identify in the appropriations sums which will affect the precautions in relation to chemicals? Can we identify in the appropriations sums which will give effect to the recommendation regarding improving the quality of transition from service to civilian life?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Going to Senator McLean's points first of all, I must say just as an observation that his questions would be more appropriately dealt with by the Estimates Committee rather than the Committee of the Whole. Nevertheless, at this stage it is not possible to identify the expenditure to which the honourable senator referred. I am hoping at a later point today to have some further assistance in this matter. The questions that the honourable senator asked go to a lot lower level than the general allocations. If I can ascertain an answer this morning, I will certainly pass it on to the honourable senator when I am replying to other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon, in rather a bullish speech this morning, managed to offend 90 per cent of the military establishment. He made a major point about separation rates. Just for the record, the separation rates for the September quarter of 1987 totalled 2,518, whereas for the comparable period last year the figure was was 2,432 compared with a 10-year average of 2,076. These are figures that would concern any government. But I do not know that they justify the hysteria that was displayed by Senator MacGibbon this morning. I very much doubt that they do. In particular in this chamber during consideration of the Estimates in committee, specific comments have been made about the most worrying aspects of separation rates-that is, resignations from the Royal Australian Air Force. A variety of steps are being considered to try to reverse that trend. We have already announced some in terms of extended service of pilots when they sign up and coming to some sort of sensible agreement with Qantas Airways Ltd; We are even considering Senator Harradine's suggestion, although it was already under consideration, about the use of reservists as flight instructors.

Senator MacGibbon quoted what has been said by Mr Peter Young, who, I think we would have to say, is a professional military critic. He earns his living by being critical of the military. In fact, I think he earned his first political endorsement to run for office because of his role as a military critic.

TALK.START.PARA: —By the Labor Party.

—Yes. In fact, for a period, Mr McMahon denied us the pleasure of his company in the chamber across the way. Senator MacGibbon fairly vigorously, and I think very unfairly, attacked Mrs Kelly, the new Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. He did not really adduce much evidence in that attack, nor did he adduce much evidence in anything else he said. He made a lot of assertions but unfortunately he did so without some more fundamental underpinning of evidence. As a result, I do not take his views terribly seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, Senator MacGibbon said that the Australian Labor Party is not interested in defence because it follows socialist pacifist doctrines, that it has no military experience at all. Really, he can do better than that. The Labor Party has been quite dedicated to building up the defences of this country, to developing a strategy and adhering to it. It has not adopted just an ad hoc series of pre-election commitments, as the honourable senator's Party has done in the past. The policy of the Liberal Party of Australia on this matter has waxed and waned. But too often, for political reasons, the Liberal Party has sought to exploit military issues.

On the other hand, the Labor Party is very much dedicated to a world disarmament viewpoint. It is very easy to distort that commitment because we have long and short term goals. Our long term goal is worldwide disarmament, especially in the nuclear area. But at the same time, we do not think this sort of disarmament will be progressed by our ignoring or taking a pacifist view of our own armed forces. The defence paper which was brought down a few months ago is clearly a document on defensive strategy. We are building our defence forces around a defensive strategy, not an aggressive one under which we would seek to expand our borders or interfere unduly with our neighbours' affairs. I reject the charge that we are in some way, through some philosophical commitment-I think the honourable senator was saying this inadvertently rather than deliberately-white-anting the military forces of this country. I absolutely deny both charges.

Senator MacGibbon went on to say, to give himself an air of even-handedness, that there were some crook Liberal Ministers. I invite him to get up and name them. He is quite happy to rip into Mrs Kelly. He is quite happy to admit that there were some fairly bad Liberal Defence Ministers. Let us get their names on the records in a few minutes time. I will be very interested to hear the honourable senator's view on what their weaknesses were.

The honourable senator referred to the survey, on which I was ambushed the other day, as to the reasons people resign. I found that an interesting survey. I understand-and I will readily accept advice and be corrected on this-that almost exclusively the people being surveyed responded to suggested answers. From time to time I have had experience with surveying. The responses to this survey were what I would expect. It was not unusual for the people to respond in the way they did to suggest gripes. To me, the main value of that sort of survey is the extent to which the people concerned responded to some questions and not others. That is something that the Department of Defence and everyone else will have to take on board and examine carefully. But the value of all such surveys is slightly limited.

Senator MacGibbon alleged that if a bunch of boy scouts landed at Manly on Saturday the Australian armed forces could not defeat them. That is an insulting suggestion. It is one that is not in keeping with the honourable senator's dignity and wide knowledge of defence matters. It may have been made to make a colourful point, but I do not think that in his heart of hearts he believes it.

Senator MacGibbon went on to speak about politicisation of senior personnel. I am not really sure what he was referring to. He went on to say that all senior personnel are chosen by the civil side of the Defence Department, that there is some sort of Russell Hill clique and that there is a club atmosphere. It is true that the Secretary is consulted on all appointments but does not have to approve them. That is my understanding of the system. It is easy to make allegations of bloated bureaucracy, cronyism, et cetera. Those allegations would have a little more force if some evidence were brought forward. Senator MacGibbon seems to be working backwards. He is not happy with the performance of the senior people in the armed services. He says that is reflected in the view of the lower ranks and is one of the reasons for the current separation rates. In seeking a reason for that, he seems to build his case backwards. Unless he can give some evidence, I do not accept that some of the more senior appointments do not deserve to be there on merit.

Senator MacGibbon alleges that such senior personnel are simply careerists-I think that is a fair description of his allegation-that they become one-star generals and that all they ever live for is to become two-star generals. That is not unusual or necessarily a bad thing, provided that it does not interfere with their careers. Most people in this chamber who sit where Senator MacGibbon sits aspire to move somewhere else-a little closer to the front. Having ambition in the armed forces is not a bad thing. If, though, the proper goals of the military forces and their duties were sublimated and distorted by that ambition, he would have a strong case. But I have not heard him produce evidence of that here today. I do not want the honourable senator to name individuals in this chamber-I am sure that he does not want to-because that is most unfair. So we are both at a disadvantage in regard to his allegations. I do not think that what the honourable senator put forward here today has much substance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My questions to the Minister for Home Affairs relate to the proposed intelligence and monitoring operation at Geraldton. Before I ask specific questions, I will say a little about the Defence Signals Directorate (DSD), which is the Australian authority which will allegedly operate the new facility. According to Professor Des Ball, who wrote a book about the security arrangements between the United States (US), the United Kingdom (UK), Canada, Australia and New Zealand called The Ties that Bind, which was published by Allen and Unwin in 1985, the intelligence budget has doubled since 1978. Professor Ball's book is a very significant study of the security arrangements, the intelligence gathering operations and the sharing of information which occurs between those countries. The Defence Signals Directorate fits into that framework. I quote very briefly from Des Ball's book:

SPEECH.PARA: The Defence Signals Directorate (DSD) is described in the Commonwealth Government Directory as an organisation within the Department of Defence `responsible for defence signals and communications security'. Although there had been occasional references in the press to an Australian signals intelligence (SIGINT) organisation, the existence of the DSD was not officially acknowledged until the Prime Minister's statement on the Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security in the House of Representatives on 25 October 1977, when Mr Fraser stated:

`The Defence Signals Division is an organisation concerned with radio, radar and other electronic emissions from the standpoint both of information and the intelligence that they can provide and of the security of our own Government communications and electronic emissions. It is an agency which serves wide national requirements in response to national priorities.'
The first official recognition of the DSD was given by the then Prime Minister in 1977. However, as Des Ball pointed out in his book:
The history of the DSD can be traced back to 1939-40 . . .

So for all those years Australians were kept in the dark about the existence of this very significant aspect of Australian intelligence gathering organisations. Des Ball says that the six intelligence agencies-the Office of National Assessments, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, services intelligence directorates, the Joint Intelligence Organisation, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and DSD-have about 2,500 staff. As I have said, the entire intelligence budget has doubled since 1978. According to Des Ball's book, the Defence Signals Directorate provides the Australian intelligence community with substantial quantities of extremely valuable intelligence. It states:

Some examples, taken from the Annual Report of the Joint Intelligence Organisation, 1974, include South Korean diplomatic traffic, Pakistani diplomatic traffic after the Indian nuclear test, information on armed incidents between liberation movements and security forces in southern Africa, fighting on the Iran/Iraq border, French nuclear testing and pre-knowledge of detonations, the Indonesian order of battle in Irian Jaya and Timor, as well as diplomatic messages concerning world currency problems and national responses, diplomatic messages relating to the Law of the Sea Conference, Japanese diplomatic messages in general and in particular those with economic content, and `diplomatic messages emanating from a number of foreign missions in Canberra'. Other examples . . . Chinese nuclear, advanced weapon, and space-testing activities; on the Middle East, especially the Israeli-Egyptian-Syrian War of October 1973 and the involvement of the superpowers in that war; on Soviet naval activities in the Indian and Pacific Oceans; on Indonesian views on and activities against dissident groups on the Papuan New Guinea/Irian Jaya border; on the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea in December 1978, and on the subsequent Chinese invasion of Vietnam.

The report of the Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security in 1977 paid tribute to the work of the DSD and recommended that its status be enhanced. It stated: `DSD is a very capably managed agency and believed to be so by most of its staff and others who deal with it'. This is certainly the assessment of the Canberra consumers of the DSD's material. If there is any criticism-
this is a very important point to note-

it is that the DSDs collection activities are too wide-ranging and too indiscriminate, producing much intelligence of only marginal strategic significance. The foregoing examples of intelligence provided by the DSD suggests that the DSD is guided more by the requirements of the Western SIGINT community in which it is a major participant rather than by the more delimited requirements of Australian security.

That is the most important point to make. The activities of the DSD as they have operated in the past, and presumably as they will continue to operate and be further expanded by this enormous installation which is planned for Geraldton, will take Australia further into the area of gathering information which is perhaps fascinating for the defence community but not relevant to the defence of Australia. That point has been made over and over again. Given that, according to the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, our area of strategic influence should cover about 10 per cent of the world's surface and that the operations of the Geraldton base will be able to cover more than 30 per cent of the world's surface, the question needs to be asked again: On whose behalf are we collecting the information? It is not information which necessarily will be relevant to the defence of Australia. Under the United Kingdom-United States of America agreement which is the subject of the book The Ties that Bind-the 1947 agreement which is claimed by Des Ball to be one of the most secret security agreements of all time-the information will be passed on to the United States. So, on behalf of the United States intelligence community, we will be doing the work and passing on the information. Another very important point that is made in the book is that the information is not necessarily passed back. According to a former National Security Agency officer, all information goes to the United States but the United States does not totally reciprocate in passing it on to other powers. We ought to take that matter very seriously.

The DSD and the joint intelligence facilities that are available in the Australian community are far in excess of what the Canadian Government and other nations of a comparable size have. Again, the point needs to be made that we are doing the work on behalf of the Western alliance, and in particular on behalf of the United States, and are spending a great deal of Australian taxpayers' money on information gathering that is not relevant to our defence needs.

My specific questions relating to the base at Geraldton are: Firstly, how much money has been allocated for the purchase of the land; that is, the 35 hectares for the compound and the 415 hectares for the buffer zone? Secondly, how much money has been allocated for the computer systems; where will they come from and exactly what types of systems will they be? Thirdly, when will work on the infrastructure start? My fourth question relates to the overall budget. According to Des Ball, the joint intelligence agencies have staff of about 2,500. If Geraldton takes 125 people, which is what we have been told so far, that represents about 5 per cent of the total number of staff. Are extra staff to be allocated or will they be taken out of the existing intelligence community; that is, will they be transferred from one of the other agencies to the DSD facility at Geraldton? What will be the extra costs of the staffing allocation? The DSD's overall budget is about $30m. How much more will it be with the Geraldton facility added to it? Will the Government give some indication of why there is such a discrepancy between the original figure that was bandied about-I realise that it was an unofficial figure but I gather that reputable newspapers in this country had received it unofficially from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley)-of between $20m and $25m and the figure that is now being touted by members of the Department of Administrative Services in the Geraldton area of $300m? The question has been asked before and I ask it again. Finally, what are the total construction and running costs of the proposed Geraldton facility?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Home Affairs for his reply to me. It was quite obvious from the way in which he responded that my points went home in a significant way. He knows, as I do, that there are very real limits as to how far we can take this debate in public without prejudicing the careers of otherwise estimable members of the defence Services. Time is short, so I will not go into that in great detail. However, I would like to pick up a couple of his points.

SPEECH.PARA: He talked about ad hoc decisions being made before elections. The Australian Labor Party has a terrible record on this. One has only to look at the FFG and Leopard tank decisions of the Barnard era. One can look at the decision to proceed with the surface combatants before the last election in July this year. This was rushed through by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) as a selling point, before the Navy had worked out its requirements. Indeed, today the Navy still does not know what it wants those surface combatants to do from an operational point of view. One can also look, of course, at the way the submarine program was driven to a decision to precede the election.

That can be contrasted with the history of the Liberal-National Party Government. The FA18 contract was the biggest defence contract up till that time. That decision could have been taken before one of the elections. It was not, because the Chief of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, the Chief Defence Scientist, Professor Fink, wanted more time to look at the properties of the epoxy bonding of the graphite panels on the aircraft. He was concerned about their fatigue life. It is a matter of public record-in a speech made by the Chief Defence Scientist a year or two ago-that he went to the then Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, and said, `Minister, I understand you want the decision rapidly so that you can announce this with an election coming on. I am sorry, but I need more time'. Killen said to him, `You take all the time you want. It is important that the correct and proper decision in your judgment is made. The political considerations are quite secondary'. We do not see that philosophy followed in the Australian Labor Party.

Without going deeply into the matter, I want to talk about the politicisation of the senior levels of the Australian Defence Force. I have referred to this matter in the past in this chamber. The only point I want to add is that I emphasise that I am not talking about politicisation in party political terms. That is not part of my argument at all. What I am saying is that there is a very great danger that the advice that the Parliament and the executive Government get from the professionals in the service is increasingly tailored to what they perceive to be the view of the government of the day. Senator Robert Ray should be as concerned about that as we in the Opposition are.

I am sure that if Senator Ray had a tumour somewhere he would go to a surgeon and he would want that surgeon to give him accurate advice as to whether it was benign or malignant. Even if it was malignant he would want to know that so that he could put his affairs in order. There is a very great parallel between the advice tendered by senior serving officers and the sort of advice we would expect from specialist surgeons or other specialist people in this country. We want them to tell it like it is. We will worry about the political consequences; we will make the economic changes that are required to cope with them.

But as someone who has sat on Estimates committees interviewing senior officers, I make the statement without qualification that I have noticed over the last 10 years an increasing degree of politicisation in the advice that is given in this chamber and of officers thinking: `What does that senator want for an answer and what does the Government want?'. One can see their minds working, and one can see the way that things are changing.

Senator Ray brought up the resignation rates of pilots, and he mentioned that some changes had been made. For 20 years we have had an average loss rate of pilots from the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) of about 47 per year. For the last three years the loss rate has been 60, 70 and 107 for last year. We have a pilot training capability of somewhere between 55 and 65 a year. Against the loss of 107 last year we trained about 65. Up to this point in this financial year-in about four months-about 80 pilots have applied to leave. We are critically short of pilots. I applaud the moves that Senator Ray has made. They are common sense and they are the correct moves to make. But the fact remains that we are left with a very great shortfall in pilots.

There are two consequences of this. First of all, in losing 107 pilots we are not losing those just through their elementary or advanced flying training courses. We are losing pilots who have served at least eight years in the RAAF, pilots who are pretty close to 30 and who have the experience we need to flesh out the squadrons. We cannot take a pilot through an operational conversion unit, put him into a squadron and get him to do the difficult and dangerous things that the Royal Australian Air Force requires of its pilots.

We train realistically in this country. The operational squadrons fly those aircraft-whether they are the fighters or the strike aircraft, the F111s-to the limit for their flight envelopes. They fly them at night and they fly them in the worst of weather. The Royal Australian Air Force-with its F111 low runs, or terrain following runs-is the only air force in the world that trains at night and in bad weather. We have the best pilots in the world. Because funds have been run down we have fewer hours available for flying. What the Air Force has done is put fewer pilots in a squadron so that it can keep a figure of about 20 hours a month flying time for those pilots in the fighter squadrons. That is the correct thing to do, from a safety point of view. But because we have had fewer trained pilots, with the loss rates we have, we now have very few fighter pilots in this country.

We have very few instructors. We have a great shortage of instructors. So trying to compensate for the loss by putting more people through the schools runs into the brick wall of the great shortage of qualified flying instructors (QFIs). One of the sad things is that the pool of pilots from which the QFIs are drawn is that of the transport and helicopter squadrons. These are not the people we want to be instructors of a fighter squadron, because it is a different breed of cat-somebody who flies a 130 Hercules aircraft is different from the aggressive, cocky, quick-thinking, quick-reacting fighter pilot. The fighter pilot ethos is a very real thing. It is not so long ago-a year or so-that Singapore asked for some flying instructors. We sent up some from the RAAF and this was followed by the ignominious act of the Singaporeans sending them back because they happened to be transport flying instructors and the Singaporeans wanted fighter pilot instructors.

So the loss of trained pilots is enormously serious. It is a huge economic loss; it is a huge loss in capability. Even if we established a crash program and trained 150 pilots or whatever the figure required to bring us up to strength, we are looking at about eight to 10 years before we get those people capable of going into operations to do the sorts of things that we require of our pilots in the operational squadrons. The tragic accident last week involving a young FA18 pilot was, to the best of my knowledge, a normal training accident, if such a thing can be described in those terms. I certainly do not ascribe any fault to the Government for that. If we are going to train realistically we will have losses in lives and aircraft. But, unfortunately, that sort of thing will increase because of the lack of experienced pilots in the Air Force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be extremely brief because this matter has already been dealt with a number of times in the Chamber today and yesterday. I have just four brief questions on the Australian defence satellite communications station to be situated at Geraldton, Western Australia, which is, of course, of concern to all Western Australians. I will not ask the cost of the glossy brochure which was put out by the Department of Defence, of which I have here a photocopy. But I would like to say that this brochure really has a bit of the naive soft-sell about it. It has the usual salesman's ingredients. First of all there is a little fear: the suggestion that the spy-base is important to Australia's defence. Then there is a bit of flag waving: the suggestion that it will all be Australian owned. Then there is a bit of local fervour: the suggestion that it will be tremendous for the local shopkeepers. Finally, there is a sop to the conservationists: the suggestion that the Army will look after the environment. I repeat that: the Army will look after the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of the four questions I want to ask has already been asked, but I would also like an answer to it. The Government White Paper cited the cost of this station to be in the region of $25m. The figure being bandied around now is in the region of $300m. How much will it cost? Secondly, as it appears that we do not have the technology ourselves to operate such a station on our own, will the guts of the station be all United States technology? That is, are we going to have United States made computers and receivers so that they can receive information from United States satellites? Thirdly, because Australia is a signatory to the little-known United Kingdom-United States secret information treaty, will the information that we collect go to the United Kingdom and the United States? Fourthly, will that information then be passed back to us?

I would like to remind the Senate that we have not had the whole truth by any means about the other bases which we have in Australia, which are not Australian-owned, as this is purported to be. Also, governments in the past have been quite content to pass on the naive untruths, or not full truths, given to them by other nations. I would appreciate truthful answers to these questions this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the minimum of rhetoric, I have a number of brief questions about training. Who will train the personnel required to staff the Geraldton base? Will there be a need for advisers in the early stages of the operation of the base from other than Australia to get the whole thing on line?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reinforce Senator MacGibbon's opening comments about the gross inadequacy of the appropriations for the Department of Defence. A mere two weeks ago, we debated, as a matter of urgency, the crisis that is occurring within the defence forces. We are in a situation of national crisis, and that crisis, and the remedy for it, are not reflected in these appropriations. They reflect the Government's attitude, which is traditionally to ignore service problems because they are not represented in a high profile way. I would suggest that the climate is changing.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to cite the attitude of the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association in relation to these matters. Like, I would imagine, most other senators, I have received a letter bearing the signature of Major General John Whitelaw, the National President of the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association, in which he lists the grave concerns of those in the Services, and their families, today. It suggests that they are well and truly aware that we are in a state of crisis, and that they will be demanding action in a way not previously used by defence personnel. I quote partially from Major General Whitelaw's letter. He had already spoken about their concerns over the 2 per cent discounting of Defence Force retirement benefits, but that was not the essence of his comments. He was just citing previous ways in which Defence personnel had been maltreated by the present Government. He said:
I now wish to draw your attention to some other matters of concern to our Association:
proposed changes to the Defence Service Homes Loans Scheme.
the proposed introduction of the Military Compensation Scheme.
the inordinate delay in establishing the Defence Housing Authority.
the present unrealistic Service Allowance.
cuts in the ``Repairs and Maintenance'' Budget resulting in a continuing deplorable standard of Service Housing.
unacceptable restrictions on the payment of Education Allowance.
the non-implementation of the recommendations of the Hamilton Report-only one of the 15 recommendations has been partially implemented.
He has cited there six areas of grave concern to serving personnel. He continues:

Should these matters not be quickly and satisfactorily resolved the result will be further dissatisfaction in the Services, a decline in morale, an increased resignation rate, a reduction in Defence capability and increased costs.

Members of this Association and indeed most responsible Australians are greatly concerned about this state of affairs. We propose vigorously to press for an early resolution of these issues, and look forward to your active support.

That letter went to all parliamentarians. It is an expression of the extraordinary level of dissatisfaction that exists among serving personnel. It is a warning to this Government and, one would imagine, subsequent governments, that there is a level of concern that will lead to unprecedented actions. Senator MacGibbon has cited the fact that the lead times to put into effect solutions to problems of this magnitude are in the vicinity of one or two decades.

Those are the generalised comments. I would like to offer the Minister an alternative analogy about our capabilities to one that Senator MacGibbon offered and which, in broad terms, I would endorse. But let us make it more specific and cite the comments that senior Army officers made recently in the Press following major exercises which, in summary, admit that we could not defend a major metropolitan centre in this nation against conventional attack for beyond two weeks. I do not believe that to be an exaggeration. Those are not the words, but they are a reasonable translation, of statements made by those who are commanding our defence forces. The realities are that we have gross inadequacies. We have rampant low morale and resign- ation rates, and an extraordinary crisis, acknowledged here in this letter by the formal representative of those serving within the defence forces. That is not acknowledged but in fact denied by the present Government, to a level of irresponsibility which will cause a backlash from history that will condemn this Government as having totally neglected the defence of our continent and our nation.

Those were fairly broad condemnations, probably as broad as one could get, so I would now like to cite something more specific, and that is in relation to the Government's proposed actions to reorganise the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO). The reorganisation to make the DSTO a more effective and efficient organisation was announced by the Government on 12 October. As the Government may know, the manner and implication of this reorganisation is causing concern within the DSTO work force, and amongst unions associated with that work force. Unfortunately, we have another area of low morale emerging, and one that will undoubtedly grow as a result of a measure announced by the Government as recently as 12 October.

The concerns about the reorganisation of the DSTO can be put under three headings. First, there is opposition to the rationale of the reorganisation. There are those who simply reject the reasoning behind it. The essential thrust of the reorganisation is to concentrate more DSTO work on high level research and development. That would seem, on the surface, to be an appropriate emphasis. Existing routine work is to become the province of the private sector through contracted projects with the DSTO. On the surface, that would appear to be a reasonable suggestion. However, a valid question here might be: To what extent has the Government investigated the capacity and willingness of the private sector to do this before announcing the reorganisation? There is an assumption that the private sector is both willing and able to assume these responsibilities should that reorganisation be put into effect.

This question is relevant to the second major concern of the work force, about the proposed reduction in the work force numbers, and the extent to which target numbers will be achieved through redundancies. Will lost employment and positions in the DSTO be made up for by the private sector taking up more contract work from the DSTO? Even if the private sector does so, of course, that does not deny the fact that those within the DSTO are likely to be faced with redundancy. It does not prove the fact that, by bearing that redundancy, in the long run the reorganisation will be more effective and efficient anyway.

Finally, I refer to the animosity within the work force as to the manner in which the reorganisation is proceeding. There are complaints of lack of consultation and apparent vagueness of the process-vagueness in terms of its cost, its benefit and its progressive impact on the people involved and on people in the defence science and technology area in general. It would thus appear that the reorganisation is worth our close initial and ongoing examination. This does not necessarily mean that we should oppose the rationale of the reorganisation, but we are simply questioning its costs and its cost effectiveness. Although it is a form of privatisation, it may have its merits. The attitude of the Australian Democrats towards privatisation is to consider each proposal on its merits. It may well be that this proposal has merits, but there is no evidence in the Government's announcing of the proposal that it has examined the proposal in terms of its costs versus its benefits.

Therefore, my question is: When is the Government going to address, in terms of appropriations and policy, the extraordinary historical crises that we have on our hands in relation to our defence capability? Lastly, I ask the Minister to address himself to the specific questions I have posed in relation to the reorganisation of the DSTO.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to a few of the contributions that were made. Senator Vallentine made a contribution. When I asked her yesterday why she was breaking the conventions of this place, she said that she was not bound by them. Neither am I in her case, so I will proceed to the next contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon gave a far more mellow and constructive speech on the second occasion on which he spoke. I congratulate him on his improved form. He gave a detailed analysis of the problems that occur in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). I do not contest much of what he said. We are trying to redress those problems. I think that Senator MacGibbon would have to concede that those separation rates are somewhat distorted by what we call the `Vietnam bulge effect'; those recruited in the Vietnam period-in other words, the 20-yearers-are tending to be a disproportionate number of those who are resigning. It would be equally futile to argue that that is the sole or dominant reason for pilot separations in the RAAF.

Senator Jenkins raised a number of matters. She mentioned, firstly, the cost of the Geraldton project. I do not think that it was Senator Jenkins who mentioned the amount of $25m initially. We have searched the defence White Paper to try to find that figure and we cannot. If any honourable senator can assist us as to where it is in the defence White Paper, I would be interested to know because it has evaded our searches so far. I represent the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in this chamber and his instruction to me is that he will not release the cost of that project at this stage, especially any specific allocations of money. On the question of the technology involved, again if we are to give a detailed exposition of all the technology used we might as well have tourist tours around the base at Geraldton and tell everyone exactly what we are doing there. I was asked whether the information goes to the United Kingdom and to the United States of America. I am not able to assist the honourable senator on that matter. I do not have knowledge in that area. Whether the Minister for Defence will want to respond to that question, I will have to see. However, that is one matter I will send over for his consideration.

Senator Jenkins also asked whether that information boomerangs back. Again, that is related to the question: `Have we got the whole truth?'. No, honourable senators have not got the whole amount of facts that are available although that is not a result of a deliberate desire to mislead or distort. So the question of whether we have told the whole truth is an unfair one to my way of thinking. The answer to the question of whether we are going to make available the full facts about Geraldton, its purposes, exactly what it does and what it receives is categorically, no. I was asked whether we are giving truthful answers. I do not give a high morality to truth. I tend to be truthful out of expedience and pragmatism. It is much more difficult if one gets caught not telling the truth. Of course, if I am not telling all, there is confusion about whether I am telling the truth. I leave that philosophical question in Senator Jenkins's good hands.

Senator McLean made a number of points, almost to the point of being a harping critic. I ask Senator McLean: How much of the gross domestic product should we spend on defence? What other Government programs should we take money away from to reallocate to defence? If I had $2 billion, $3 billion, $4 billion or $5 billion given to me tomorrow and was told that I could spend it on extras for the Defence Force, I would be absolutely delighted. An almost infinite amount of money could be spent on defence. I would love to see more money spent on defence. Of course, Senator McLean is sitting there in the luxury of never having been in government, the luxury of being a carping critic and the luxury of appealing to every minority group in the community, without ever having realistically to outline the way in which he would raise the revenue, how he would carve it up and how he would deal with thousands of different priorities. That is an easy life. We do not have those sorts of easy lives.

Some of the criticisms Senator McLean has made are not justified; others are. However, he has to understand that in terms of framing a Budget we do not have an infinite amount of money to make available for defence. I would love to be a fly on the wall in Senator McLean's party room. Given the pacifist views of many other honourable senators in his party room, if we were to walk into this chamber and say that we were going to spend an extra $2 billion, $3 billion, $4 billion or $8 billion on defence, I wonder what the response would be. We would be accused of being fascists, of being militarists and of trying to provoke and destabilise this region by such a massive increase in defence spending. It is the old trick of the soft and hard cop working two sides of the street. I do not accept it.

I ask Senator McLean to correct me if I am wrong, but the one or two specific points he made referred to Defence Science and Technology Organisation loans. The working party on that will be reporting shortly, I am informed. I think Senator McLean raised also the question of military compensation. We are awaiting the Government's response in relation to the overall issue of compensation. I think that matter is before Cabinet at the moment. It is considering the compensation issue in regard to all Government departments. Of course, the Defence Housing Authority has now been established. Finally, I think Senator McLean made a point about the service allowance. The Australian defence forces argued this matter at the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal hearing. On this occasion it failed to convince the Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government argued against it.
—The Government often intervenes in cases.
—The Government does not intervene.

—Of course we do. Of course we have intervened on occasions. As Senator MacGibbon would know, we have just intervened in the building industry matter to put a case before a variety of tribunals. Indeed, it was only last week that the Government intervened on the Remuneration Tribunal to put the case that the 11.7 per cent wage increase was not justified for the honourable senator and me. The Government does intervene. I hope that Senator MacGibbon at least agrees with that. He may say that we do not intervene enough or in the method or mode that he would like. As I said, the Tribunal did not, on that occasion, uphold the allowance that was sought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take on board the criticisms of the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). I suppose at this stage it is reasonable to make the observation that I have only been critical. However, I intend to be constructive in my suggestions as time goes on in this place. The Minister might refer to my maiden speech, in which I--
—I missed it, I am sorry.
—I will send the Minister a copy.
—Signed?

—Yes, indeed. In my maiden speech I commended to the Government the process of lateral thinking in relation to lots of things. One particular suggestion I made was that if it could do some lateral thinking in shifting the emphasis from the military defence model to a civil-military defence model, project its thinking three or four decades ahead and completely change the whole rationale on which we plan and expend in relation to defence the moneys would be readily available. I cited the fact that we fund our volunteer bushfire brigades, our volunteer coastal patrols and our volunteer rescue organisations by selling lamingtons on street corners. As a result, those organisations are grossly inadequate.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet we expend literally billions of dollars on and in areas of defence which only can be judged to be a complete and utter waste of public expenditure. If we did some lateral thinking and shifted from the essentially historical, outdated and outmoded model of military offensive-defensive thinking to a civil-military model, we would get better value for money and the $7.6 billion appropriated to defence would be used much more effectively. It is my intention to develop that model. If I contribute nothing more to this place, one of my primary objectives in the next three years is to develop an alternative model along those lines. I am delighted that the Minister has said that he would love to consider any propositions we put on the table in relation to defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —And revenue.

—Yes, and revenue. I must correct one of the Minister's fundamental misconceptions about the Australian Democrats. The Democrats are not anti-defence. We are pro-defence but anti-nuclear. That distinction should not be beyond the Minister or anybody in this chamber. I enunciate it quite clearly here and now so that the confusion the Minister has just fallen into hopefully can be avoided in the future. So I take on board the criticisms the Minister has made. I offer the promise-that is a dangerous word, I realise-hopefully to make a contribution of alternative approaches to defence which will be considerably cheaper and much more cost-effective.

—In response to Senator McLean, of course we look forward to any suggestions. I stand by my comments on the Australian Democrats. I have just defended myself from the same accusation from Senator MacGibbon as Senator McLean has just done today. I guess we can both feel affronted in the one day because we have a very similar attitude; that is, a strong Australian defence. We are working for world-wide disarmament, especially in the nuclear area. I have listened to a lot of fairly pacifist speeches from the Democrats over the years and have drawn my own conclusion. But no doubt somewhere in the Democrats' extensive national platform there is a fully-fledged defence policy. I understand that the sort of lateral thinking the honourable senator has in mind will now be accommodated by slightly new decision-making processes in the Democrats, where democratic centralism will play a little more prominent role than it did previously. I knew 10 years ago that that would eventually occur if the Democrats wanted to develop an up to date, flexible and intelligent policy.

—I have a number of things to raise in the appropriations debate concerning the Department of Defence. In view of the approaching suspension of the sitting I will not have long to do so. However, I would like to begin by complimenting the Department-I am sure that will shock it more than anything else I can say-on having changed its approach to Estimates committee hearings. The Department would well know, although not all honourable senators would know, that over many years the Estimates committee investigating the Department of Defence has been extremely critical of the numbers of people from the Department who have attended the hearings but who have still been unable to answer questions on the day and have taken so many questions on notice. Nasty aspersions have been cast by many senators on the Department for the reasons behind this. I hate to be considered to be overly cynical but it seems to be a very convenient arrangement for any department to take its questions on notice and so polish the answers to suit either the Department's or the Government's purpose.
—At least they are all answered.
—No, they are not-not this time.
—There are three to come.

—Where have they been answered? The Minister can have his turn later; I am having mine now. I am pleased to tell the Committee that this time the Department sent far fewer officers but, on the whole, much more senior ones. It was very refreshing to be able to question senior serving officers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address my comments to some remarks Senator Stone made at the committee stage of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) on 20 November. Senator Stone used that occasion to launch a personal attack on Jack Marks, a leading trade unionist in Western Australia. I have known Jack Marks for many years. He has held a number of elected positions within the trade union movement during that time. He was elected to those positions because he had the confidence of the rank and file membership of the union to which he has dedicated his working life-the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. The reality is that one does not become or remain an elected official in the trade union movement without displaying qualities of integrity and leadership, but Senator Stone and his ilk do not want to deal in industrial realities. They want to create myths in order to attack the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone described Jack Marks as being `a notably malevolent member of the trade union movement in this country' who led, among others, `a small band of trade union thugs operating at Pannawonica and Wickham in the Pilbara'. My dictionary defines `malevolent' as `wishing evil or harm on others, malicious'. The term `thug' means `rough, brutal gangster or robber, originally a member of a fanatical religious organisation in India'. They are words which, properly used, would sit easily with Senator Stone. The whole fanaticism of Senator Stone's beloved New Right movement is directed to exploiting the working people of Australia for the benefit of the rich and powerful. That is real thuggery.

Senator Stone, who has spent the main part of his career as an unelected and closeted senior bureaucrat far from the hard reality of the production of real goods, is again displaying his wilful and abysmal ignorance of industrial relations matters. The reality is that Jack Marks, as President of the Mining Unions Association, and other trade union leaders spent a great deal of time and effort persuading workers to resist management attempts to provoke confrontation at Robe River. That is not my version of what happened; it can be seen on the public record if Senator Stone and his friends are prepared to examine the public record in an impartial way. Marks and many other union officials were severely criticised by many within the trade union movement for not seeking to escalate the dispute at Robe River to a Pilbara-wide or even an Australia-wide dispute. Perhaps Senator Stone might like to debate the issue with Jack Marks on live radio or television, then the public can determine for itself exactly who is or has been malevolent or a thug. I would be happy to help organise that debate because I am confident who would win. It would not be Senator Stone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly today about an issue which has received relatively little public attention to date, and certainly not in our major capital cities, but which represents a disturbing development in furthering Australian involvement in the international nuclear industry. It concerns a $7m development application to convert a disused brewery at Tuncester, on the outskirts of Lismore, into a rare earth processing plant. The application has been lodged with the Lismore City Council by the Queensland company Deckhand Pty Ltd, which is a wholly owned company of Currumbin Minerals Pty Ltd, an Australian sand mining and heavy mineral processing company producing monazite, rutile and zircon.

SPEECH.PARA: The function of this plant would be to process monazite and other mineral by-products of sand mining in order to extract mineral components known as rare earths. These elements have uses in the glass, ceramics, illumination and chemicals industries but are also vital to the metallurgy, electronics, weaponry and nuclear industries. This obviously is where my primary interest in the matter lies since the products and by-products of this operation are highly radioactive.

Australia currently dominates the world monazite market, with approximately 85 per cent of international sales, but has not to date been involved in the processing or purifying of rare earths which increases their value to 10 to 15 times that of the raw product. Australia presently exports monazite concentrate to France, the United States of America and Japan for processing. The proposed plant at Tuncester would be Australia's only rare earth processing facility. The development of this new industry raises some serious concerns about effects on the health of the local people and plant workers and its impact on the environment of the region, as well as local primary industry, tourism and property values.

Consequently, there exists very strong local feeling against the Deckhand proposal. Seven thousand Lismore residents have felt strongly enough about the issue to sign petitions opposing the plant's establishment. They represent a quarter of the population and include a wide cross-section of people in that area. The people of Lismore and elsewhere oppose the plant on a number of grounds, not least of which is the use of rare earth products in nuclear technology. The sand mining industry has for many years been closely tied to the nuclear industry. The development of this plant could potentially implicate Australia even more deeply in the supply of radioactive materials to the international nuclear industry.

Although only a relatively small proportion of the world's rare earth compounds are used in this way, their applications are disturbing. Thorium 232 can be reprocessed to produce uranium 233, and thus becomes a principle fuel for fast breeder reactors-as in India and the United States. Uranium 233 is also used in nuclear weapons manufacture and rare earths generally are vital components in supermagnets, superconductors, missile guidance systems and lasers-all of which are employed by the United States strategic defence initiative (SDI) program. The Government claims to be opposed to the Reagan Administration's Star Wars efforts, yet such opposition is completely at odds with the processing and export to the United States of strategic materials which are vital to the SDI program-the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons notwithstanding.

In addition, there are enormous health and environmental questions to address. Deckhand would annually produce and store 865 tonnes of radioactive toxic waste, including thorium, uranium, radium and lead residues. Thorium, for example, remains radioactive for 14 million years. It is more highly radioactive than uranium tailings and emits radon gas. There is no known safe method of disposal for such waste. Yet the company intends to establish the plant and-as is characteristic of the nuclear industry-cross its fingers and hope that technology will provide it with a means of disposal at some time in the future.

In the meantime Deckhand proposes to store its radioactive waste on site in sealed fuel drums for `temporary storage' of three years with an extension every two years from then on if no national waste repository site has been found and established. Potentially, then, the waste materials could be on site beyond the 20-year working life of the plant. What guarantees do we have that Tuncester will not attract wastes from other plants and very quickly become a de facto toxic waste dump?

A question also exists as to whether or not the proposed storage drums will be capable of safely containing these wastes over time. Decomposition will result in a liquid waste with a Ph level sufficient to breach the plastic seals, allowing acid liquid to contact the steel drums, resulting in rapid corrosion. Potentially, then, highly radioactive liquid materials could escape into the storage areas. Even if the form of storage proposed by Deckhand were to be as effective as it expects, the company claims that the containment will only absorb most of the residue radiation. Exactly how much this amounts to is not specified; in fact, the lack of quantitative data in the development application generally is very disturbing.

In addition to the extremely serious and unsolved problems of waste storage and disposal, the environment will be further damaged by waste water from the plant. According to Deckhand's submission, 320 million litres of radioactive and toxic waste water will be piped from the plant every year. It will include 13 kilograms of thorium, 0.68 kilograms of uranium and traces of radium 226 and lead 210. Mr Brian Thomas, Deckhand's Director and the head of the Department of Physics at the Queensland Institute of Technology, claims that the plant will be completely and utterly safe because thorium and uranium levels are below those permissible under New South Wales legislation. However, it is worth while noting that the relevant legislation-the New South Wales Radioactive Substances Act and Regulations-was enacted in 1957 and 1959 respectively. Can we regard 30-year-old legislation pertaining to safe radiation levels as adequate?

The company proposes to pipe its radioactive waste water to the South Lismore sewerage works for unspecified treatment and then to the Wilson and Richmond rivers before reaching the sea at Ballina. Deckhand's environmental impact study does not deal with the environmental effects on the aquatic environment and specifically the likelihood of biomagnification of contaminants; that is, the concentration of toxins up the food chain to birds and other animals. Radioactive contaminants have implications for the entire ecosystem of the Lismore region. It is estimated that wastes in the water system could accumulate at levels up to 10,000 times higher than those of the surrounding environment. The plant would also pump additional phosphate and nitrogen wastes into a river system already struggling to cope with its present levels of pollutants.

The company has also not considered the environmental effects of a burst or fracture to the three-kilometre long waste water line between the plant and the sewerage treatment works. The former occupant, Carlton and United Breweries, experienced a number of these breakages. West German academic, Associate Professor of Physics Phillip Jennings, notes that ruptures of the liquid waste pipelines have been a frequent event at the SCM plant at Australind in Western Australia. The groundwater there is now heavily polluted. The environmental future for the Lismore area appears to be even more alarming when one considers the chemical component of the proposed plant's operations. Eighteen truckloads of volatile chemicals and fuels will arrive at the plant every week-18,000 tonnes per annum-and up to 700 tonnes will be stored on site at any one time. Aside from the obvious risks of fire and explosion, which the company attempts to minimise in its submission, there remains the question of spillage either in transit or on site. According to Professor Jennings, `some spillages are inevitable'.

Airborne radioactive contaminants pose a further health risk to the area. Deckhand admits that the radioactive gases, radon and thoron, will be released into the atmosphere from both the processing plant and the waste treatment plant. Prevailing winds will carry these gases towards Lismore. In addition, the dust created by the process poses risks to those working with and transporting monazite. The company estimates the leakage of radioactive dust from the mill room to be as high as 10 per cent per hour. Inhaled mineral sands dust is considered by health workers to present the greatest risk because the inhaled dust can remain in the lungs for long periods of time whilst it continues to emit radiation. The Queensland Government has recently accepted a compensation claim by a Brisbane metal worker who is dying of leukaemia after being exposed to radioactive mineral sands mined and sold by Currumbin Minerals. This company failed to reprocess its beach sand to remove the radioactive minerals before selling it for sand blasting purposes. Currumbin Minerals did not take the opportunity to make its product safe, and it is the parent company of Deckhand Pty Ltd which now seeks approval for the establishment of a mineral sands processing plant situated within a 10 minute drive of a large population.

Despite evidence such as this, the company seeks to claim our trust by saying that it can and will operate this facility safely and without risk to the public. Even the health of Deckhand's potential employees has not been properly considered, let alone the health of the people of Lismore. For example, the plant caretaker's cottage is situated directly between the radioactive processing area where radon gases are released from the stack and the waste repository site. Deckhand's environmental impact study admits, at page 85, that the public and employees will be subject to radiation exposure. Does it really expect the public to accept happily and compliantly its claims that these exposures will be `as low as reasonably achievable'? In view of the industry's record, the assurance which the company gives about acceptable limits must be viewed somewhat sceptically. Its application constantly refers to acceptable levels of risk and minimal environmental effects. How many times over the past decade have we been given such assurances by profit motivated, vested interests who want us to accept new technology in our backyards, only to find that these assurances counted for nothing? Witness organochlorides, DDT, thalidomide and nuclear energy.

Deckhand's assurances are predicated on the belief that there is such a thing as a safe level of radiation. This belief must be refuted. Maximum permissible exposure rates have been reduced again and again in recent years as more has become known about the effects of radiation. Dr Karl Morgan, former President of the International Commission for Radiological Protection, states that there is overwhelming evidence to show that there is no safe level of exposure and no dose of radiation so low that the risk of malignancy is zero. Furthermore, the risk is cumulative; that is, plant workers will be subject to repeated exposures, as will the local population. Overseas research in similar plants has shown death rates amongst plant workers to be significantly higher than the national average and that they experience an increased incidence of genetic disorders and infertility.

Even if we disregard for the moment the health and environmental risks of this rare earth proposal, there remains the question of the plant's economic feasibility. Deckhand is inexperienced in this field and may soon be competing against a similar plant proposed by the French company Rhone-Poulenc at Pinjarra in Western Australia. This company is the world leader in rare earth processing and its proposed plant would have the capacity to process all of Australia's monazite output. Mineral sands processing is a highly competitive industry and many companies have gone bankrupt. For example, the Port Pirie plant in South Australia ceased operations in mid-1972 after only a few years of operation because it could not break into the world market.

It is instructive to note that mineral sands enterprises elsewhere have also gone bankrupt, leaving behind their radioactive mess-for example, the Wonnerup plant in Western Australia, where the State Government is currently footing the bill to clean up the site since the company is no longer in business. What are the provisions for clean-up if Deckhand also goes out of business in the event of mismanagement? There is no indication that the company will be insured for clean-up costs if the venture fails to be profitable. After decommissioning, the plant may become a huge drain on the public purse and perhaps even a site to be guarded for many decades to come. If the company does experience financial difficulties the first rule of business is to cut costs. In the past this industry has looked first to stinting on the environmental and health safeguards which companies consider to be expensive. We should note the poor environmental records of other plants which process mineral sands-for example, those in Western Australia and Tasmania which have all been subject to Environment Protection Authority inquiries because of toxic gas emissions, liquid waste spillages and groundwater contamination. I do not need to recite the many problems which this industry has caused, they are catalogued in the reports of two Western Australian Government inquiries-the Winn report on radiation effects and the Playford report on environmental effects. Experience must make us sceptical about Deckhand's assurances. The Lismore Chamber of Commerce strongly supports Deckhand's proposed rare earth plant but one must surely question the overall advantage of providing a mere 20 jobs--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I seek leave to extend my remarks for a minute or so.
—Is leave granted?
—No.
—There being objection, leave is not granted.
—Perhaps I should move that so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent me from continuing my remarks.
—Why don't you give him a couple of minutes and don't be so churlish?

—I have discussed the matter with the Government Whip, and the arrangements were made with him. If Senator Button has a contribution to make he should make it. We would like to know who is running the Parliament. Does the Government know? The point is that we are past 1 o'clock, and I believe that in that situation we are not able to take votes in this place and consequently I cannot see how Senator Wood's proposition can be accepted.
—I point out to Senator Wood that a vote cannot be taken until 2 o'clock.

—For the sake of two minutes, some grace from the honourable senator would have been appreciated. Very often in this place we are asked to give leave for one thing or another. In fact this place could not run if individual senators refused leave to other senators, and I would ask the honourable senator to reconsider his objection to granting leave.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am not going to prolong the debate on this issue. Under Sessional Orders no votes can be taken at the moment. The simple solution to the dilemma that we are in-and I have passed a note to Senator Wood to this effect-is that all he need do is wait until Senator Watson makes his contribution and he can then stand again, gain the recognition of the Chair and conclude his remarks. Everybody knows-and Senator Wood should know-that this debate is limited to 15 minutes per person, and we should all understand the need to keep within the confines of that restriction. It is very unusual to ask for extensions of time in the Senate; I cannot recall any such occasion in the short period of three years that I have been here.
—My ruling stands. There being an objection, leave is not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes of the Senate's time to discuss the loss of continuity of the Senate and to offer some proposals aimed at trying to resolve double dissolution deadlocks. When the Parliament was dissolved on 5 June this year, no senator had actually served the full six-year term for which he or she was elected. The continuity of the Senate, therefore, has been eroded by the trend in recent years increasingly to make use of section 57 of the Constitution, which relates to double dissolution.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 73 years between Federation and 1974, there were actually only two double dissolutions-on 5 September 1914 and 28 April 1951. Yet in the 13 years since then we have seen four double dissolutions-18 May 1974, 13 December 1975, 5 March 1983 and 5 June 1987. Clearly the circumstances have changed since our founding fathers settled on the formula for the resolution of legislative deadlocks between the Senate and the House of Representatives. Both major parties must take some responsibility, because there are problems with double dissolution provisions. The first, of course, is the loss of continuity of the Senate, and the second is that it may be merely a trigger for an early election rather than a genuine means for resolving a deadlock between the Upper House and the Lower House.

So far as the loss of continuity of the Senate is concerned, one of my concerns is that one of the principal tasks of the Senate is to act as a House of review. Traditionally, it is in this chamber that alternative views may be presented for discussion, and amendments suggested to proposed legislation. In order to assist the Senate in the function of review, it was a continuous body, to be dissolved only by a double dissolution. To achieve this continuity, section 13 of the Constitution provides for the rotation of senators. While actual events modelled themselves on this theory for many years, the frequency of double dissolutions in recent times has really led to the Senate becoming more reactionary and a political body. The Senate's function as a House of review, I contend, is being undermined. In the words of Professor Geoffrey Sawer, recorded at page 17 of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice:
. . . there is no point in having a House of review unless you have some degree of difference between the points of view of the Houses, and you get that more with the staggered system of election.

If we wish to maintain the traditional role of the Senate, perhaps it is time to conduct a review of the conditions that have lead to the dissolution of the Upper House four times in the past 13 years. It has long been the contention that a double dissolution ought not to follow the Senate's legitimate exercise of its function of review, but should apply where responsible Government is impossible. Unfortunately, nowadays it is becoming a tool for granting a political advantage.

So while the principle draws broad support, the definition of the circumstances that prevent responsible government have often sparked heated debate. While the rhetoric runs high about the importance of the Bills that trigger double dissolutions, actions often suggest that they are of less significance than the onlooker may have believed. Take, for example, the most recent election. The Australia Card Bill provided the trigger for a double dissolution when, on 2 April 1987, it was defeated in the Senate for the second time. Yet it was not until 28 May, some two months later, that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) actually requested that the Governor-General exercise his power to dissolve both Houses of Parliament.

Should we then perpetuate a system that allows a mechanism designed to resolve genuine deadlocks between both Houses to be manipulated simply for political gain at the cost of undermining the traditional function of the Senate as a House of review? I ask: Would it not be more prudent to start investigating some alternatives for the resolution of deadlocks that are actually less vulnerable to political manipulation and place a greater responsibility on the elected representatives to try to solve their differences for the benefit of Australia as a whole? I think some of the alternative proposals that we should look at should be based on this principle of conciliation as the aim rather than confrontation. For example, there is reason to give some consideration to alternative proposals, or the clarification of existing provisions for the resolution of differences between the two Houses. Some of these mechanisms might include, for example, a managers conference. In my State of Tasmania the State Parliament selects representatives from both Houses to meet and attempt to resolve these differences. Secondly, we could have more referendums on the particular issues which are actually in question.

Whatever the outcome may be, I believe now is the time for a reconsideration of existing provisions. The last time there was a substantial discussion was about 37 years ago when a select committee of the Senate was appointed to discuss the Constitution Alteration (Avoidance of Double Dissolution Deadlocks) Bill. But circumstances really have changed quite a lot in that time. A joint all-party committee should be established, as a matter of some urgency, by this Parliament to review all the mechanisms for resolving the differences between the Senate and the House of Representatives. Naturally the Constitutional Commission could look at this. The point I am making is that a lot more effort is required by both Houses of Parliament to try to resolve issues of deadlock between the two Houses than is presently the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue the speech I was making before my time expired, Mr Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and regret any inconvenience that may have been caused by my inexperience.
—Your inexperience is manifested by your courtesy, Senator.

—I thank Senator Button. The Lismore Chamber of Commerce strongly supports Deckhand Pty Ltd's proposed rare earth plant, but one must surely question the overall advantage of providing a mere 20 jobs for 20 years in an area with an unemployment rate of 20 per cent. Even if the plant could provide full employment in the region, would it be worth the risks it represents?

SPEECH.PARA: In response to public pressure, the New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment has appointed an inquiry into the proposal. This inquiry has received 50 submissions against the plant and only five in favour of it. Mr Unsworth himself has indicated some concerns about the proposal despite his previous enthusiasm for the development of the industry. Unfortunately, though, even the commissioner conducting the inquiry on behalf of the Lismore City Council does not have the power to subpoena very relevant information about the company's proposal. Commissioner Simpson is forced to rely on that information which Deckhand decides to present freely. The company will not even release the exact routes by which the monazite will be transported between the source of supply and the proposed plant because of `commercial considerations'. The company, I would suggest, would not disclose these routes precisely because to do so would have revealed the sites of its current stockpiles of mineral sands. Not surprisingly, it fears that public knowledge might generate a controversy similar to that which erupted in the early 1980s over the radioactive contamination of the Byron Bay area.

The residents of Lismore are, therefore, being denied access to information about the transit of radioactive substances through their own community. Local residents are now calling on the Federal Government to appoint a royal commission to inquire into all aspects of the Lismore rare earth proposal and the industry generally in an effort to extract information not currently available to them about the ways in which this proposed plant will affect the health of themselves, their families and the natural environment of the area in which they have chosen to live.
