Deckhand, like so many other commercial interests, is scrambling to gain a slice of the pie in this relatively new industry without proper regard and respect for the health, safeguards, storage, waste disposal and environmental impacts of its proposal. What price will residents of Lismore pay for such development? The Chernobyl and Three Mile Island disasters stand as silent testimony to the folly of science and technology in developing an industry before they were prepared for or capable of dealing with its hazards.
Sitting suspended from 1.16 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that Senator Tate will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today as he is attending the National Crime Authority Inter-Governmental Committee in Hobart. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Tate in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to Senator Reynolds.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is it a fact that the exit interest rates being earned by the Commonwealth superannuation fund have fallen from 23 per cent in July to zero per cent at the end of November? Is it a fact that contributors to the Commonwealth superannuation fund who have recently retired but who will not receive any payouts from the fund until after next Monday, 30 November 1987, will receive zero per cent interest on their money in the fund since 1 July this year? If this is so, is it publicly known? Is it also a fact that a senior officer of the Commonwealth superannuation fund board submitted his resignation on Tuesday, 24 November and officially retired yesterday and is to receive the 23 per cent for this period? Does the Minister know whether this officer has received privileged treatment? If he does not, will he make immediate inquiries and let the Parliament know today what the position is?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney has put me in an awkward position, not because I mind disclosing the facts but because I had intended to put out a Press release tomorrow that would be a bit more comprehensive than the answer I am able to give here. Since I have been asked the question, it is probably just as well that I put out the essential facts now. The 22 per cent, which I think is a correct figure, was the exit rate--
—I was given 23 per cent.

—It was 23 per cent or something like that. That was the figure for the entire financial year. It has been the practice within a financial year for a quarterly exit rate to be declared, based on the apparent earnings of the fund in that quarterly period. People who retire within that quarter receive a pro-rata amount calculated in that way. I mentioned last week that the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust is less exposed than most other superannuation funds to the decline in the share market, but it appears that, following that decline, the earnings rate to the end of October is probably negative. However, the law, I am advised, does not allow a negative notional payment, so I have made a determination that the exit rate for the September quarter will be zero. I was hesitant there not because of the zero figure but because I was not certain precisely what it applied to, but I think it is the September quarter. I suppose that should be taken as a formal announcement.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the resignation, I know nothing about that. I would like to check this but I am fairly confident that it is correct. I just thought of something else. I am not trying to be evasive; I am trying to think of what advantages might be conferred on certain people by making this available. If, however, someone did resign on 24 November, my expectation is that that person would not gain from it because no exit rate had previously been determined for the September quarter or any subsequent period. I will check that out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer. I note the final part where he expressed the view that somebody with inside information, if you like, would be unlikely to gain. I simply ask, in light of the fact that that matter clearly has been raised with the Opposition, whether he can make inquiries and give us an answer as early as possible. I think the Minister would agree that that sort of allegation goes to the confidence that people feel in the system. I will be grateful if the Minister can indicate that he will check the position and let us know, preferably today, but, if not, as early as possible.
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen a transcript of an interview of Liberal Party President, John Elliott, on Michael Schildberger's radio program this morning? Does the transcript add any greater definition to the proposals for a mini-Budget to bring in a $3 billion surplus this year, which Mr Elliott has put forward a number of times over the last couple of weeks? Will the Government examine the proposals with a view to their implementation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the transcript of this morning's Schildberger program, during which Mr Elliott said, among other things:

ANSWER.PARA: I made two comments, one, there ought to be a $3 billion cut in expenditure and I think that's right that was Elders view and the other one is that you cannot have the Reserve Bank propping up the dollar. I think there's been a bit of that and it's better to let it fall to its natural level. I think those two comments hold.

That is a fairly significant expression of an opinion about policy coming from somebody who has said that he will not publicly offer opinions about policy. In reply to Senator McKiernan's question, that statement has significantly clarified Mr Elliott's view. Previously he had called for a $3 billion Budget surplus, leaving open the question as to whether that was to be achieved by reductions in expenditure, increases in taxation or a mixture of both. It is now quite clear that he believes that it should be done by reductions in expenditure. That again emphasises the difference between the Liberal Party's extraparliamentary leadership and its parliamentary leadership. The view put by the Opposition during the election campaign was that expenditure should be cut to fund tax cuts. Mr Elliott's view is that expenditure should be cut; implicitly, taxation left alone; and a Budget surplus produced instead of the neutral Budget or the balanced Budget which Mr Howard was talking about during the election campaign, although, of course, he failed to address the specifics as to how that was to be achieved and made a $1,500m error with his arithmetic as well. Mr Elliott is, at least implicitly, if not explicitly, rejecting the Howard tax cuts proposal.

I also note from the Schildberger transcript that Mr Elliott has left open the opinion of the Liberal Party including a consumption tax in its policy, thereby effectively repeating the statement which he was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 26 October as having made the day before. The report stated:
Mr Elliott told reporters in Port Kembla last week that as President he would continue his push to change the Liberal tax policy in the direction of broadening the indirect tax base . . .

He still remains of that view and he is still publicly canvassing that as a policy option in spite of commitments that he is alleged to have given previously. I note again the comments by Mr Michael Pratt, the would be latter day Andrew Jones and the endorsed Liberal Party candidate for the Federal seat of Adelaide, who said:

I'm excited that John Elliott is aggressive and resilient and strong. Andrew Peacock is a man of immense character in terms of a Treasury portfolio and John Howard-he's toughed out some tough times, he's really had to fight and claw his way back.
So if there should be a by-election for the Federal seat of Adelaide I look forward to seeing Mr Pratt campaigning on the application of a consumption tax and an assets test amongst other things.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to the annual report of the Australian Audit Office tabled yesterday in which the retiring Auditor-General, Mr John Monaghan, drew attention to formal advice from the Department of Finance in the wake of this year's Budget process which made explicit that Department's ambition to confine and limit the scope of the Audit Office's external audit function. I ask the Minister whether he can confirm that the Department of Finance has sought to circumscribe the Auditor-General's clear audit mandate in this way; and, secondly, whether he is prepared to provide an unequivocal assurance to the Senate that the Auditor-General will be provided with sufficient resources and functional independence from ministerial or Executive interference to enable him to continue to discharge his crucial responsibilities to the Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to make a very clear distinction between functional independence-that is, not being subject to ministerial direction-and financial autonomy. I want to make this very clear again: every publicly funded agency or department or unit, including the Parliament, will have its appropriations set by the Executive Government, which of course means whatever group of people or parties has a majority in the House of Representatives. The proposition which Senator Stone seems to be endorsing, that some people who have no responsibility for the raising of revenue should have ad lib access to the Government bank account, in my view is untenable. It is certainly not accepted by me, whether it be the Auditor-General or anybody else. The functional independence of the Auditor-General is another matter. I make absolutely no apology for holding that view. It is a fundamental tenant of responsible government that whoever has the responsibility for raising public revenue has the control of its expenditure and I do not intend to resile from that position.

ANSWER.PARA: What appears to be the principal complaint of the Auditor-General-I must confess I have not had time to read the report but I have read a summary of it-is the proposition to install computer equipment which I think involved the expenditure of, from memory, about $8m over a period of years. The Department of Finance did a cost-benefit analysis of that, insofar as it is possible to do such cost-benefit analyses, and presented a report on it to the Expenditure Review Committee. The conclusion which the Department had come to was that in strict cost-benefit terms that expenditure was not viable and had any other department or agency been involved the Finance recommendation would have been that the expenditure not proceed because, on the best possible assessment, it would not give an adequate return on the capital investment. However, because it involved the Auditor-General the Department of Finance left that question open. The expenditure was authorised by the Expenditure Review Committee and ultimately by the Budget Cabinet, although it has slipped a little in time.

The Auditor-General has also been provided with additional staff-off the top of my head I think it is 15-in the last Budget in recognition of the case that has been put forward for a higher level of auditing activity. But I repeat-and I am surprised that Senator Stone does not share this view-that every agency of the Government, every agency which is funded by public funds, by revenue raised by taxes imposed by the Government, will have its appropriations set by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the lecture given the Senate by the Minister in his response, will he agree, first, that the Australian Audit Office is not an agency of the Government but is an agency of this Parliament and that the Auditor-General is responsible to this Parliament and not to the Minister or to the Executive branch of Government? Secondly, will he agree that his distinction between functional independence on the one hand and financial provision on the other is a meaningless one if in fact the reduction of financial provisions is such as to reduce the meaningfulness of functional independence?
—The term I used towards the end of my answer was any unit, organisation funded by public money raised by the Commonwealth Government--
—You corrected your initial slip of the tongue.

—I said `agency' and then I said any unit funded by public money-be it the Senate or anything else-will have its appropriations set by the Executive Government. Neither the Auditor-General nor anybody else, as long as I am Finance Minister anyway, will be given ad lib access to the Government's bank account; that is, ad lib access to public moneys raised from taxes. Nobody will be given that ad lib access and I am surprised that Senator Stone should be suggesting otherwise because I would be astounded, quite frankly, if it was his view when he was Secretary to the Treasury that people should be able to come along and write out cheques to whatever amounts they like on the public bank account.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the distorted report by Ross Dunn in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald about the pecuniary interest register in the article headed `Senators shy about interest register'. The report asserted that Government senators were refusing to go ahead with the public register of their financial interests. Is it not a fact that there is no such refusal by Government senators, that it is Government policy that there be such a register for senators as well as members of the House of Representatives (MHRs) and that the Leader of the Government moved the necessary motions in the last Parliament and intends to do so again? Also, is it not a fact that it is the Opposition in the Senate which is the stumbling block to a Senate register of pecuniary interests since it would not only oppose it but do so at such great length that there would not be sufficient debating time this year to deal with this amongst all the other matters which must be dealt with by the Senate? Does he not agree that both Houses should have similar rules on this matter and without any more delay than necessary?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Inaccuracies in questions are common often enough in this chamber but when inaccuracies are inaccuracies that are disclosed by the record of the Senate itself, I think you might have some role to play. Senator Coates is wrong on several counts. For example, no such motion was ever moved in the Senate; a motion was given notice of. No motion was moved so the honourable senator is clearly inaccurate in what he stated, his facts are wrong, and I suggest that the question be ruled out of order. The honourable senator should go away and at least get his facts straight before he presumes to ask a question.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I will certainly check the record but there is very little difference between giving notice of a motion and moving one. In any case, I think Senator Button spoke to the notice of motion. It was adjourned.
—I will allow the question. I ask the Minister to deal only with that part that falls within his responsibilities.

—I think the circumstances of the question require a benign answer. The answer to the first part of that question is: Yes, I am aware of the article by Ross Dunn in the Sydney Morning Herald. It is not a fact that there is opposition amongst Government senators to the pecuniary interests register, and that should be corrected right at the start.
—What about Caucus?

—No, Senator, it is a fact that there is not opposition among Government senators to a pecuniary interests register. Of course, there may be disagreement about the nature of particular proposals. If that is what Senator Chaney is drawing my attention to, that is an appropriate correction. It is Government policy that there be such a register for senators as well as MHRs. As Leader of the Government in the Senate, I gave notice of the necessary motions in the last Parliament and I intend to do so again. It is also a fact that the Opposition in the Senate appears to be opposed to a Senate register of pecuniary interests. That would create difficulties for the Senate in terms of the business list which the Senate has, if we were to spend a great deal of time debating that issue. So Government legislation on this matter is appropriately a question of priority in terms of the business of the Senate. I certainly agree that both Houses should have similar rules on the matter. Any assistance we can get from either House in making those rules as workable and as sensible as possible will, of course, be appreciated.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of a report from a major church group on recent events in New Caledonia which indicate that the French Government does not intend to move towards democratic self-government of that country, but is reinforcing its colonial power through the proposed so-called Pons statute, giving ultimate power to a French Government official, as well as intensive lobbying in international forums? Is the Minister further aware of persistent rumours that the Australian Government will succumb to this pressure from the French Government and intends to reverse its present policy of independence for New Caledonia? Does the Minister appreciate the damage such action would cause to Australia's standing in the region? Can he give an assurance that no such change of policy is contemplated and that the Australian Government will continue its efforts to achieve independence and democratic self-government for New Caledonia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the particular report from the church group to which Senator Macklin referred. Of course, we have our own sources of information on and assessment of political developments in the region and, on the basis of that information, we are perfectly capable of forming our own views on what is happening. It would appear that the proposed statute--
—Where did you get your information from?

—It is rather better information than that which impressed the Opposition's former spokesman, Mr Brown, in Fiji, I seem to recall. Senator Hill should not wax too lyrical about that. I refer in particular to the statute to which Senator Macklin referred. It is clear on our analysis that the proposed statute that has been referred to by Prime Minister Chirac and the DOM-TOM Minister Pons will not accord New Caledonia the same degree of autonomy as that enjoyed by French Polynesia, for example, and the powers accorded to the regions will not be as wide as those under the Fabius-Pisani statute of the previous French Government. The Pons statute, apparently, has just been approved by the French Cabinet. It is understood that it will complete its parliamentary process in France before the end of this year.

ANSWER.PARA: The passage of that statute will not alter the basic policy stance which we have had and continue to maintain in respect of New Caledonia, which I think can be described as follows. We would like to see a peaceful, orderly transition to multi-racial independence which recognises the rights of the indigenous people and safeguards the rights of all other long term residents. Australia wants to maintain a constructive dialogue with all parties involved in the New Caledonian issue, including the French Government. Australia's position takes into account the strong support for independence in New Caledonia expressed by the South Pacific Forum island countries, as shown in the communique of the Apia forum. Australia supported reinscription of New Caledonia at the United Nations General Assembly No. 41 as a means of ensuring that the territory's progress towards self-government and independence was regularly reviewed by the United Nations (UN). The UN Committee of 24 has since considered the question of New Caledonia, and adopted a resolution in August this year.

Australia supports a free and genuine act of self-determination in New Caledonia which is consistent with the universally accepted decolonisation practices and principles of the UN. We take the view that the referendum that was held by France on 13 September was inconsistent with that requirement. Finally, in general terms, our wish remains to help to ensure that a long term, viable, peaceful political solution can be found to the problems that continue to beset New Caledonia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Local Government inform us of the effects that the Commonwealth's new general purpose financial assistance arrangements for local government are having on rural local councils? Is it true that the new system discriminates against councils outside the capital cities because the grants are now determined on the basis of population and the needs of councils are not taken into account?

—It is not true that the new system discriminates against rural councils, but I thank Senator Childs for his question. Last year the Commonwealth introduced the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986. The purpose of the Act is to provide untied financial assistance to local councils to compensate them for disadvantages they suffer in raising revenue and meeting the needs of their residents. Councils that are most disadvantaged in respect of raising revenue and meeting needs will be helped the most under the new system. For instance, rural councils whose communities may be facing a decline in economic capacity, which in turn can have an effect on the ratable capacity of the land, should be advantaged under the Act. It is simply not fair to say that the new system is discriminating against rural councils in favour of capital cities. For instance, I know of a number of rural councils in Queensland that have been advantaged. Brisbane City Council, for example, is facing a loss of revenue. As I have said before in this place, grants are not determined just on a population basis. Many factors, including revenue, which I have just mentioned, and the costs associated with providing all the services expected of local councils, such as roads, health, welfare and libraries, are taken into account. In fact, this year some of the largest increases in grants have gone to rural councils. For instance, in New South Wales-Senator Childs's own State-Wagga Wagga received an increase of over $123,000, Albury received an extra $80,000 and a number of other councils, such as Culcairn and Wentworth, received increases.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to various newspaper reports suggesting that Telecom Australia has unmasked an international phone fraud ring involving Telecom operators and customers in four States and overseas. Is it a fact that this scam came to light only because of painstaking cross-matching of computer records by the Overseas Telecommunications Commission? Did Telecom have any independent monitoring program in place? Is it correct that detections to date may well be the tip of the iceberg and that there are likely to be several hundred more persons involved? What is the estimated cost to revenue of this racket? Will the Minister order a full inquiry into the state of Telecom's internal fraud detection techniques?

—I will take those detailed questions on notice. But in the context of the general issue of fraud detection and security, at the beginning of this week I referred to the general security inquiry which Telecom had set in train at the beginning of this year, which covered not only, as I understand it, physical security, but also the kinds of issues to which Senator Alston referred. The organisation is acutely conscious of the need to maintain maximum security of all its telecommunications operations. I am sure that the nature of the present exercise, which has been partially revealed in the Press so far, is only part of a quite intensive ongoing security operation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EMPLOYMENT OF JAPANESE STAFF BY DUTY FREE SHOP

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The Minister will recall that on 2 November I asked her about Japanese nationals working on the Gold Coast. Did the Minister indicate that a particular store was employing seven Japanese staff, of whom four were working holiday- makers? Has the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs reviewed the employment and entry conditions of the other three and, if so, what are the results of that review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my reply of 2 November to Senator Colston, I said that initial inquiries by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs indicated that four of the seven were working holidaymakers. Following a visit to the store by staff of the regional office of the Department in Brisbane, I can now confirm that this is the case. In addition, the review of the employment and entry conditions of the other three has in fact been completed and they are also in Australia as working holidaymakers.

ANSWER.PARA: The working holidaymakers scheme, which is reciprocal, allows for young people from other countries to undertake casual employment, usually no more than three to six months, with the one employer, to help them finance their holiday. All of the seven people in question had been employed at the store for less than three months. The departmental officers, at the time of their visit, took the opportunity to point out to the store management what their responsibilities were when employing expatriate staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce concerns offsets. The Minister will be aware of the warning by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of the major potential for abuse in the offsets program. Is it a fact that the offsets group in the Minister's Department has been disbanded and the staff scattered throughout the Department? Is this a result of recent allegations made to the Public Accounts Committee of impropriety? If not, what is the reason?

—First of all, that has not happened, so I can only be speculative about the other parts of Senator Lewis's question. What has happened is that some 20 people in one division in my Department have been moved to another division. There is nothing abnormal about that. That has taken place because, particularly in the information industries, there has been a creative process in policy making which now leads to an administrative role which is best carried on in another division of the Department. That has happened. So the speculation which is inherent in the honourable senator's question is something which, I suspect, we can leave in the air because it does not follow from the premise.

—I ask a supplementary question. What security systems, if any, has the Minister introduced to overcome the possibilities of abuse or corruption, as indicated in the Public Accounts Committee's report? What measures have been taken to ensure that future administration of the offsets program is effective, that outstanding offsets obligations are satisfied and that comprehensive records are maintained?

—That, of course, is not a supplementary question. It is a totally different question. In fact, it is a speech and not a question at all. But a number of steps have been taken in relation to all those matters. I think it is probably better that, rather than take up the whole of Question Time, I provide the honourable senator with a more comprehensive and detailed answer as soon as possible. I will do that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to statements in the House of Representatives on 18 November by the honourable member for Fadden, Mr Jull, about the availability of inbound seats to Australia. As the Minister would be aware, these statements have been reported in a number of newspapers. Can the Minister advise the House whether these statements accurately reflect the situation of airline seat availability into and out of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the Opposition spokesman on tourism, Mr Sharp, made a comprehensive fool of himself in the other place last week when his attack on the tourism Minister, Mr Brown, backfired, Mr Jull leapt into the act with a speech on airline capacity into Australia which was described by Mr Warwick Costin in a number of Sunday newspapers and, indeed, in newspapers elsewhere, in the following terms:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Jull got a hero's reception from his leaders and colleagues for turning the debate into one of underlying worth. He was backslapped, congratulated and later asked to write a briefing paper for all Opposition MPs.

Can I say that that gives a wonderful insight into the knowledge and sense of discrimination of members of the Opposition, because when one looks at the terms of that hero's speech by Mr Jull, one finds that it not only is inaccurate in a number of respects but also lacks analysis, draws conclusions which are misleading and distorted and is, in a number of respects, quite out of date.

Let me state the facts as they are. Of the 11 airlines mentioned by Mr Jull as not having spare seats into Australia, he has neglected to say that permanent capacity increases have been negotiated with a number of them at airline level-that is, Malaysian Airline System (MAS), Thai Airways International Ltd and Singapore Airlines Ltd. Singapore Airlines in particular will be entitled to operate two extra services from December. With the exception of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, none of the remainder of the 11 airlines has sought any increased capacity. I repeat: none of them has sought any increased capacity. Moreover, two of these carriers-Air India and Alitalia-have in recent years reduced the level of their scheduled services into Australia and could, if they wished, without any further steps being taken by anyone, increase their services again. I acknowledge that KLM has since applied for additional permanent capacity and this is being negotiated with the Dutch Government. However, it is only KLM of the 11 of which that is true.

Mr Jull neglected to mention that, of the 11 carriers he did mention, only three of them-MAS, Olympic Airways and Singapore Airlines-have filed to operate supplementaries over the current period and all those filings have been approved by my Department, as I indicated several days ago would be the case. There are 14 overseas airlines which between them are now operating some 75 supplementary flights between now and February. But the vast majority of overseas operators into Australia are not seeking supplementary flights at all. Take, for example, United Airlines Inc., a major provider of services whose public affairs manager in Australia, Mr Sean McNamara, was quoted recently as saying that it does not have enough aircraft to operate supplementary flights. He was then quoted as saying that this was not just an Australian problem, but a world problem with passenger numbers having gone through the roof.

Then we had from Mr Jull an exposition on the subject of wait list numbers. Certainly, for Singapore Airlines, it looks large. The Press has claimed, and this figure has been often repeated, something like 4,500 wait listed for that area alone. What Mr Jull and others, however, have not taken into account is that while some wait lists look large, they are really quite dramatically exacerbated by multiple bookings as people seek to secure their preferred flight. Those figures need to be adjusted accordingly.

Let me now just describe to the Senate the real situation on seat availability as it presently exists, both into and out of Australia. This is the information on the situation as it now stands, through to the end of February.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, you can incorporate it.

—I know it hurts Senator Lewis. I understand the indignity and stress that he is caused to hear one of the Opposition spokesmen so revealed for naked pig ignorance. But this is the truth of the matter. I am sure that honourable senators, with the forthcoming season in mind, will be very interested to know, on behalf of not only themselves but also their constituents, what the wait list situation is. On the United Kingdom (UK)-Europe-Singapore-Bangkok route there are presently 15,164 inbound seats available between now and February and 26,583 outbound seats available; for the United States of America-Canada route there are 10,803 inbound and 14,123 outbound; in Asia otherwise, there are 6,559 inbound and 11,736 outbound. Those figures do not include a further 48 supplementary flights which Qantas Airways Ltd has yet to release for sale. This represents approximately an additional 18,000 seats into and out of Australia and, on inbound sectors, will add an extra 27 from Asia, 20 from Europe, United Kingdom and Singapore and one from the UK in terms of flights.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, Mr Jull made some further ill- informed comments about the Government's so-called restrictive approach to charters. What he does not seem to have appreciated-this hero of the Opposition-is that on 7 October I announced relaxed guidelines for international charter flights that are designed, of course, to promote the development of inbound tourism by allowing passenger charter flights to play a very real and very complementary role to scheduled flights. To the extent that Mr Jull utterly failed to acknowledge that statement, this is another perfect demonstration of the total ignorance with which he foisted his views upon the Parliament. He makes no reference whatsoever to those new guidelines, showing that he is simply quite unable to keep up to date with the developments as they have occurred.

All I can say, in conclusion, is that it is manifest that Mr Jull satisfies that description that Senator Stone so kindly put on the record for us, as reported on page 2255 of Monday's Hansard-and I recommend it to the reading of all honourable senators-when he referred to the number of duds purporting to be spokesmen for the Opposition. It is a classic demonstration of just how many duds there are and in how many areas they purport to state the truth but fundamentally and comprehensively get it wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I preface my question by referring to claims by Philippine military intelligence sources that six Australian organisations have supplied funds to the Communist Party of the Philippines and its military wing-the New People's Army (NPA). Is the Government concerned that any such action by the organisations named in several newspaper reports could contribute to undermining the Aquino Government and have serious ramifications for Australia's relations with the Philippines? Does the Minister agree that the only effective way of checking the truth or otherwise of the allegations is an inquiry by an Australian security organisation? Will the Government institute such an inquiry to establish beyond doubt, firstly, whether any funds from Australia have found their way-perhaps as a result of laundering through front organisations-to those Philippine communist organisations and, secondly, whether any public money is involved?

—It is the case that Philippine military intelligence sources have been quoted in the Press as claiming that a number of Australian non-governmental organisations (NGOs) have provided funds to the Communist Party of the Philippines and its military wing-the New People's Army. No evidence is available to the Government which would uphold those claims. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) has mechanisms in place to assess carefully all NGO projects which are funded by the Government. Philippines Defence Secretary Ileto is reported to have said that the Philippines Government had asked some foreign governments for assistance in investigating such allegations. I place on record the fact that no such request has been made of the Australian Government. I should say, finally, that the violent activity which is pursued by the Communist Party of the Philippines, through the NPA, against the democratically elected Government of the Philippines is opposed by the Australian Government and is regarded by us as totally contrary to Australian values.

—I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Minister's response, I ask: In what way did AIDAB check out the claims that have been made, and does the Minister regard whatever inquiry AIDAB has undertaken as a satisfactory substitute for an inquiry by an Australian intelligence organisation?

—I regard AIDAB as having more credibility than, firstly, the Press and, secondly, the present questioner; but I will seek further details on what mechanisms may have been implemented to check out the grants in question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. I ask the Minister whether her attention has been drawn to Press reports that stated that it would be unjust and oppressive for 16 New South Wales Aborigines to be sent to Queensland gaols to stand trial in view of the racial discrimination and inhuman gaol conditions in that State. In light of this report and further reports that referred to gaol conditions, especially at Boggo Road Gaol and, in particular, the proposed opening of the black hole section to house Aborigines, I further ask the Minister: Has any approach been made to the Attorney-General's Department or the Federal Government to assist in resisting the opening of the section of Boggo Road Gaol known as the black hole because it is claimed that this section does not meet the international standards of human rights to which the Australian Government is a consenting party? In what area does this section of the gaol infringe those international standards set on human rights? It seems quite obvious from the interjections by honourable senators opposite that they do not believe a great deal in human rights.

—I thank Senator Jones for his question. While I am acting for Senator Tate, I would not want to answer the detail of Senator Jones's questions, except to say that obviously there is a great deal of concern in the general community and in this chamber, other than those who chose to snigger, as to the very serious question that Senator Jones has raised in this place today. It is of significant concern to all Australians that the Queensland Government, such as it is on this historic day in Queensland, should even consider re-opening the black hole at Boggo Road. I can only hope that, as there has been a change in leadership in Queensland today-I assume that the new leadership will be somewhat more open-minded than the one that has existed for over 19 years-that very serious question will be one of the first priorities of the new leadership. I will refer the detail of Senator Jones's question to Senator Tate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SENATE ELECTION: HIGH COURT OF AUSTRALIA PETITION

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Home Affairs to an article in the Australian newspaper of 20 November entitled `Verdict may force Senate election'. Can the Minister confirm that on 19 November the High Court of Australia announced that a petition from a New South Wales Senate candidate, Mrs Nile, challenging the election of Senator Robert Wood as a senator for New South Wales in July 1987 has constitutional implications and has, therefore, decided to relist the hearing for 9 December? What advice has the Minister received from the Australian Electoral Commission regarding Mrs Nile's challenge, and on what grounds did the Commission originally argue against Mrs Nile's petition? Can he confirm the statement in the Press report that the Electoral Commission will try to persuade the High Court to declare the whole Senate election for New South Wales void if the Court upholds the petition? What would be the implications of the High Court's upholding of Mrs Nile's petition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm that the matter is before the High Court and has been adjourned until 9 December. In adjourning it, the Bench made it quite clear that there were constitutional implications. Also, it thought it appropriate that State governments or State Attorneys-General be consulted in this regard. Senator Short asked me what advice I have had from the Electoral Commission. The answer is not a lot, and I am not about to reveal advice from part of my Department to myself. Of course, that does not preclude me from going to some of the other issues which the honourable senator raised.

ANSWER.PARA: He asked: On what grounds did the Commission originally argue against Mrs Nile's petition? Essentially, the Commission is represented there because it has a peripheral involvement in these matters, which are basically constitutional. I think that they go to section 44 of the Constitution. Senator Wood should answer this question in terms of the details. There is also a section in the Commonwealth Electoral Act that says that no person shall nominate for election unless he is capable of taking his seat in the Parliament. That was an amendment we made to the Electoral Act in 1983 or 1984. The Commission has some interest in these matters in that regard.

Senator Short asked me to confirm a Press report that the Electoral Commission will try to persuade the High Court to declare the whole New South Wales election void. I would point out that it was a newspaper report which was well-informed in some areas and fairly basic and weak in others. I have no knowledge of the Electoral Commission arguing publicly or privately that the election should be regarded as void if Mrs Nile's petition is upheld. I would not like to test the extent to which I can direct the Electoral Commission, which we created basically as an independent body. It is not my view that it should be arguing that. I would be very surprised if that section of the Press report had any validity at all.

Senator Short went on to ask: What would be the implications of the High Court's upholding of Mrs Nile's petition? The High Court-or the Court of Disputed Returns-could eventually do a variety of things. Firstly, it could dismiss the complaint. We have at least one vote for that already. Secondly, it could declare Senator Wood not eligible and nominate another of the candidates to replace him. Whether that would be done by way of a count-through or just by its choice, I am not certain. Thirdly, it could declare the election absolutely void. The consequences of that are a bit like a curate's egg-both good and bad. The worst aspect, Mr President, is that you would have to vacate the chair for three months. Whilst that would be a loss to the Senate, I could not stand another election campaign when you were running for President.

My colleague who is on sick leave at the moment, Senator Richardson, would also be a little agitated, although I understand that a person can be a Minister for, I think, three months without being a member of parliament. My other New South Wales colleagues on this side of the chamber, none of whom are present at the moment, would be somewhat distressed because, as I recall, one of the provisions is that if their positions were declared void they would have to pay back all their salaries and allowances to the point of 11 July. I am not sure whether Senator Walsh would consider an act of grace payment in these particular circumstances.

As for honourable senators opposite, we would have the normal sorts of problems. Where would poor old Senator Brownhill end up on the ticket? Would he be put at No. 3, 4 or 5? Having two Baumes run for pre-selection also causes problems opposite. At least I would not have to worry about Senator Bishop's new office in Parramatta if she gets tossed out. As for Senator Puplick, well, he has had a nice stay on the front bench. I am sure he will be back if he is removed.

This matter does raise a serious point, one which may have to be looked at in terms of Senate elections. By the way, I am not suggesting that there is any fault at all involved here or that there is any validity to the case. But to have 11 duly elected senators forfeit their positions, through no fault of their own, because of a problem with the twelfth seems to me incongruous. But we recently saw something similar occur in the Northern Territory. Mr Tuxworth, through no fault of his own, had to vacate his seat and re-contest the by-election. I am not trying to nobble or in any way influence the Court's decision. I just say generally that the disqualification, the expense of an election and the disruption that would be caused seem to me a rather pointless exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Special Minister of State advise the Senate of the Government's commitment to research into effective treatment and rehabilitation programs for drug and alcohol abuse? Does the Minister support the establishment of centres throughout Australia to conduct research in the areas of drug and alcohol abuse?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the second part of Senator Aulich's question is yes. In fact tomorrow, at the University of New South Wales, I will be opening Australia's second centre for research into effective treatment and rehabilitation programs for drug and alcohol abuse. The centre will receive $1.2m for the current financial year under the national campaign against drug abuse. The centre will conduct research into effective treatment and rehabilitation programs as well as basic research on social and psychological factors relating to drug dependence.

ANSWER.PARA: A particular facet of the research will be to explain why approximately two-thirds of people treated for drug and alcohol problems relapse shortly after discharge from treatment. The centre will concentrate on the development and evaluation of treatment methods for the early recognition of drug and alcohol problems and ways of moderating consumption or promoting abstinence. The research will concentrate on alcohol, tobacco and opiate drugs, which represent major areas of concern in our society.

The Government wants to get the message across that the whole community needs to understand that we are all open to the problem of drugs and we all need to be aware of how to cope with them. The Government has allocated $2.6m to the national campaign against drug abuse for research into this area between 1985 and 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the answer he gave me regarding the import duty on diesel injection pump parts and turbo charger parts. I quote his reply:

QUESTION.PARA: Importers of replacement parts used for diesel injection pumps and turbo chargers not manufactured in Australia will continue to have the opportunity to import their goods at 2% duty irrespective of the proposed tariff changes referred to by the honourable senator.

My questions are: What exactly does he mean by `have the opportunity to import their goods at 2 per cent'? Secondly, is it automatic that those specialised parts not manufactured in Australia will remain at 2 per cent? Or does it mean that the importer will have to reapply to obtain that concession, thereby causing those importers to pay the higher 25 per cent rate of duty until the decision is made and then apply for a refund?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable senator to put the question on notice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer to a statement made earlier this week by the Hon. Dr Cornwall in the debate in the South Australian Parliament on the Reproductive Technology Bill in which he advised the South Australian Parliament that Senator Ryan had spoken to him on two occasions about the need for uniform legislation in this area of major public importance. My question to the Minister is: On what dates did the Minister speak to Dr Cornwall about this particular matter? I ask also whether the need she saw for uniform legislation coincided with the recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985, which is contained on page xv of the Committee's report, and which includes:

QUESTION.PARA: making unlawful any destructive non-therapeutic experimentation which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
If it was not that advice, what advice did the Minister give Dr Cornwall?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Harradine will be aware-because I have answered questions from him on this subject before-the Government is considering a response to the Senate Committee's report, and the Government is considering a broader approach to the whole bioethics question. What we have undertaken at this stage is to establish a national bioethics committee which will operate as an expert and representative body to which references could be sent by the Commonwealth or by State governments. I have told Senator Harradine before-and I repeat this-that the Government is not anticipating Federal legislation in these areas at this stage; that is, we currently have no such plans.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also the case that, as a part of considering the way in which the Commonwealth can play a constructive role in this extremely complex and sensitive area, we have looked at what the States are doing. It is very much my view that it would serve the interests of the Australian people if we can avoid a situation where States have legislation in these areas that differs quite markedly from that of other States. For example, in the area of in vitro fertilisation, it does not seem to me to be in the interests of Australians if States differ in their legislative criteria for eligibility for going into such a program. If there were such different criteria from State to State, we would have what I would consider to be the unfortunate position of women or couples moving around, State hopping, trying to find legislation which suited them.

It is a new area for governments to be involved in legislatively. It is an enormously complex area. It touches on very deeply held views of different sections of the community, and it brings to the fore the pluralism of our society, because there is no doubt that there is a very wide range of moral and ethical views held sincerely by different sections of society on what is the right way to proceed in these matters. I repeat that I believe it is in the interests of Australia that the States, in the event of their wishing to legislate, do so in consultation with each other and with the Federal Government in an effort to establish common ground and a common approach to legislation. It is, of course, up to the States to legislate as they wish. Victoria has already legislated and South Australia is in the process of enacting legislation. However, I think it is in the interests of everybody for the States and the Commonwealth to find common ground for this legislation.

I have not had the opportunity to visit Dr Cornwall to have formal discussions at any length on this matter. I have seen Dr Cornwall from time to time and no doubt those matters have been discussed informally. The most recent occasion of my meeting with Dr Cornwall was at the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy which, as I recall, was held on 5 or 6 November. But I can find that date more accurately for Senator Harradine.

I would like to say that Senator Harradine has expressed a great interest in this matter. Indeed, he has a record in this place of having a very active interest in such matters. But I would point out that his views on the matter are not the only views that are held within society. There are, as I said, a range of views held within the scientific community, amongst people who concern themselves with ethical matters and amongst legislators. I would ask him to consider that the Government, in arriving at its position on such a complex matter, must endeavour to arrive at a position which does justice to the variety of views which are held in the community, and does not simply adopt one view at the expense of other views which are held with equal passion and conviction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I was talking not about my views but about the advice given by the Minister. If the Minister has spoken to Dr Cornwall about this matter, how was she able yesterday to say, in answer to a question that I raised on the appropriations, that she had not had discussions with the South Australian Government about this particular question? Is she aware of the fact that the South Australian Parliament last night went some way towards adopting the Senate Committee's recommendations by amending the legislation to ensure that there were no detrimental experiments on embryos?

—When Senator Harradine asked me yesterday about discussions, I answered by saying that I had not had a special meeting with Dr Cornwall on that matter. There have been officer level discussions and certainly the view that Dr Cornwall has put forward, as quoted by Senator Harradine-that I believe that uniformity of approach is desirable-is my view, and no doubt it is a view that has been conveyed to Dr Cornwall's office by my officers. I have not had the opportunity to have full formal discussions on this matter with Dr Cornwall, although it is probably the case that we have discussed it on other occasions when we have met with other agendas. However, if the South Australian legislation has looked closely at the Senate Committee's recommendations and adopted some of them, that is quite a useful course of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs-I promised a further answer to Senator Newman. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley)

TALK.START.PARA: has now provided additional information. I seek leave to incorporate his answer in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

During Question Time on Tuesday of this week, Senator Newman asked several questions relating to the causes of officer resignations in the Australian Defence Force. She also tabled a report which contained the results of an Army survey of its officer resignations.
In particular she asked:
Whether the Government had been in possession of this report?
Whether Ministers had misled parliament over the last two months by failing to acknowledge the underlying reasons for the rate of service resignations.
The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answers to the Honourable Senator's questions:
The report referred to covered the period mid-February to August 1987. It is an initial report issued internally within Army and is still subject to further analysis.
Ministers have not misled Parliament. On the contrary, this Government has shown a determination to tackle problem areas that have arisen for a variety of reasons and is doing something about them.
Senator Newman also asked supplementary questions as follows:
Had the Government obtained similar reports into the reasons for resignations of officers from the Royal Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force?
If so, will the Government table those reports and make them available to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its enquiry into separation rates?
The Minister has provided the following answers to these questions:
Yes. Such surveys are normal management practices within the Services.

The Government has no intention to table reports which are essentially working documents for the internal use of the Department and the Services. However, a consolidated and fully analysed paper is being prepared for submission to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has provided additional information in answer to Senator Hamer's question without notice of 23 November. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The Dibb Review of Australia's defence capabilities recommended in 1986 that, while individual services should retain an advisory role, the ADF's military planning and policy, including forward equipment planning, should be centralised under the Chief of the Defence Force (CDF) working in close association with civilian staff under the Secretary. As a result the Government last year created the position of Vice Chief of the Defence Force with specific responsibilities to CDF for long term planning and for the co-ordination of ADF force development planning. Single Service Chiefs of development were made directly responsible to CDF (through VCDF) for aspects of ADF force development.

The Minister for Defence announced the creation of the position of VCDF on 3 June last year when tabling the Dibb Review in Parliament. This measure was part of a continuing process designed to increase the oversight of single services by the headquarters of the ADF and to encourage a comprehensive approach towards the structuring of the ADF for our strategic circumstances.

The Secretary to the Department of Defence and the Chief of the Defence Force have together informed the Minister for Defence that they regard as fundamentally sound the joint process whereby the Government is presented with professional civilian and military advice on the development of the ADF. This joint advisory process has been supported by successive Governments since at least the Second World War. Over time improvements can be sought but these need only be at the margins rather than by radical change.

In this regard, the Force Development and Analysis Division will remain under the Secretary of the Department of Defence and will continue to play a major part in the examination of proposals for new major capital equipment.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)
