GROUP E
Department of Defence
Proposed expenditure, $7,150,478,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before lunch I was saying how refreshing it was to be able to question senior serving uniformed officers and to receive their frank, clear and honest answers. The Estimates Committee inquiring into the Department of Defence has not always had the pleasure of that sort of direct approach and I hope that it is one that the Department will see its way clear to continue in the future. I was about to draw attention to the number of questions to which answers had still to come forward, but I understand that, due to no fault of the Department or my office, there was a hiccup on the delivery of answers to members of the Estimates Committee. They have now arrived, but I have had the benefit of looking at some of these answers only during Question Time. I thank the Department for its efficient handling of the Estimates Committee. A number of questions were put on notice earlier on by the members of the Committee, and these were answered prior to the hearing. A number of other questions were taken on notice during the hearing, and we have now received most, though by no means all, answers and I give credit for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in this debate, my colleagues referred to the report from the 1 Psych Unit to the Military Secretary, which I tabled in the Senate on Tuesday. It seems to me that the sad thing about that report is the number of times on which leadership was referred to as being something which was lacking in the Services and the provision of which would have been an important factor in keeping officers in the Army. It is leadership at both political and military levels that is required. Of the most serious 12 factors, four relate to senior officers. There was a need for a more positive commitment to be shown by senior officers towards service conditions, better leadership by superiors was needed, greater loyalty was required from senior officers, and a more positive commitment needed to be shown by senior officers towards defence issues.

Equally, politicians and governments have to take the blame. The report said that if a more positive commitment had been shown by politicians to defence forces and national defence conditions of service, if there had been a better understanding by politicians of the problems of Army personnel, these things would have helped persuade officers to stay in the Army. We desperately need leadership from the top for our service men and women. A lot of factors affect the high separation rates that we are currently suffering. Many of them can be dealt with in dollars and cents, but by no means all. It is very sad, and a terribly serious matter, that at both political and service levels, these men and women feel that they are lacking leadership.

Serious also is the fact that they feel that they need more open career management, greater responsibility and more autonomy in their work tasks and greater acceleration of promotion for persons of demonstrated performance and that they would like to see more weight being given to merit than to seniority in promotion. There are a lot of other factors that contribute to the dissatisfaction of the families, which we have debated before a number of times in Parliament, especially in relation to the education of the children of service personnel.

I think we must take serious note of these matters that are raised in the report. No doubt, it was a confidential report within the Department of Defence but I, for one, feel that it is in the interests of Australia's defence that these matters be made public. It is interesting to note that among the answers to questions on notice which I received only during Question Time today, one answer related to separation studies. I draw the Senate's attention to the answer which stated:
The more common themes emerging from these studies are:

(a) Locational, Societal Aspects. Families are less mobile because of the increasing importance across society of maintaining the existing employment of spouses for economic and self-actualisation reasons, and to maintain educational stability for children, particularly in secondary school.
(b) Service Conditions. Personnel do have perceptions as to the relative standing of the ADF in the community, particularly in regard to conditions of service.
(c) Other. A range of issues relating to feelings and attitudes about individual career prospects through to the nature of the working environment in the ADF.

I think that is a very poor response. I am very disappointed that the Department feels that it can describe studies into the reasons for separation in those gobbledegook terms when we have, fortunately, the benefit now of reading the actual study from the 1 Psyche Unit to the Military Secretary which really sets out what the worries are. Who would know the seriousness of the leadership problems from reading that gobbledegook? Who would know the seriousness of the career management problems and who would know the seriousness of the family problems from reading that rubbish?

I would like to turn now to another question that relates to the separation figures, or to the lack of them. We are all aware that the figures that used to be produced for members of Parliament ceased to be produced at the end of June. Since that time we have been advised publicly that anyone who wishes to apply for the separation figures on the defence forces should make application. When that announcement was made early this financial year my office rang the Department requesting that figures be provided to me on a monthly basis. The Department said to ring the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). My office did so and was told that it would be taken care of. On 7 November, still having had no figures, I wrote to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel requesting figures for July, August, September and October. On 18 November my office was phoned by a member of the Minister's staff who, in a very abrupt and unpleasant manner, said that requests should be made to the Department every month. My officer said that she had called the Department in the first place and that she had been told to talk to the Minister's office. This member of the Minister's staff said that at that time the procedures were not in place but that they now were and that this matter was being handled by the Department. He was clearly not interested.

I draw the Committee's attention to the fact that in the report to the Senate of Estimates Committee E the Committee expressed quite a bit of concern about this matter. I turn to page 11 of that report where it is stated:

The Committee was aware of the decision by the Minister for Defence to discontinue the Departmental practice of publishing monthly statistics. Having considered this matter the Committee requested that any member of parliament, who makes a written request for monthly separation rates and other defence statistics of the kind previously made available, should be supplied with those materials on a regular and continuous basis without having to make repeated monthly requests.

Monthly requests are a lot of nonsense. It is a bureaucratic attempt to prevent members of parliament from receiving this information. It is a stupid nonsense. It is made worse by the fact that when we get these figures, I understand, they will be nothing like the quality of the figures previously available to members of Parliament. I understand it will just be a brief sheet of figures, whereas we used to get a very excellent break-up of the figures so we could truly have an understanding of what was happening in the defence forces. I draw the Committee's attention to that criticism in the Committee's report and I urge the Department to take action accordingly.

I would also like to refer to other matters contained in that Estimates Committee report. The Committee addressed itself to a number of matters relating to the Department of Defence. One of them concerned the availability of the departmental annual reports. It seems to be a very cynical exercise. Perhaps I have a suspicious nature, but my colleagues obviously felt the same way, because the report condemned the fact that the Department of Defence report was available one week after the Estimates Committee hearings finished. I draw the Committee's attention to the fact that when the Attorney-General's Department was to appear before the self-same Estimates Committee it had the courtesy to provide the Committee with a draft copy of its report. I fail to see why the Department of Defence is not able to do equally well. I urge it to improve its game in that area in the future.

I wish also to raise the question concerning the amount of expenditure on personnel in the defence budget. I think it was Mr Ives who gave some information about the break-down of the defence expenditure. He said that 29.6 per cent of the budget went into capital procurement, 42.2 per cent went on personnel and 28.3 per cent on operating costs. I would like to draw the Committee's attention to the fact that I have received a letter from a former senior officer commenting on this break-down. I think it would be worth the while of honourable senators to ponder on these facts. He said:
The British Forces had by 1978 reached about that same ratio and many of their servicemen were on welfare payments.

I remind the Senate that with the new family assistance supplement we are going to have numbers of junior ranks with children in receipt of welfare payments from this Government. So the situations are very similar. He goes on to point out:

Almost every viable and comparable organisation from BHP to private schools appears to budget for personnel costs of about 50-60 per cent. One cannot deny the need for new and better equipment for the ADF, but the introduction of this equipment carries a personnel and logistic cost if it is to be introduced in an orderly fashion. What has been happening is that the new equipment is being introduced at the expense of everything else, and in the face of a diminishing overall budget. Something has to give, and the major symptom of this is in the form of personnel departures.

I urge the Government to take serious stock of the break-down of the defence budget to see whether it has perhaps not launched off too far into capital procurement costs at the expense of personnel costs. In my view it is dangerous to go too far down that track and get the defence budget out of balance.

Lastly I would like to draw attention to the article in the Australian newspaper to which my colleague Senator MacGibbon referred earlier concerning the guidelines introduced for service spouses when they meet the Minister. I think it is a desperately sad situation when we find that service spouses who are not under military law, they are not under the command of commanding officers of units, are being instructed as to how to behave when they meet their Ministers. I feel it is a terrible shame. It is incredible that the Australian Labor Party would countenance such a thing. I cannot imagine, for example, trade union spouses in a similar situation, putting up with that for one minute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Being asked to discuss it over a cup of tea.

—Yes, as Senator Walters said, being asked to discuss it over a cup of tea. It is incredible to imagine. One wonders whether they are going off in their white gloves to courtsey, as Peter Young suggested. How can the service personnel get their message across to the Ministers and to the nation if their spouses are muzzled? It is the only opportunity they have to express a point of view. They do not have the freedom of trade unionists to organise their labour to speak out publicly. They are able to be represented only by their spouses. This amounts to intimidation either by Ministers or by the chiefs. I would like to get to the bottom of that matter. I signal just how serious it is. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel said in the House of Representatives yesterday that she had made no complaint to General Gration, nor would she make any. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: Any guidelines that the Chief of the Defence Force would issue would be at his own prerogative and of his own doing, and I would have nothing whatsoever to do with them.

I hope that is correct, but somebody has issued those guidelines and decided that that is how Ministers must be treated by service spouses. It is quite appalling. (Extension of time granted) I would like to ask just who took the decision that guidelines of this kind would be issued to service spouses. I would like to know whether the chiefs took that decision on their own initiative or whether complaints were made by Deputy Secretary A when he returned from the meeting at Holsworthy, which I also attended. I draw the Committee's attention to the fact that Deputy Secretary A represented the Minister at that meeting; he was her official representative. He also had the hide to tell those angry and worried people that the Government has the right to give them their pay and conditions and has the right to take them away. The people at the meeting, naturally, howled at him and were furious. Somebody asked him to repeat that statement. Either with total insensitivity or lack of any sort of political nous, or arrogance-I cannot think why-he cheerfully repeated it. If that person was a representative of the Minister, Ministers and their representatives deserve whatever they get when they go out to visit service spouses. I would like to know the answers to those questions before I ask further questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —After such a peremptory demand, I jump to my feet.
—It is the least you could do.

—I think so. Senator Newman made a few points along the track. She made a few comments on the survey. That matter was raised earlier in debate. The survey, as she says, is interesting. Surveys that go just to the problems of the disaffected and not the whole service can have slightly distorting effects, especially when the questions are listed, not for an actual response, but for a tick or a cross or something else. Nevertheless, that document will be analysed at great length.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman commented on the difficulties she has had in getting the separation rate figures. If the story she has outlined today is accurate in all respects, I have some sympathy with the points she is making. I will have her comments drawn to the attention of the Minister. Figures are either published or they are not. One does not set up a merry-go-round just to make it hard for people to get such figures. That is not productive for anyone. If we expect a 4 per cent second tier pay rise, Senator Newman's case today is one thing that could argue against it. Concerning Senator Newman's question about the Department of Defence annual report not being available, I am advised-and I have not checked it-that it is the standing practice of the Department to negotiate a publication timetable with the printer. The practice was followed in respect of the 1986-87 Defence Report.

The timetable was determined with a view to the report being tabled by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) concurrently with his delivering the Defence budget statement on 8 October. The Department adhered to the timetable and provided clearance for final galley proofs to the publisher in accordance with the timetable agreed. However, printed copies were not available until 28 October, the day before the report was tabled. Again I say that I do not think it would be deliberate policy to delay the publication of these reports so that the Estimates committees would be over and done with. That would also presuppose some genius calculating when the Estimates committees were going to consider and complete their tasks. It would be beyond me. I do not know whether it would be beyond Senator Newman to know exactly when they would be finished but I think it would be beyond the Defence Department. So I doubt that that was a deliberate policy, although if there were four, five or 10 coincidences in a row there might be some doubts. But that is the explanation at this stage.

The final issue Senator Newman raised about guidelines for the behaviour of spouses when meeting the Minister has been blown up a little. I might be able to assist her with some points that have been placed at my disposal. The guidelines were directed at commanding officers and provided advice-I stress `advice'-on fostering meetings of service spouses with the Minister, when the meetings are held on Defence property. It is the normal meeting practice to have an identifiable convenor. The guidelines are to facilitate ministerial contact with spouses. Ministers can answer, without notice, policy questions, but need warning as to specific questions in depth. When a meeting is intended to be for spouses it is reasonable, I think, that spouses have the Minister to themselves. The wearing of civilian clothes is intended to foster the atmosphere when the Minister is talking to spouses without the inhibition of service personnel of various ranks being present.

If, on the other hand, local groups would like the Minister to meet mixed groups of service personnel and spouses, the invitation should advise the Minister accordingly. The guidelines also reiterate that meetings arranged by service spouses should not be gate-crashed. That is the extent so far of my advice on some of the issues Senator Newman has raised.

Whilst Mr Peter Young's argument in his newspaper article could not be described as not factual, it certainly bent around a few issues and somewhat sensationalised the approach. I do not think that there is anything particularly wrong with structured meetings if one wants a productive result. I do not think that those guidelines, in any way, are meant to inhibit debate or be patronising towards the spouses of service personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to place it on the record that the meeting at Holsworthy, where there were 500 soldiers, sailors and airmen and their spouses, was entirely organised by the local branch of the national consultative group of service spouses. It was an extremely orderly, but cross, meeting. The women ran it entirely and although many cross people were there they were continually reminded by the chairperson that the people invited were the guests of the organisation and were to be treated accordingly. The meeting responded. So I do not understand why there is any need for these guidelines. I have asked the Minister what caused them to be prepared and distributed. I would also like to know what is the end purpose of them.
—Senator Newman asked whether the Government would be prepared to distribute copies of those guidelines or make them available.
—I have got them.
—What is the point of the honourable senator's question?

—I did not ask that at all. I asked: What was the end purpose of distributing them and, after the behaviour at Holsworthy which was exemplary except verbally, to the representative of the Minister-who really incited the abuse-who decided that these guidelines would be distributed, on whose complaint was it done, and for what purpose?

—At this stage I cannot assist the honourable senator with an answer to that question. It is not within my knowledge or of that of the immediate officers who are here to assist me. I will seek advice on that matter and try to get an answer for the honourable senator before these proceedings are over, as to who decided to issue the guidelines and under what circumstances they were issued.

—I thank the Minister for his answer. I am concerned that this is an attempt to muzzle the service spouses. I dare say that there is not much point in asking the Minister whether that was the case, as I am sure he will deny it, but that is how it will look to defence families. I would like to know whether the chiefs will withdraw the guidelines, whether the Government will withdraw the guidelines or whether they endorse them.

—We are getting beyond the purposes of the Committee. The honourable senator is asking me to comment on future Government policy. She knows that I am not in a position to do so. I am the Minister representing the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). I cannot give Senator Newman a guarantee today that those guidelines will be withdrawn or tell her which future policy is associated with them. Indeed, I have already said in a previous answer that I am not sure who issued those guidelines, let alone being able to make an assumption on who could withdraw them. It is just not possible to answer those sorts of questions in an Estimates debate.

—I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that paragraph (1) of the guidelines states, `where service spouses are invited to talk to the Minister for Defence or the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel'. These are the guidelines agreed to by the Chief of the Defence Force for meetings which are held within service establishments. Am I to understand from that that Minister Beazley is also requesting to be so protected? If that is the case, there seems to be an internal contradiction within the document. Although he is specifically referred to in paragraph (1), in paragraph (3) the references to the Minister are continually in the feminine.

—I do not have an answer to that contradiction concerning the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). One explanation is that when he is on leave Mrs Kelly acts as the Minister for Defence as well as being the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, but I doubt whether it is contrived for that reason. I will seek advice to see whether the guidelines are intended to cover Mr Beazley also.
—I ask the Minister why spouses who are also service personnel are not to wear uniform at these occasions.

—I said in the second last point I made in answer to an earlier question that it was in the hope of fostering the atmosphere of a particular meeting that everyone was asked to be in civilian attire. I can add nothing further to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a question which is directly related to the Estimates concerning the subject of capital procurement for the Defence Force. This is not a criticism of Senator Newman's questions, which were also directly related to the Estimates. My question concerns the structure under which the Defence Force's capital procurement is organised. Unlike the United States Congress, we do not go through the proposed capital procurements item by item, discussing them and then rejecting or approving them. Nevertheless, I think we are entitled to know, in view of the very large amounts spent on capital procurement, whether the structure and the arrangements are sensible. A week or so ago I asked a question about this of Senator Ray. I have now received from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) a complete non-answer-what might be generously described as bureaucratic gobbledegook.
—There is a lot of that.

—Did the honourable senator say, `Join the club'? There is quite a lot of that going on. The problem in the past has been that the three separate Services have each had their own structure for their forward equipment. In fact, one could make a good case for saying that they appeared to be fighting different wars. One of the advantages of the Department of Defence is that for the first time we might have a coherent approach to the role, function and equipment of the Defence Force as a whole rather than an uneasy amalgam of three separate Service bids. I think the position of Vice-Chief of the Defence Force was established with a view to facilitating that.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask a question which seems to me to be fundamental: Has the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force taken over the task of proposing the equipment and the structure of the whole Defence Force-not an amalgam of the three separate forces? In the past the three Services were putting up bids on their own. They were competing with each other and the Public Service by manipulating and playing off against each other, managing to keep control in their own hands, very much, in my view, to the disadvantage of the efficiency of our Defence Force, certainly because of the antagonism it produced between the uniformed professional members of the defence forces and the civilian elements. I see in the answer I have received from the Minister that the latter are described as `professional civilians'. I am not quite sure what a professional civilian is. Perhaps the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) will be prepared to explain that expression in the answer she gives me to this question. These professional civilians managed to keep control of the structure of the Defence Force in their hands. This was very damaging to the efficiency of the Defence Force. Structural and equipment decisions were made which were not right in the light of what the Australian Defence Force as a whole needed in view of the available capital resources.

I again ask: Does the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force, representing the Chief of the Defence Force, now have responsibility for determining and recommending the structure and equipment of the Defence Force in the future rather than acting as a mere co-ordinator of bids from the three separate Services? In particular, are the officers in each Service who were previously responsible for the planning of the equipment and structure of their own Service still responsible in this role to the Chief of Staff of their own Service, or are they responsible to the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force? That is fundamental. Until that responsibility is transferred we will have made no progress. It is urgently necessary for the officers responsible-in the Royal Australian Navy, the Army and the Royal Australian Air Force-for looking at the future needs of their side of the Services in relation to the Defence Force role as a whole, if it is to work, to be responsible to the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force, not their own Chief of Staff. If they remain responsible to their own Chief of Staff we will continue to face the same problem.

The other question which I asked, and to which I got what seemed to me to be a rather bizarre answer, concerned the Force Development and Analysis Division. This body looks, very properly, using operational analysis, at the various possible equipment options. In a system where the Chief of the Defence Force is looking at the future equipment of the Force, the people using operational research techniques to examine the relative merits of various solutions must be responsible to the person making the equipment recommendations. It appears from the answer to my question that the Force Development and Analysis Division is responsible to the Secretary. That is the old system of confrontation and division, giving the Secretary ammunition so that he can shoot at the recommendations of the Chief of the Defence Force. That has been very divisive in the past and, if it continues, will be very divisive in the future.

I ask the Minister: Are the Service officers responsible for planning the future equipment of the Defence Force responsible to their chiefs of staff, or are they directly responsible to the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force? Is the Force Development and Analysis Division responsible to the civilian Secretary, a professional civilian, as he is described in the answer I have received, or to the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force, who I understood was to be responsible for the future equipment programming of the Defence Force?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate on the appropriations for the Department of Defence I tabled the Hogg report and sought leave for the incorporation in Hansard of its recommendations. The observation was made that it was an abnormally long document for inclusion in Hansard. To incorporate in Hansard only that portion of the recommendations which is precisely recommendations, and excluding all the comment, would bring the document back, I would imagine, to about one column length of Hansard print. I seek leave to have the recommendations, excluding the comments, incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
RECOMMENDATIONS FOR CABINET
Part `A'

The following are recommendations for Cabinet consideration on matters raised by the VVAA in response to the Evatt Commission's findings, conclusions and recommendations together with those matters arising from my examination.
1. On the matter of the request from the VVAA for a further scientific inquiry into the work of the Evatt Royal Commission, I recommend the following:

A. that the VVAA be advised that the Government will not proceed with any further inquiry into the work of the Evatt Royal Commission, as whatever its deficiencies are, no benefit would accrue to the health of Vietnam veterans from such an inquiry;
B. that the Government proceed with the following scientific inquiries to be conducted by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) or an equally appropriate authority.
i. The mortality study of Australian Vietnam Veterans be regularly updated over the next 15 years, with the first update commencing forthwith, followed by further updates at suitable intervals.
ii. That the epidemiological study of the morbidity of Vietnam veterans in Australia referred to in the Evatt Commission be reactivated and proceed forthwith.

iii. That the Government in conjunction with the state governments arrange a nationwide study of the mortality experience of all agricultural workers who have been exposed to 2, 4-D and 2, 4, 5-T or a combination thereof, in the course of their work.

iv. That the Government request the NHMRC to examine the feasibility and benefit of a birth effects study on women who are believed to have been or are likely to have been exposed to 2, 4-D, 2, 4, 5-T or a combination thereof.
v. That the Government immediately establish an epidemiological study into the possible health effects arising from the use of Dapsone.

2. On the matter of the claims laid against the Evatt Commission by the VVAA and in other official correspondence, published letters and specifically the rebuttals of November 1985, April 1986, March 1987 and July 1987, I recommend the following:

A. That the VVAA be supplied copies of the replies prepared by the Special Projects Section of the Department of Veterans' Affairs with the advice that they conclude the government's response to matters relating to the conduct of the inquiry.
B. On the many claims of bias and plagiarism, we advise the VVAA, in line with the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department on bias and mine on plagiarism as expressed in my report:
i. that whilst the government does not endorse all aspects of the Evatt Commission's work, it does not accept that it acted with bias.

ii. and that whilst regretting the Evatt Commission did not act less clumsily and with greater sensitivity in its use of sections of Monsanto's submissions and Efron's ``The Apocalyptics'', the government does not accept that the inadequately attributed inclusions constituted plagiarism.
C. On the conclusion of the Evatt Commission of Agent Orange NOT Guilty.
I recommend the government maintains a position consistent with:
``No causal connection between the use of Agent Orange and the ill health of veterans or their families has been proven.''

D. On the possible matter of any future Royal Commissions of a kind where scientific knowledge or inquiry will play a relevant part, I recommend: that the Government establish such Commission(s) headed by a judge sitting with one or more fellow commissioners drawn from the appropriate scientific profession.

E. On the handling of the release of any future scientific studies as recommended, the government ensure that the media is properly briefed as to the intent of the study and the meaning of its findings prior to their reporting from a base of ignorance or misinformation. That for those outlets with the capacity, coverage should be handled by their scientific reporters.
Part `B'
The following are additional recommendations which amend some of the responses prepared by the Department of Veterans' Affairs in its draft Cabinet Submission of July 1986.

1. Benefit Claims-In the consideration of claims for benefits relating to stress, mental health disorders, cancer, alcoholism and circulatory system diseases, the post war circumstances of the veteran should be taken into account. Any alienation from the community resulting from its seeming indifference or disdain to those who served should be a factor for consideration.
2. Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service-That the government commits itself to maintaining, extending and improving this service for a period of five years at which time it will be subject to review.
3. Veterans Day-Monument-That the draft recommendation on a Vietnam Veterans Day and monument be adjusted, if necessary, to benefit from the experience of the October 3 Welcome Home Parade.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the Committee's attention to the report of Senate Estimates Committee E insofar as it relates to the quality and supply of current Army footwear. The Committee was told that the matter was a very sensitive one. Although there are stocks of all sizes of general purpose boots, there is not an adequate stock of any one size. There is quite an explanation in the Committee's report. The Committee considers that the provision of comfortable and reliable footwear to service personnel is a serious matter. The Committee was little comforted by Major-General Fitzgerald's frank admission that those responsible for solving problems such as defective material in boots `have been singularly unsuccessful in doing so over recent years'. I gave examples of boots which were losing all their eyelets after three weeks of use and boots which were so designed that they were giving blisters to wearers who had never had blisters before. Major-General Fitzgerald said that what I had described was absolutely true. Why has the Department been so singularly unsuccessful over so many years in achieving a satisfactory boot? We have had armed forces since Federation and I would have thought that some expertise would have been developed in the design and size of boots necessary to ensure that they wear well and do the job. I have to ask in open committee a simple question: Why can we not do it? Why are we not doing it?

—I think I would have preferred that the honourable senator asked that on the night of the Estimates Committee hearing. She might have got a more accurate response than I can give her today. I do not know why that piece of apparel is so poor. We got a partial explanation, from memory. We are now starting to head back in territory a few weeks. The position is not satisfactory, as was noted in the report of Estimates Committee E to this chamber. This will obviously come to the attention of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) as a matter of urgency. Senator Hamer, having been provided with what he calls a bland answer of gobbledegook--
—Non-answer.

—A non-answer. He now seeks from me a more firm answer in the foreknowledge that I do not have any further information. Rather than give him an extended non-answer, I simply say that I cannot add to the points he has made at this time. The question may have to be pursued in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Committee much longer. I have a question relating to the education allowance. During the Estimates Committee hearings we were told that only 87 children received the education allowance although there are 70,000 service personnel, of whom a high proportion are single. The average amount received is $4,425. The payment is governed by a set of eligibility criteria which is applied at unit and service office levels. Comprehensive statistics on applications and reasons for rejections are not kept. My first question is: Why can the statistics on applications and the reasons for rejections not be kept in the light of the widespread understanding in the defence forces that it is practically an impossibility to get this allowance? It is widely recognised, and it was recognised by the Hamilton report of the Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses, which looked into conditions for families, that education of their children was one of the major concerns. Yet we have a determination as to the education allowance which sets out that children in a boarding school can, in certain circumstances, get up to $3,958 a year for their tuition and $2,918 a year towards their board. If day pupils want to board at a guest house or hostel, they can get only $2,055 towards their board and nothing towards their tuition. If they want to board privately-which is convenient for many of them-they can get only $1,925 per annum towards that board and, once again, nothing for their tuition.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite apart from it being extremely difficult to get the allowance because of the way in which the criteria are interpreted, there are two kinds of school children. We have those going to expensive schools with parents who perhaps have a private income-and God knows there are few enough of those in the Services these days-and can get assistance for both their tuition fees and their boarding school fees. But those going to non-government schools and boarding privately or living in a hostel cannot get any assistance for their tuition and get a lesser amount for their board. If they board privately they get very little help at all. If they are in a government school maybe they do not need the same amount of assistance towards their tuition fees but I still regard the allowances for a hostel or private board as being quite inadequate when parents are trying to keep teenage children-which is the age we are usually considering-at a great distance from the parents, who might be at the other end of Australia. There is almost an insuperable hurdle in finding boarding accommodation for children who are not already attending a school which has such facilities. Although the allowance serves the needs of very few, it really is poorly structured for the majority.

I welcome the recent announcement of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) since the Estimates committee hearings that some assistance will be given for remedial tuition or coaching if children move to another State. But so many families would prefer to leave their children in the State system where they have the major part of their secondary education. I want to know why more information is not being kept on the number of people who apply for the allowance and why they are rejected? Why are the guidelines not being eased? Why are the amounts not being improved?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statistics are not kept. These decisions are made at a unit level. It seems to me that if we were to keep all these statistics that may be useful to absolutely anything we would come into this chamber and suddenly be accused of hiring thousands of bureaucrats to keep meaningless statistics. It is sort of a vicious circle: whether to devolve or whether to centralise. Those decisions being made at a unit level, the statistics on why people have not qualified for the allowance are not kept at a central location.

SPEECH.PARA: Criticism was raised about why the level of funding has not risen. That is a matter that I do not have any details on. I do not know why the criteria are not modified in a way which would be of benefit to other service personnel. I do not know how long those criteria have existed. Sometimes they just sit there-as in any government policy area-untouched for several years until someone is reminded that it may be about time to review them. There have been a lot of changes in the defence area. It is not possible to change everything at the one time. That particular concern, whilst it is not dealt with in the Estimates Committee report, may well be worth drawing to the Minister's attention for some consideration in future or to the attention of Assistant Minister Kelly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hamer's comments brought something to mind. In about February this year the Department of Defence issued an invitation to register interest for the new surface combatant for the Royal Australian Navy. In general, it went out to Australian shipbuilders asking them to make proposals on the design and construction for what has become the Anzac Class. As I understand this-and I seek confirmation of it-in September or October of this year the rules of the game were changed so that only those yards that had facilities already in place could tender. In other words, unless they had all the construction facilities and equipment on hand they were not allowed to tender for the contract. It seems to me that this restricts the contract to Williamstown and the Newcastle State Dockyard. Last night I was in the Parliamentary Library. I am not sure of the publication but I think in the International Defence Review there was the record of an interview with Minister Beazley. He said quite bluntly, `In my judgment there are only two yards in Australia that can build this surface combatant'. Is that an accurate representation of where we stand in regard to contracting? If it is, what about the money that those companies have spent in good faith in responding to the invitation to register interest at the start of the year? Surely, in light of the history of shipbuilding in Australia, the last two places in which we would build ships would be the Williamstown dockyard in Melbourne and the Newcastle State Dockyard in New South Wales.

—I am informed that at this stage there are no contracts. In fact, we are still in the process of selecting the design; therefore, no particular shipyard has been chosen. I have not seen Mr Beazley's comments on the subject. They may be based on history or on his knowledge of the general construction area. Who could disagree with the comments on Williamstown and Newcastle in terms of past performance? In terms of future viability, though, they will either be able to produce efficiently or they will not get contracts. It is not as though nothing has happened in that regard. A majority of the work force is starting to become convinced that the old game of starting to build a ship and then holding everything to ransom has long since gone. I think that this Government's record in that area is one of an improving situation. We have made it very clear that it is not in the interests of the taxpayer to pour more and more funds into dockyards to see them wasted by either industrial disruption or inefficiency. Unless those two places reach efficiency levels, they simply will not get contracts.
—Has there been a significant narrowing of the eligibility of companies to tender for this contract after the initial request for registration of interest was called for?
—I am sorry; I cannot assist Senator MacGibbon any further. I am not aware that that is the case. I am never that definitive in saying no, there has not been, but we are not aware of it.

—I noticed earlier that Mr Finnegan was advising the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). I am not sure whether he is still here. During the Estimates committee hearings Mr Finnegan answered some questions from me concerning temporary rental accommodation and the reimbursement of families, particularly in the Sydney area, where so many high costs must be outlaid before they can be reimbursed. I have been advised from a number of sources that there were delays in reimbursing these families. Mr Finnegan said that he had not heard of this and that he would be prepared to examine it. I asked him to take another look at the matter and he said he would do so. I wonder whether any up to date information is available as to whether this matter has been speeded up and what the delays are before families are reimbursed.

—This morning the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) asked me from where I obtained the figure of $25m regarding the cost of the Geraldton satellite station. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray recently was reported in this chamber as saying that the Government was working towards increasing the compulsory retiring age of pilots of wing commander rank in the Royal Australian Air Force to 55 years. I thought perhaps that this might have been a mistake. Then I checked and found that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly, had used exactly the same words in the other place. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that this matter is of particular concern to all officers in the Australian Defence Force as this change could mean that one of the following courses is contemplated: the retiring age of only wing commanders would be increased to age 55, which would cause mass resignations of wing commander pilots who have not completed 20 years service to qualify for the pension and squadron leader pilots who have completed 20 years but who might be promoted soon; the retiring age for wing commander pilots and other service equivalents-commander, Royal Australian Navy and lieutenant-colonel, Australian Army-would be increased, causing mass resignations of those people who have not achieved retiring age and also amongst squadron leaders, lieutenant-commanders and majors who have served over 20 years and who might be promoted; or the retiring age scales for all service officer ranks would be increased, since to imply an increase to one rank within one service would be discriminatory in the extreme, thus causing mass resignations from the three services.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister: Is the Government really aware of what it is doing when it is talking about working towards increasing the compulsory retiring age of pilots of wing commander rank to 55 years? TALK.START.PARA: —I think these thoughts were particularly targeted at the pilots in the services. I will have to seek a response from the Minister on the eventual effects on the other arms of the services.

—Is the Minister not aware of the fact that if this is what the Government is going to do, there will be a very quick mass exodus from the Royal Australian Air Force, particularly of squadron leader pilots who have completed 20 years of service and who think they might be promoted soon or of wing commanders who have not completed 20 years service to qualify for the pension? —It hasn't been thought through.

—Senator Reid interjects that it has not been thought through. I would rather not go into depth on subjects that I do not know enough about. After all, I am representing the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I do not read every defence report that comes across my desk; indeed, I am not shown all the reports. So rather than postulate on the honourable senator's hypothesis, I should get a considered response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise that it is sensible of the Minister to get a considered response, but I also draw attention to the fact that within a couple of days both Senator Ray and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) used exactly the same expression in the two chambers. So I alert the Minister to the danger of causing more of a problem than we already have.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to wind up by drawing the Committee's attention again to the report of the Estimates committee which says that on many occasions it has raised the question of the high rates of resignation from the Defence Force. TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget Papers reveal an incredible increased expenditure in sections of the Department of Administrative Services. There is, for example, an increase of 63 per cent, or $55.9m, in expenditure on Commonwealth offices. There is an increase of 54 per cent, or $74m, in property management and services. If one looks at the tables in the back of the Budget Papers one will see that these rises are part of a continuing exercise in a massive expenditure rise by this Government on administrative services, particularly on accommodation of various kinds. Since this Government came to power there has been an increase of something like 50 per cent, from $127m to $186m, in construction services. There is a fourfold increase, from $46m to $144m, for Commonwealth offices. There is a threefold increase, from $70m to $211m, for property management and services. There is a 3.7 times increase, from $100m to $373m, for rent. One thing that this Government is doing is looking after itself fairly well at a time of restraint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer to the Parliament House Construction Authority. The Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) will be aware of the matter as he was the Minister who, on Estimates Committee E, gave many of the responses which exposed certain anomalies and contradictions. The answer generally bore out the Auditor-General's criticism that there had been significant management inadequacies in the new Parliament House, which have operated to the detriment of the interests of the Commonwealth and, ultimately, the taxpayer. Of particular concern was the confirmation by the Authority that the site's 200 plumbers each received a $500 pay-out following a nine-week strike, simply to return to work. The Authority admitted that it was reimbursing some of the plumbing contractors for this payment that they had made to their employees. Yet, despite the fact that the Authority, and ultimately the taxpayer, is paying for the deal, it was claimed that the arrangement was made without the Authority's knowledge or approval, and, at the time of Estimates Committees E, we did not know how the plumbing contractors were being reimbursed by the Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: Worse still, it was admitted that if the Authority had known about the payment, it would not have agreed to it because, as it conceded, the deal was outside the Government's industrial relations policy. I submit that it is utter hypocrisy for the Authority to claim as it did in its response to the efficiency audit, that it had effectively applied the project's industrial relations policy of not giving into the unions' demands just to have the building completed on time. Furthermore, the Authority was complacent about the deal and its implications, and it apparently plans, as I understand from evidence given to Estimates Committee E, to do nothing about recouping the payouts. It seems that the Authority's only concern, according to the Chief Executive, was that, at the end of the day, payments did not exceed the approved amounts for the contract. This raises the question: if the contract does not exceed the approved amount, how much fat has been built into the new Parliament House contract so that it can absorb the cost of deals like this payment? This deal alone cost $100,000. Even if the payments do exceed the approved amount, the Authority will no doubt insist that the cost has not overrun budget. The Authority will simply apply its own particular brand of Yes Minister logic, which has allowed it to say that the cost of constructing the new Parliament House has not blown out.
The $500 payout to each of the plumbers reinforces the Auditor-General's criticism. This is really what I want to get on to. He stated:
The Authority's continued reluctance to take action against the construction manager for an unauthorised expenditure indicates a lack of effective control.

Of greater magnitude and concern than the plumbers' payout is the reponse given in answer to me about a question in respect of the longer running dispute. In the Estimates Committee I asked the Construction Authority the following question:

In another response to the Auditor-General you stated that the construction manager's response to the unions' claim for severance pay in 1983-84 was that the claim should be pursued through the Arbitration Commission and the claim would be resisted.

I believe, and I mentioned this in the introduction to the report, that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) had made a similar remark. This explanation is at odds with the Auditor-General's report which states:
The Authority accepted liability for costs to contractors-
which was approximately $6.5m-
. . . the CM may have improperly given unions reason to believe that a severance pay scheme might be favourably considered as part of the renegotiation of the Site Agreement.
I asked the Construction Authority how this anomaly could be explained. Mr Peatey, on behalf of the Construction Authority, replied:
It is obviously an opinion of the Auditor-General; it is not an opinion the Authority shared.

That is the point that I wish to discuss. Recently, I received a copy of a letter from the Auditor-General, dated 16 November 1987, to the Chairman of Estimates Committee E, Senator Aulich. In regard to the point I have just raised, the Auditor-General had this to say:

Senator Parer referred to the comment in the Auditor-General's report (paragraph 5.12.2) that the Authority accepted liability for costs to contractors affected by the strike in 1983-84 because the construction manager (CM) may have improperly given unions reason to believe a severance pay scheme might be considered favourably.
He repeated the answer given to me by the Authority's Chief Executive, Mr Peatey, that that was the opinion of the Auditor-General, but not the opinion of the Authority, and went on to say:

The question of whether the Authority accepted that liability is not one of opinion, but of fact. The Authority received legal advice at the time which indicated that the CM failed to discharge properly its duty to manage industrial matters and that the contractors would be entitled to reimbursement by the Authority of extra costs incurred. After considering the advice, the Authority informed the CM:
formal agreement has now been obtained to accept valid claims from contractors which flow from events to the recent site stoppage on severance pay.

Here we have an Estimates Committee, questions are asked, answers are given and they are incorrect. It is apparent from the Auditor-General's letter, to which I have just referred and which came to my desk today, that, one way or another, the members of the Senate Committee were misled by the Construction Authority. I am not sure whether this was deliberate or not, but we were misled. It seems extraordinary that the Construction Authority would say to me that that is simply an opinion of the Auditor-General, and not the opinion of the Authority when we are now aware-it was in the Auditor-General's report, as I subsequently found-that it received a legal opinion on this matter. I would like an answer to these questions. Were we misled? If so, why, and what does the Government intend to do about it?

I have another point that I would like to raise. In the Estimates Committee, I asked a question which was subsequently responded to about the number of working days lost through industrial disputation from September 1985 to the present. I think the response to this question is worth recording. It states:
The site has not been closed down since the 14 week dispute in 1984. Records are not kept in a manner that would provide a direct answer to this question.

However, in order to assess the cost the project of industrial disputes, after 1984 a formula was agreed between the Authority, the Departments of Finance and Administrative Services (then Housing and Construction). Part of that formula provides an assessment of `project days' lost through disputes.
In the period September 1985 to September 1987 (inclusive) the assessed project days lost was 133.5, or an average of 5.6 days per month . . .

That 5.6 days a month means that one week of project days was lost each month for two years. I think that it can be safely anticipated that, in view of the past record of the construction of the new Parliament House, in the closing stages of the construction unreasonable demands and, hence, disputes can be expected to escalate. I ask: What contingent plans does the Authority have to handle this situation? In view of a nominated opening date will the Authority simply pay up at taxpayers' expense?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is to be regretted that the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) is not here at the moment because I want to add to something said earlier by Senator Crichton-Browne about St Martin's Tower in Perth. I want to draw to the attention of the Minister an article in yesterday's West Australian newspaper under the heading `Concrete Cancer'. This building in Perth which houses the Commonwealth's parliamentary offices is described as having the disease, concrete cancer. It is fairly common knowledge that, in fact, pieces of the building's cladding have been falling off for a number of years. There are a number of Western Australian senators, including myself, who are situated on the thirtieth and thirty-first floor of that building. The Committee can understand that I have a very personal interest in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I presume that the lease paid by the Commonwealth under the appropriation for the Department of Administrative Services includes an allocation towards the cost of the maintenance of the exterior of that building. This is worrying because also in the article in yesterday's newspaper to which I referred it was stated that there is litigation because of the state of the exterior of the building, involving the owners of the building, the builders, the architects, the structural engineers and the concrete suppliers. Therefore, I presume-I hope I am correct-that under the appropriation money has been set aside for the possible relocation of senators if the lease has to be terminated and, also, in the event of damage to Commonwealth personnel or property, due to structural movement or collapse of the building, there would be suitable compensation payable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just one question. I thank the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) for the letter he sent me in relation to Deakin Offices. I ask: Are there any non-Australian Government tenants of the Deakin Offices building; if so, who are they?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the best of my knowledge, I think I can say that there are almost certainly no non-Australian Government tenants. Senator Walters asked a question at the Estimates committee as to who occupies the Deakin Offices building.
—What departments?

—Senator Walters asks, `What departments?'. Certainly as far as I know there are no other occupants. The reason I hesitate is that in my first letter to Senator Walters, out of a sense of natural modesty and otherwise, I said `include the following departments' and Senator Walters automatically assumed that there must be other departments. That is why I have come back to be a little more definitive in my answer.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I should say something a little more broadly-based about the Deakin Offices because all sorts of conspiracy theories have been going around as to what is being done there. These theories seem to have emanated from a one-time employee of the Department of Social Security who is writing all sorts of conspiracy theories now and bolting them around the traps. I am not saying that any honourable senator would be gullible enough to believe them, but such rumours create other stories from more reasonable people and they are transferred on until finally they are brought in here.

Just recently the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, wrote a four-page explanation to all Ministers explaining the background of such rumours. Part of the accusation was that only the Minister for Science and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, would understand what is really happening in Deakin Offices. A few weeks ago Mr Barry Jones wandered down there and had a wander through. To put all things at rest in terms of what is going to happen, I understand that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, with all its computer experts, will have a thorough and complete coverage of everything in the building. Hopefully, that will bury the rumours first, that it is a secret Australia Card headquarters where we are printing away Australia Cards for everyone and, secondly, that it is being used as the offices to re-elect Labor for a fourth term, or anything else. As far as I know, and with almost absolute certainty, I can say that normal Government processes and computer operations are occurring in that building. The conspiracy theories have little or no foundation.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case there is any suggestion that I would be taking information from anyone outside, as I told the Minister in the Estimates committee hearings, I rang and asked whoever answered the phone to tell me what departments had offices in the Deakin Offices. I was told that no, they could not tell me; if I wanted to know anything they had been instructed not to tell me and I was to apply to the Department of Administrative Services. As I also said, when a member of my staff went to Deakin Offices to inquire he was told, `No, sir, I cannot answer your question. Would you please leave'. When he did leave, the number of his car was taken and he was checked up on. The Minister must admit that that raises certain queries in senators' minds. Such questions do not have to come from outside this place.

—Heaven forbid that I should accuse Senator Walters of falling prey to a conspiracy theory. I was quite explicit in excluding any honourable senator. All I was saying is that such rumours have done the rounds. Apparently someone who holds a position in that building has been a little overzealous in taking the action he did. Of course, we deplore that sort of behaviour. In my view, it is a fairly mindless act. I repeat that the Public Accounts Committee is going to go to that building and give it the once over in terms of looking at all its computers and anything else. No doubt, it will report to this Parliament. I think the Committee is due to go on about 6 December, I cannot quite recall the correspondence. Certainly, first, that Committee has made the decision to go and, secondly, it has been given permission to go and look at all aspects of the building.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Defence a short time ago, the question of removals came up. Senator Ray queried my claim that evidence had been given at the Estimates committee hearings of the Department of Administrative Services estimates of one damage claim for every 2.3 removals. I have checked and that figure does not appear in the Hansard of the Estimates. However, evidence was given that the rate has remained approximately the same for a number of years and the Department has not been able to get that rate down despite strong efforts. I think it is a matter of concern that the Department has not been able to get that rate down. However, I am convinced that the small nature of the penalty which the Department imposes, that is, one month's suspension, clearly is not enough to sheet home a few lessons. I am glad to draw it again to the Minister's attention and hope that we will see an improvement by means of stiffer penalties.

SPEECH.PARA: The other interesting thing to which I would like to draw the Committee's attention is the evidence given by the Government Printer, Mr Rubie, when talking about the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. It is a very interesting outcome of the user pays principle because the number of Commonwealth gazettes produced has been reduced, because people have to pay for them, from something like 12,000 to around 8,000. Apparently the Government Printer did predict this. It is one of the consequences of moving towards cost recovery, where people have to pay for what they use. I am very glad to see that economics are being made in such sensible directions and I give credit for it.

Evidence was also given, however, that some departments-and the department mentioned was the Attorney-General's Department-were not producing their material in a camera-ready form so that cost savings could be made in what went into the Gazette. That, these days, is paid for by the client departments. In the case of the Attorney-General's Department there was quite a high cost for gazetting pages and pages of marriage celebrants. I hope the Government Printer will be teaching his clients how to make cost savings in the amount of gazettal space they use in future.

I have a couple of questions. One relates to an answer given by the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) in connection with the list of Defence properties for sale. The answer was quite detailed but I found it a little hard to follow. I wonder whether any elucidation could be given now. I am told that the total target revenue in 1987-88 from the disposal of Defence properties is $59.5m. It was said in the answer:

The Government has decided that the Department of Defence should be responsible for raising about half of this amount ($30m). That Department is therefore undertaking all necessary action to dispose of particular properties.

My first question relating to this answer is: Why is the Department of Defence responsible for raising that $30m? Why is this not being done through the Department of Administrative Services? With regard to the $30m, the Department of Defence apparently has asked DAS to dispose of some of the properties, to the tune of $7m. If Defence has been told to dispose of the properties, as distinct from DAS disposing of them, why does it then ask DAS to do it? A sentence in the answer said:
The balance of the program ($13.5m) remains unspecified.
Why is it unspecified and how long will it remain so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that most of those Department of Defence properties were well under way for disposal at the start of this year. The honourable senator asks why Defence is disposing of them. I cannot put it more bluntly than to say that it won the battle in the Cabinet room. However, the Department of Administrative Services will not be divorced from the process. It will be involved in the process of the disposal of those properties to make sure the proper methodology is used. That answers the question in regard to the $30m.

SPEECH.PARA: I apologise to Senator Jenkins for not being here to answer her questions. I had anticipated a slightly longer speech on the new Parliament House, which I have heard many times before-and I wanted a brief break. Concerning the problems she raised with regard to St Martin's Tower, I will seek a report in the next two or three days on all aspects of concern by honourable senators. I probably will not table that report but I will write to her and other interested members of parliament indicating the salient points in that report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to draw the Minister's attention to the fact that at the April Estimates hearings I would like more information about that Department of Defence list. I am afraid that some of the Minister's answer was a bit beyond my understanding. It may be simply that I have not yet had the benefit of the joy of the tussle within Cabinet. I fail to see why that should have anything to do with who sells properties when it is clearly the responsibility of the Department of Administrative Services to buy and sell Defence assets. Perhaps the Minister can explain that to me at another time.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to questions relating to the Constitutional Commission. In response to questions to the Attorney-General's Department we were told that $70,000 had been spent on publicising preparations for the launches of the advisory committee reports and for the advertising of hearings and the work associated with those hearings of the five advisory committees. Was a consultant engaged to advise on or arrange this publicity and advertising? If so, was this arranged through the Department of Administrative Services? Is this not required by the Department of Finance guidelines?

The Constitutional Commission published a book called Australia's Constitution: Time to Update, which was not published through the Australian Government Publishing Service. Did the Attorney-General's Department, for example, give the Constitutional Commission the right to go outside the guidelines for Commonwealth departments and statutory bodies and not publish through the Australian Government Publishing Service or did the Constitutional Commission take it upon itself not to follow the guidelines? Who makes the decisions as to whether a statutory body such as this does not follow guidelines? I would have thought that, as this body uses public moneys to do its job and comes under the umbrella of the Attorney-General's Department, it should follow the requirements for consultants and the guidelines for printing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any specific information on that matter. That question is more appropriate for the original Estimates committee processes. Maybe it can be raised when the Attorney-General's Department is brought back on, as I understand it will be, because those opposite missed the boat this morning and let the votes for that Department slip through. In a burst of enormous generosity we will call that Department back on. The Department of Administrative Services does not know anything about the matter at this stage. It could be pursued with the Attorney-General's Department. If we can find out anything in the meantime, we will certainly let Senator Newman know. As happens so often, specific questions requiring such specific detail cannot be answered in the debate in the Committee of the Whole. The questions should first have been asked at the Estimates committee hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the Estimates Committee hearings I referred to the use of architectural and engineering consultants in the Northern Territory by the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Defence. I was given a number of answers by departmental officers. I refer in particular to the reply given by Mr Martin:

SPEECH.PARA: The general process for some time has been that the Darwin office is a subset of the Adelaide office, but there is a definite policy to try to maximise the placement of consultancies in the Northern Territory.

I am concerned that this procedure appears to be back to front or the wrong way about. The extent of capital works that take place in both South Australia and the Northern Territory would indicate that the Department ought to look very seriously at locating its principal office and principal professional and technical staff in Darwin, rather than Adelaide.

The current 1987-88 works in the Northern Territory, excluding Tindal, amount to some $50m, while in South Australia the extent of the capital works program is some $6.7m. Whereas the number of professional and technical staff engaged by the Department in the Northern Territory is 76, in South Australia it is 287. There appears to be a great deal of inefficiency in the way in which the Department is currently administering its activities in South Australia and the Northern Territory. This problem should be seriously addressed. The Adelaide office is in the process of seconding additional staff to work on projects. Seconding is always a suspicious staffing arrangement because, ultimately, it entrenches the engagement of consultant mechanisms. Once we second people from existing offices, the mechanisms build in a certain creep and a certain process whereby the work takes place.

I believe that the Department needs very seriously to look at the capacities that currently exist in the Northern Territory for major utilisation of the private sector architectural and engineering consultants and at reversing the process of transferring staff out of the Northern Territory and into South Australia when the principal construction work load is in the Northern Territory. I look forward to the Minister's reply as to how this matter is being addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of matters that arise out of the answers given in the Estimates committee hearings. They relate particularly to the cost of Government advertising and to the operations of the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS). So far as the cost of Government advertising is concerned, the figures presented in the detailed answers to the questions that were asked are very revealing indeed. They give us a very clear example of the very large amount of money being spent on government advertising for the purpose of promoting the Government rather than informing the electorate generally. I ask for a comment from the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) on this matter. I think it is of very real concern that enormous amounts of money are now being spent on government advertising for no apparent purpose other than to promote the image of the Government rather than on advertising in the normal sense of the word.

SPEECH.PARA: Work that has been done in response to information obtained through freedom of information requests and from other sources has shown, for example, that in 1985-86-these figures are a year old-the Government's advertising bill increased to $34.64m, of which $23m was spent on campaigns and $11m on the day to day advertising of government jobs and public notices, with which latter advertising, of course, we would have no complaint at all. As pointed out by Senator Michael Baume as a result of the work of the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee last year, that $34m was almost double the amount spent in the last full financial year of the preceding government. There has been an enormous escalation in expenditure, not on explaining what government is doing but on promoting, I would say improperly, contentious decisions or promoting the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Ministers. I do not believe that that ought to be the objective of the use of taxpayers' money on government advertising.

The figures have reached an extraordinarily high level. I believe that it is a matter of very great concern to the public. Even in terms of the promotion of government programs, millions of dollars are being spent on advertising programs that either have not been effective or have yielded very little indeed. For example, in response to questions asked in Estimates Committee E, a figure of more than $1m was given for the advertising of the apparent virtues of the Australian traineeship scheme in 1986-87, yet the results, lamentably, have been miles below the Government's own targets. The Government had estimated that in 1986-87 15,000 people would commence traineeships, but it was revealed in Estimates Committee D that the actual result was in the vicinity of fewer than 7,000. As for 1987-88, officials of the relevant department acknowledged that the results would fall far below target. As for the famous target which occasioned so much publicity and on which so much was spent in government advertising-that, in the year ahead or thereabouts, 75,000 traineeship places would be made available and filled-it is acknowledged by all concerned that that target has no hope of being met.

Similar comments could be made in principle about the money spent on advertising the International Year of Peace (IYP). The figures presented to us show that $319,643 was spent on advertising IYP. I would like to have a comment from the Minister as to whether he seriously believes that any of that expenditure has made the world any more peaceful or has had a beneficial influence on the attitudes of Australians towards what is obviously a very important issue. I am not decrying the importance of the issue; I am decrying the way in which taxpayers' money has been spent to promote government rather than anything else.

The business migration program is another example. Approximately $34,000 has been spent on advertising that program, yet we have had examples in recent times of enormous delays in the processing of applications. We have had topsyturvy changes to policy and decisions have been made without any guarantees to the Parliament that the new arrangements being introduced will not open up new avenues for corruption and will not increase difficulties in the whole area.

More than $2m has been spent on the Australian made campaign. I note in passing that that is one of the John Singleton advertising agency promotions. I would have thought that the benefit that has been derived from that was little or nil. Something like $2m has been spent on promoting the Government's policy on the fringe benefits tax. That to me was simply a promotion in the community of a contentious policy. I do not believe that government or taxpayers' money can legitimately be used in any shape or form in advertising campaigns in such areas as that.

I again express the concern of the Opposition about what this Government is doing in the area of advertising. I think it is improper. The Government and the Minister must take a look at this matter. If they are really fair dinkum about restraining government expenditure and operating properly on behalf of the taxpayers, these are quite improper uses of taxpayers' funds.

I have a similar comment to make about the operations of the National Media Liaison Service. That service is costing the taxpayer something like $1m this year. It is a ubiquitous service. The staff are attached to ministerial officers. In response to a House of Representatives question on notice it was stated on 26 October by the Minister for Administrative Services on behalf of the Minister for Home Affairs that the Director of the National Media Liaison Service and the Ministerial Media Group, Colin Parks, worked at Australian Labor Party headquarters during the last election campaign. He acted as the co-ordinator of ministerial activity during that election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was he still on the payroll?
—Not only was he on the payroll but he was not even on leave. He did not seek official leave during that period.
—That is a disgrace.

—I believe that is an absolute disgrace. I think I am right in saying that the problem that Senator Baume struck towards the end of the election campaign was in relation to some comments on radio that were picked up as part of the election campaign by the NMLS representative in Hobart. We have no objection, of course, to the Government having its own intelligence network in terms of media liaison. Any government or any party worth its salt will do that. But it is an absolute disgrace for taxpayers' money to be used for that purpose. We are now talking about taxpayers' money of the order of $1m per year. Salaries of the National Media Liaison Service this year are estimated at $600,000. There are other costs. In response to a question from me in Estimates Committee E on 8 October the answer I received was that other costs for the NMLS on top of the $600,000 for salaries form part of the total additional funds provided for the NMLS and the Ministerial Media Group which are estimated at $526,000 in 1987-88.
