So we are talking about a figure in excess of $1.1m and a total staff of 20. I reiterate to the Minister the great concern that I have and that the Opposition has about the use of taxpayers' money for these purely party political purposes. I guess it is asking too much to expect that he will take any notice of what I am saying, but I can assure him that there are many people out in the community who are very concerned about what they would regard as a totally wrong use of their taxpayers' funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short is a fascinating study here today. It is a pity we do not have a time machine because I would like to go back to 1980 when he was defeated as member for Ballarat. I do not raise that in a derogatory sense; the tide was against him. It must have been like being hit by a truck because he has suddenly got political amnesia and he does not recall what happened between 1975 and 1980 when he was a government member. His Government and the Government that continued in office during the 2 1/2 years he was on the, let us say, interchange bench of politics, spent enormous amounts of money on government advertising. This Government has set no new patterns, no new record levels. When was there any criticism from Senator Short when he was in Parliament or a candidate for the Senate on the level of government advertising by the Liberal Party of Australia in coalition with the National Party of Australia? Was there any criticism then?
—I think you criticised it.

—There is a difference: I admit my inconsistency on these matters. I have already confessed to it today. I remember the old Government Information Unit. Does Senator Short not recall that? It used to be the propaganda wing of the Liberal Party of Australia, nothing more-so much so that it would not even give the National Party much of a run. Senator Short makes a great point that the National Media Liaison Service may have played some political role. I hope John Howard's staff went on holiday for the whole of the campaign! The trouble is that every time he was filmed around the country there was the ubiquitous Graham Morris-or whatever his name is, the bloke you cannot miss-in the background all the time. What was he doing and what were all the rest of them doing there? Of course every member of the Opposition uses his parliamentary staff in election campaigns. Of course, the Opposition uses its allocation in the election campaigns.
—That is nothing to do with the National Media Liaison Service.

—Senator Stone is not stupid. He is not going to go out and campaign all around this country by himself. He will use his research staff and anyone else he can to assist him in this way. What is really galling, of course, is that-Senator Short has let the cat of the bag-we caught Senator Baume and the result is that we have moved him 11 feet in this chamber, from where Senator Short sits up to the second row. It was a bit unfortunate in terms of the timing; I agree. That was a very efficient operation. Let us recall the events. Senator Baume was, I think, in Ballarat. Through the marvels of modern technology he was rung from Tasmania. He was then asked a series of questions about the Liberal Party tax policy. It must have been very irritating to Senator Baume because the bloke asked him the question about nine times. When Senator Baume finally made a stumble, the caller said, `Thank you very much. Good bye' and he hung up in Senator Baume's ear before he probably even had a chance to correct that answer. That is quite possible. It was a beautiful piece of cross-examination: the Queen's Counsel finally elicits the answer he wants and asks no more questions. So it was picked up by some diligent officer. So what; that was his job. So it was transmitted to the Labor Party. So we did ambush John Howard with it at the National Press Club and the wheels fell off the Opposition's campaign for the second time. That is bad luck. The Government Information Unit would have done the same in 1980.
—The National Media Liaison Service.

—No, I am talking about the Liberal one. The Liberal one would have done exactly the same. Of course it would have. It worked as a servant of the Government for whatever political purposes that Government put to it. Let us cut out the hypocrisy here.
—No, you are wrong.

—Senator Stone says I am wrong; I say I am right. Let us cut out the hypocrisy. We had this out in Estimates Committee C from 1981 to 1983. The only difficulty was that it was a lot harder to pull information out then than it is today. In 1982 we had to sit on nine occasions to get a lot of that information. We were told in 1982 that there was no post-Budget survey on the Budget. We were told time and time again. Amazing! At the ninth meeting we got the copy of the results of the survey. So Senator Stone should not come along here and say, `No, it was not put to that purpose'. The truth was rarely told about these matters. Senator Short says that government advertising and the levels of it are of concern to him because most of the advertisements are of a political complexion. I deny that most are. I concede that it could be construed that some are, but most are not. The largest single items are for defence. They can hardly be regarded as political advertisements, the ones for the Defence Reserves and so on. The reason that government advertising has gone up substantially over the last few years, really relates to three campaigns: the one on acquired immune deficiency syndrome-I hardly think it was a political point we were making on that-the Australian made campaign and the anti-drug abuse campaign. They were the three big ticket items from 1985-86 to 1986-87. There is also a large component of what one might call functional advertising where we advertise committee hearings, staff positions, et cetera. That amounted to $13m out of $40m, I think, in 1986-87. Six million dollars was spent on creative campaign productions; $21m in actual placement in the media-that comes to $27m-and then the other $13m was almost all spent on essentially things such as advertising for tenders and those sort of machinery type things.
—I am not objecting to that; I am objecting to the $27m.

—Senator Short objects to the $27m. I am saying that at least $11m of that amount goes in the defence area et cetera. A lot of the concern will be, from my point of view, about what is institutionalised; what is not reviewed every year. We have taken steps since I became a Minister to make sure every one of those programs is properly reviewed and evaluated. I would be delighted to cut the figure down. I think $40m a year on government advertising should be about the outside of the envelope. We should, wherever possible, be looking to reduce that amount of expenditure. The role of the ministry of Home Affairs in this is not so much in the initial decision making as to where one should advertise or how much should be spent but in making sure the proper procedures are followed and the right master advertising agencies are used. Also through a ministerial council various advertisements are reviewed to see whether they are effective.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not trying to deny responsibility in this regard. What I am saying is that we do not have absolute authority in determining which campaign will go and which one will not. Those are usually Cabinet decisions. We then review the nature of the campaign and a variety of things such as expenditure; if the proper tendering processes have not been used, we force them to go through those procedures. But by accumulating a fair bit of information, because one has an overview of every department, one is able to establish whether the priorities of the Government are sufficient, and whether there is enough challenging of previous assumptions. I am not saying that I would make a decision one way or the other, but we would look at whether it is justifiable to spend $11m on defence advertising every year or whether it should be increased in line with the consumer price index. Those are the sorts of decisions that governments must make.

In response to the honourable senator's view that the entire $27m concerns straight-out political advertising, I deny that that is so. One could place certain connotations on it-that some of it is supportive of Government policy in terms of the fringe benefits tax. It is very hard to know where to draw the line in regard to the fringe benefits tax-whether one is just supplying information and explaining systems to the public, or whether one is pushing a party political barrow. I defy honourable senators opposite to say, in relation to one of the ads on the fringe benefits tax, that we are pushing our political barrow. It looked more like a play from the Marquis de Sade. I could never follow any part of it. I cannot see how we were pushing a message with that advertisement. That was one of the poorer advertising campaigns that has been seen in this country.

I would be interested to hear about the setting up of some definitive moral guidelines, because I know what will happen: when Opposition senators move to this side of the chamber all of those guidelines will be thrown out of the window. They would be into it like we are; that is a reality--

TALK.START.PARA: —Like you are.
—No, to the extent that the Opposition accuses us of doing it, the Opposition would do exactly the same thing.
—I hope you are wrong.

—No, Senator Stone should not hope we are wrong. When he has had a little more political rather than bureaucratic experience, he will see that political history repeats itself. I suggest that he read the transcripts of Estimates committee hearings for the last 15 years. He will see that all the same points have been made: the Lodge is too expensive; we should not fix the leaky roof. It was said in 1976; it was said in 1980; and it was said in 1986. I object only to the pomposity and the moral posturing on some of these issues, not to the fact--
—Didn't you ever do it?

—Of course I did it. I did it even better than Senator Baume does it. That is one of the reasons why we are on this side of the chamber. We did it very effectively. We certainly had more staying power. Thank goodness that Opposition senators do not, or Estimates Committee E would still be meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the general question of political advertising of which we are accused, if any definition of advertising as being political could be developed, it certainly would not even constitute a majority of government advertising. I cannot put a figure on it. It is very hard; it is a subjective judgment as to whether one regards an advertisement as a fair distribution and dissemination of information, or whether one regards it as propaganda. It is also very much in the eye of the beholder as to whether one makes that particular judgment.

In finalising the point on whether Mr Parks or anyone else was misused, governments have always used personal staff members in this way. I do not refer to public servants, because I see a distinction, if that is the one that Senator Stone wants to draw. These people are not public servants, they are personal staff of Ministers. If they wish to involve themselves in a campaign they tend to do so. This occurs on all sides of politics. I would be very interested to look at the travel patterns-if the honourable senator wants to persist with this-of the various staff of the Opposition. I am sure there would be about the same sort of pattern as for staff of Government members.

If one goes to 400 Flinders Street-and I do not mean to be derogatory to Senator Powell-in the middle of a Federal election, one is likely to trip over a bundle of Democrat how-to-vote cards and kill oneself. I have already related what happened there to a poor old window cleaner, but it is worth repeating. A poor old window cleaner's machine at 400 Flinders Street broke down. The poor man was in dire strife. The emergency services were sent for. All the television cameras arrived. What did the Democrats do to help? Two of them waddled out-that was the best description I heard-with a little sign saying, `Vote Democrat'. Every time the cameras moved, the sign moved so that it remained on the screen. I do not know whether the poor old window cleaner in fact converted to Labor or Liberal afterwards. I would be very surprised if he did not.

I have no specific information for Senator Tambling on the matter he raised, but I make the point that work loads fluctuate. That is a very important point in the consideration of the matters he raised today. When there is a need for officers from Adelaide to go to the Northern Territory, they do so. It is difficult to replicate every Commonwealth service in the Northern Territory, which comprises one Federal electorate. It would be like saying we must replicate every service in each of the 148 electorates. I know he is a passionately parochial supporter of the Northern Territory, as was his predecessor, Senator Kilgariff, as was Senator Robertson and as is Senator Collins; he is very passionate in his defence of Northern Territory rights. We very much like to assist him in most things, but there is a limit to the amount of expenditure we can pour into the Northern Territory. I think that the Commonwealth contribution to the Northern Territory is about $5,900 per head per year compared to, say, $400 for the home State of the shadow Minister and the Minister. So the Northern Territory is not getting too bad a trot, all things considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was fascinated, when I was listening in my room to the broadcast of the proceedings, to hear the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) say to Senator Stone, `You all indulge in it'. I was a member of the Senate during the time the Opposition was last in government. Following the Whitlam era, during which so much money was spent on advertising Government propaganda, when the coalition came to office I assure the Minister that that stopped. Senator Ray was not here at that time, but I can assure him that that stopped. I can assure him that, in discussions in the party room, when it was suggested that we might be able to get across our message by using the same methods that Mr Whitlam had used, we were told by Mr Fraser that that was not legitimate expenditure of taxpayers' money and that we would not indulge in that type of expenditure. So I really do not think that Senator Ray ought to include the Opposition in the methods used by the Australian Labor Party and, I admit, used continuously. The present Government is no different from the Whitlam Government in that regard; not at all. I admit that it has followed the quite traditional Labor tactics along this line. But Senator Ray should not include us, because that is not right. Indeed, it was specifically talked about on many occasions, and Mr Fraser would not allow it to happen. So Senator Ray should not try, with a charming air, to say, `Yes, we do it, but of course you do, too', because that is just not so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1981, $17.59m was spent on advertising. In the next year it went to $24.84m. I am not too good at maths, but that is about a 20 to 30 per cent increase. Not even at the previous Government's worst excess did it have inflation running at that rate. Does Senator Walters remember the selling of the 1982 Budget? Does she not remember the family group shown on television, flogging off the Budget, about which all the cartoonists had a field day? The average suburban Sullivans, if you like. Can she not remember that? I hope she is not slipping that much, because I have a reasonable respect for her memory.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the previous Government indulged in all forms of political advertising. It is in the eye of the beholder. She would not regard it as political advertising. She would say it was just a matter of explaining government policy. We did the same in opposition as the Opposition is doing now. I am quite sure that people got up in the party room and made pompous contributions, saying, `We won't indulge in this sort of thing'. Fraser said that his Government would not have any sort of a government information unit. But sure enough, it was set up the moment that the going got tough. How often did the previous Government try to justify its policy immediately after making tax cuts? There was advertising for those tax cuts. Hotlines were set up, and all the rest of it, saying, `We will explain your tax cuts to you'. The only time that it did not publicise them was when it took them back. Senator Walters has a sort of rose-tinted glasses approach to the Fraser era. I will not go into a lot of detail; I hate disillusioning people. To Senator Walters, this was a golden age. The reason I admire her so much is that she is one of the very few on the other side of the chamber who will defend those glorious years from 1975 to 1983. The rest of the people here skulk under their seats when this is mentioned. They are too embarrassed to defend that era. So, if Senator Walters does not mind, I will agree to disagree with her. In my view, the attitude of the Liberals or of Fraser at the time is like that of a lot of conservative people to chastity-they talk about it a lot, but they do not practise it much.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a couple of words in response to the comments of the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). First of all, I absolutely and totally support Senator Walters's comments, certainly insofar as they related to the five years between 1975 and 1980 when I was a member of the other place. What she said about our attitude in the party room towards this type of political advertising is absolutely correct. The Minister said that all members of the National Media Liaison Service were not public servants but were ministerial staff.
—The 10 reporters, yes.
—The 10 journalists. What about the 12 clerical support staff?
—I would have to check on that.

—In an answer to a question about the location of members of the NMLS, Senator Newman was told that members of the Service are located in Canberra, each State capital, Darwin and Townsville. Is the Minister saying that all of those people are on the personal staffs of Ministers?
—No, my staff.
—On your staff?
—That is right. That is how they are allocated.
—But, surely, that does not make them ministerial staff?
—They are employed under the same terms and conditions.
—So they are not public servants?
—No.
—Are they part of, or in addition to, the ministerial staff allocation?
—I will come to that.
—You will come to it?

—I was just trying to help Senator Short out by giving a couple of responses so that he could continue his line of questioning. But if he wants me to respond, I will get up each time he asks a question. I just did not want to continue an interchange while I was sitting down.

—If the number of staff is over and above the number of ministerial staff allocated to each Minister, I think it is patent nonsense to try to claim that they are in effect ministerial advisers. If, on the other hand, they are in fact part of the ministerial adviser complement, I do not understand what goes to make up the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS); therefore, it becomes a nonsense term. I would like clarification of that. But I suppose the main point-and I will conclude on this-is that the remarks of the Minister really confirm what I was putting to him-that the NMLS certainly, and a large part of his advertising budget certainly, is used to propagate and promote his political party in government rather than to serve the normal legitimate advertising and information provision services of government. It seems to me that the Minister has just accepted my proposition that on both those scores he is really talking about propaganda units.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always tried to preface my remarks in regard to that. I said, `In the eye of the beholder'. It is Senator Short's perception that they are propaganda units. I have said, and said very bluntly, that it is very hard to determine the difference between government information programs and propaganda. It depends on one's perspective as to whether one regards it as one or the other. What I have said to the honourable senator is that in my view, leaving that doubtful distinction and material aside, a majority of the $27m spent on creative advertising in the media could not possibly fall into that category. I do not think the Defence Reserve advertisement, and most of those sorts of things, could possibly fall into that category. What I am saying is that less than half of the creative advertising could possibly even be argued about in terms of what the honourable senator has put. Let us be quite clear about what I am saying. I am saying that there is no difference between the approach of this Government and that of previous governments. The honourable senator disputes that.
—Yes.

—He can dispute it all he likes. As I said of Senator Walters, I think the honourable senator is looking through rose tinted glasses. If I were looking for blatant examples of political exploitation in advertising, I would go no further than the one Liberal government in this country, that headed by Robin Gray in Tasmania, whose advertising is blatantly political. But one could go north.
—The question is: Do you approve of that or not? I take it from your comments that you don't.
—Senator Stone has just moved north. Maybe the honourable senator has not been there long enough to catch up with a program called Queensland Unlimited.
—That has nothing to do with Commonwealth expenditure.

—No, but it has everything to do with consistency. When has the honourable senator ever criticised that program? When has he criticised the propaganda arm of the Queensland Government, or Queensland Unlimited and the rest of that Government's material and advertising? The advertising engaged in by some of the State governments has been so bad that the Australian Electoral Commission has been able to obtain an injunction to stop these advertisements going on because they have been regarded as political.

SPEECH.PARA: The trouble is that honourable senators opposite have dim memories about their own advertising campaigns. Apparently they cannot remember them. Can Senator Short not remember the 1982 campaign about the 1982-83 Budget in which a family photograph was used in television advertisements? Is that lost from his memory? Senator Stone should remember it-he helped produce the 1982-83 Budget. I do not know whether he helped in the selling of it, but he should at least have the memory of that particular form of advertising.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would ask the Minister to withdraw that insinuation.
—What have I insinuated?
—You said, if I heard you correctly, that you don't know whether I participated in the selling.

—I do not know whether the honourable senator participated in the decision making to sell it. I do know that the honourable senator had a role in constructing the 1982-83 Budget. I cannot say whether it was an influential role or not, but I am fair in saying that. What I said was that I do not know whether he had a role in trying to sell the Budget as a public enterprise.
—Again you have misquoted yourself. A moment ago you corrected yourself by saying that you did not know whether I had a role in deciding to sell it.
—I do not know. I do not know any of these things.
—The two things are quite distinct.
—I asked the honourable senator the direct question.
—For your information, I didn't.

—Good. I ask the honourable senator the direct question: does he have any memory as a private citizen of anyone in government trying to sell it? Has that campaign escaped him? All I can say is that those opposite have very selective memories. That Budget was sold in a very controversial way. I will not go to the relative merits of that Budget or the assumptions that it was built on. The previous Government launched an advertising campaign to sell that Budget, to explain it. That campaign was blatantly political. It was a far worse example than one can find in any of our advertising because the previous Government was aiming at an early election. There were two reasons why it did not hold an early election. One was that the bottom of the harbour scam hit the fence in a big way and the second was that the Prime Minister at the time had a very bad back and could hardly participate in government for about a month.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember these issues well. In Estimates Committee C we explored how much the campaign cost and what advertising agency was responsible for it. It was through those inquiries that we realised that the Government had launched into a post-Budget survey. I think it commissioned George Patterson Pty Ltd to survey the public attitudes to its Budget so that it could base on those attitudes an advertising campaign, paid for by the taxpayer, to promote that Budget. Of course that has always occurred. We have never done anything so blatant; we have never done anything along those lines.

One could hardly say that the Australia made campaign, the acquired immune deficiency syndrome campaign, the drug abuse campaign or the Defence Reserve campaign were overtly political. One example of a political campaign in this sense has been raised today, and that related to the fringe benefits tax. This was one of the worst and most botched advertising campaigns that I have seen. Does Senator Short really think that that one would have won any votes? We did really well at the height of that fringe benefits advertising campaign! If it was-and I do not concede that it was-intended to be a political campaign, it was a pretty incompetent one.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is irrelevant.

—It is not irrelevant. I am saying that the honourable senator has accused the Government of running campaigns, not as information programs to disseminate information but for just political propaganda purposes. He brought up one example. I have also brought up the example of 1982 to show that his belief that the Liberal Party never indulged in such activities is gross rubbish.
—Can you answer my question on the NMLS staff?

—My understanding, in terms of the NMLS staff, is that those journalists are not public servants. They are hired on the same terms and conditions as a parliamentary or ministerial staffer would be. For reasons of logic, they come on to my staff as such, although I do not have day to day direction of them. That is done by the Director, Mr Colin Parks.
—Are they part of the ministerial staff establishment or are they additional to it?

—I guess it depends on where one draws the line on the ministerial staff establishment. I would imagine that they would be considered as an overall part of it, the upper limits of which were raised because of the expansion of the Ministry. However, I will check on that and get some details for the honourable senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I raised the matter of the Parliament House Construction Authority the Minister for Home Affairs left the chamber because, he said later, he had heard it all before. I wish to raise with him the question I raised in his absence because it was not responded to. I intend to pursue it a little further. At the Estimates Committee E meeting certain questions were asked of the Parliament House Construction Authority. I said, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the construction manager's response to the unions' claim for severance pay in 1983-84 was that the claim should be pursued through the Arbitration Commission and the claim would be resisted.

I think that honourable senators will recall that the Minister for Industrial Relations has made similar remarks. I then pointed out that that was at odds with the Auditor-General's report, which stated that the Authority accepted liability for a cost to contractors of about $6.5m-not an insignificant amount-because the Construction Manager may have improperly given unions reason to believe that a severance pay scheme might be favourably considered as part of the renegotiation of the site agreement. I then asked the Authority to explain the anomaly between its view and that of the Auditor-General. Mr Peatey responded:
It is obviously an option of the Auditor-General; it is not an opinion the Authority shared.
In a letter dated 6 November to Senator Aulich, the Chairman of Estimates Committee E, the Auditor-General referred to the question and answer and said:

The question of whether the Authority accepted that liability is not one of opinion, but of fact. The Authority received legal advice at the time which indicated that the CM failed to discharge properly its duty to manage industrial matters and that the contractors would be entitled to reimbursement by the Authority of extra costs incurred. After considering the advice, the Authority informed the CM:
``formal agreement has now been obtained to accept valid claims from contractors which flow from events to the recent site stoppage on severance pay''.

It is apparent from that that, deliberately or otherwise-I am not too sure-the Parliament House Construction Authority misled us in the answer because it knew that it had a legal opinion on the matter. The Auditor-General's report stated:
Audit remains concerned that a decision not to pursue recovery action was made without seeking further legal advice specifically in respect of the Authority's legal position.

There is an anomaly in that the Auditor-General made some statements and the Construction Authority, in response to a question from me, said that it was simply the Auditor-General's opinion. Yet subsequently we find that it had a legal opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that the legal opinion is not quite as decisive as Senator Parer has been led to believe-that there was sufficient evidence to require the Parliament House Construction Authority to pay the claims of contractors but not sufficient evidence to charge the Construction Manager with misconduct and seek to recover costs from the Construction Manager. I think that is the position. What we are saying is that we do not think that the legal advice is quite as decisive as the honourable senator may have been led to believe in terms of the certainty of recovery of any money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a further point before moving on. The Minister may like to answer a few questions together. The Minister used the term `led to believe', but I was referring to something contained in the Auditor-General's report. I am referring to the fact that something was wrong with the management of the Construction Authority. The Auditor-General went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a decision not to pursue recovery action apparently was made without seeking further legal advice . . .

We could not get a satisfactory answer to that. I think the point being made was that the Construction Authority wiped it off by saying that that was the Auditor-General's opinion and the Authority did not share it. The Minister who attended the meeting of Estimates Committee E-the Minister for Home Affairs-is at the table. He would have realised at that meeting that a lot of conflicting information was given to us by the Construction Authority and confusion reigned. At one stage I asked the Construction Authority whether the Minister for Industrial Relations, in keeping with his remarks that any industrial agreements should be in terms of the Government's 1984 agreement, had been informed and I was told that he had not. When Senator Walters asked the same question she was told that he had been informed. When I questioned Mr Peatey about that he said that he had been informed, but after the event. I would like some clarification on that. When was the Minister informed? That is a fairly important factor. The Minister issued Press releases and made statements in the other place that under no circumstances would he agree to anything that was outside the site agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that the Minister was told about these things two or three days after the Construction Manager told the Authority. I will repeat that: to the best of my knowledge, the Minister was informed of those events two to three days after the Construction Manager informed the Authority.

—The strike to which I refer was the plumbers' strike. It went on for some weeks and a $500 payout was made to get them back to work. The point which was made to me by the Parliament House Construction Authority during questioning and which I found very difficult to believe was that, although the strike was holding up work at the new Parliament House and everyone was very concerned about it, the Authority did not know anything about the matter. I find it absolutely impossible to believe, given that a strike had been going on for a month and the whole project was grinding to a halt, that there were not almost daily or hourly discussions between the Construction Manager and the Parliament House Construction Authority. Yet I am told-I find it incredible; in fact, I do not believe it-that the Parliament House Construction Authority did not know about it until the deal was done. I ask whether there was any discussion about it. I do not believe that that decision was made. If it was, there was something very seriously wrong with the management of the Parliament House Construction Authority.

—I am informed that the Parliament House Construction Authority did not know, but it did know that the matter was going to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The matter went to the Arbitration Commission and the agreement between the employers and employees was ratified. The $500 was paid by employers to employees-this is at least in terms of the Arbitration Commission decision-for meeting times associated with the dispute to promote commitment to the project for at least 26 weeks. The Construction Manager, as superintendent of the contract, was required to examine the entitlements of constructors. The Construction Manager is not required under the contract to seek approval of his principal, that is, the Parliament House Construction Authority. So it appears that the sequence of events is: the Authority knew the matter was going to the Arbitration Commission but was not consulted or told about the possible terms of settlement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise another point because it shows that something was terribly amiss in the whole period. I know it is water under the bridge, but I think these things are very important. The new Parliament House is a structure which, I admit, people will admire and enjoy for many years to come. But it seemed to me that there was a total and utter lack of control. There was an attitude there that it did not matter; that whatever had to be spent to complete the job would be spent-so there was an absence of budgets. But the Construction Manager himself is on record as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I think we realise the situation we were in. It was no good throwing the code of conduct around in a situation where there were so many breaches to it that you would virtually have to go and close the industry up.

Okay, that could be a reason for making the settlement, and I do not object to that. It could be a reason for saving money. But the point is that it makes a mockery of repeated statements by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) himself and, more recently, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) that the Government would not give in to industrial blackmail in order to get the job finished on time. That leads me to another question I asked and the answer I got. I asked a question as to the number of working days lost through industrial disputation from September 1985 through to the present. I will give an abbreviated version of the answer I got because I read it out in some detail in the Minister's absence:

. . . a formula was agreed between the Authority, the Departments of Finance and Administrative Services . . . Part of that formula provides an assessment of ``project days'' lost through disputes . . . In the period September 1985 to September 1987-
two years-
. . . the assessed project days lost was 133.5, or an average of 5.6 days per month.

In other words, it was a week per month for two years-every month for two years. The response said that this included stoppages for a whole host of reasons including health and safety. I think it can be safely anticipated, in view of the past record, that in the closing stages of construction unreasonable demands, and hence disputes, will escalate. The question I ask is: What contingency plans does the Authority or the Government have to handle such a situation, in view of its having a nominated opening date? Or will the Authority just pay up at taxpayers' expense?

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of Senator Parer's speech was debate. He will not expect me to respond to all of that.
—Just the last bit.

—In response to the last point: to my knowledge there is no change in Government policy from the Cabinet decision that then resulted in a statement made by Mr West in the other place and put down here by me; that the Government's attitude is that the project, whilst it is highly desirable that it be finished, will not be finished with a gun being held at our head industrially. There are always problems with redundancy when a massive project such as this is closed. But all this will have to be done within the normal guidelines and ratified by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If that is not the case, the Government will stand firm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to my question, `When can we expect to see the annual report for 1986-87?', Mr Fowler told Senate Estimates Committee E-this is shown on page 206 of the Hansard-that:

SPEECH.PARA: The report for the Authority for that year will be available in six weeks time.

That was on 28 October. I wonder now whether this report will be tabled on 9 December, which is, I think, six weeks from that date, when the Senate will still be sitting. Does this date still hold, in view of the delay involved in auditing the accounts of the Parliament House Construction Authority? I raise that matter in the context of a letter that the Auditor-General wrote to the Chairman of Estimates Committee E relating to the evidence given on this matter at the Senate Estimates Committee hearing. The Auditor-General said:

Responses to Senator Michael Baume's questions about the availability of the Authority's annual report were to the effect that the Authority had to await the Auditor-General's report on its financial statements, which had been completed to the satisfaction of the Authority and submitted to the Audit Office early in September this year. The responses-
that is, the responses from the Authority-
could imply that, in some significant degree, the Auditor-General was responsible for delay in the completion of the Authority's annual report.

The factual position is that, in accordance with normal practice, unsigned draft financial statements and related documents were submitted by the Authority early in September at which time the Audit Office commenced examination of the draft statements. These are to be discussed at a meeting with the Authority during the week commencing 9 November.
By the way, this letter was written on 10 November. It continued:

As at the date of this letter the Audit Office is still awaiting a reply to a letter of 30 September 1987 to the Authority concerning a number of matters, relevant to the Authority's financial statements.
I want to stress the next bit:

Audit cannot proceed with its task until the Authority provides adequate replies on these matters, and cannot subsequently conclude the audit until the Authority provides signed final financial statements.

That is an extract from what I understand to be an unsolicited letter from the Auditor-General to the Chairman of Estimates Committee E. I ask: What is the state of play with last year's annual report?

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears to be the case that the annual report will probably not arrive on 9 December. It cannot go to the printer until there is a certification from the Auditor-General. It is very hard for me to arbitrate between the Auditor-General and the Parliament House Construction Authority on where substantial delays have occurred. But it cannot be printed until that certification is supplied by the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General has written to the Committee and put certain views to it. The Parliament House Construction Authority does not believe it has been dragging the chain in providing material to the Auditor-General. It is a case where I find it very hard to judge exactly where the delays have been.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I imagine that the consequence of that answer is that we will not see this annual report until we meet in February, which was the situation with the latest annual report-a situation which the Minister said was, and I think all the Senate regards as, very unsatisfactory. In the report of Estimates Committee E to the Parliament there is the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report of the Parliament House Construction Authority for the year 1986-87 was not available for the Committee before, or during, the estimates hearings. It is likely that the report will not be tabled until February 1988.
The Committee was right. It continued:

Senate Estimates Committees have reported in the past that annual reports should be available for use by the Committee during the estimates hearings and appropriate efforts should be made by all of those responsible for the production and publication of reports to ensure that this occurs.
I would now like to move to the rest of the letter from the Auditor-General to Estimates Committee E which concerns me. This extract reads as follows:
Senator Michael Baume referred to the observation in the audit report-
that is the efficiency audit report of the Auditor-General into the Authority-

that the Chairman has said that the Joint Committee and parliamentary departments had been slow to address the question of operations and maintenance costs. In response Mr Peatey said, among other things, that the Authority had some concern as to when the Chairman expressed that point of view.
The Chairman made that comment in his letter of 27 March 1987 to the Auditor-General. The comment is reproduced at the last paragraph on page 3 of Appendix B to the Auditor-General's report.

Senator Michael Baume asked who had suggested that the Architect's continued pursuit of excellence was becoming costly and that delayed decisions were having a detrimental effect on the project. In response Mr Peatey attributed that view to the McCain report.

It would appear that Senator Baume's question related to paragraphs 4.5.21 and 4.5.22, page 28, of the efficiency audit report. The comments referred to there were made by Mr Peatey in a report to a meeting of the Authority in March 1986.
I read those remarks into the record because the responses given to the Senate Estimates Committee bore correcting.

I shall deal now with some other specific matters emerging from written responses by the Parliament House Construction Authority to Senate Estimates Committee E relating to matters that could not be answered at the time. I would like to note that there was considerable discussion on whether or not there had been effective cost control of the Parliament House Construction Authority before the appointment in mid-1986, as I recall it, of a cost control arrangement. The written response from the Authority now demonstrates that almost $240m worth of construction work continued under a situation which the Parliament House Construction Authority itself has designated as unsatisfactory in relation to cost control, in that it says that there was not an effective cost control system.

I would also like to raise another matter-an answer to a question that I asked about an apparent disagreement about the Construction Manager's fee. In this response, the Construction Authority said that it was awaiting an opinion from Queen's Counsel (QC) who had been briefed by the Australian Government Solicitor on the Construction Authority's behalf. The minimum fee, about which there is no disagreement, is in the order of $21.1m. The maximum is represented by the Construction Manager to the Authority at current prices as $26.1m. Clearly, $5m is in dispute. In the Authority's view, there are reasonable grounds for some increase on the undisputed minimum of $21.1m, but the Authority wishes to reserve its position in this regard pending further legal advice. I simply ask the Minister whether that advice has been received, and what the situation is with this dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wednesday next week.
—That is when the response from the QC is expected?
—Yes.

—Thank you. The next matter I want to raise is the question of frequent reporting of the cost of the new Parliament House. I said that I have not seen these frequent reports and I was assured that there had been some. I find that I was either partly right or partly wrong, depending on whether I am an optimist or a pessimist. I notice that, over the crucial time, when there were huge rises, there was a gap of two years in the figures in the Press releases that I have received. I have a Press release dated 24 August 1983, revealing that the updated figure for the building is $421.2m. The 1984 statement that I have does not have an updated figure and the next one I have, in the documents tabled by the Authority, is 1985, when the figure had gone up from $421m to $894m. I wonder whether that was the period when there was, as the Auditor-General has pointed out, some concern and confusion almost, between the Minister and the Authority about what costs were and what sort of reporting was going on.

SPEECH.PARA: I come now to a question that concerned the Minister himself in Senate Estimates, and that was the $32m fees associated with a cost item of $55m, making up a total contingency fee of $87m. I must say that the explanation that I have got does not clear that up to my satisfaction, and I would be interested to see whether it clears it up to the Minister's satisfaction. We are told that the consultants' fees of $32m, relate to the $149m total-that is, $87m contingency and $62m of additional requirements. This concerns me considerably because it means that the $32m relates to a very small amount of work being done. I refer the Minister to the fact that the $62m which makes up part of that $149m includes $9m of professional fees anyway, and I would be astounded if the consultants' fees would be fees on top of professional fees. That $62m in terms of work done is something like $53m and the other components seem, when that is taken off, to suggest that something like $94m of work was done and fees charged were about $32m, so something like a quarter of it involved professional fees.

I may have done my sums wrongly at the time, but that seems to me to be a pretty small amount. What one has to do is take off from the $149m the $32m for consultants' fees and $9m of professional fees to see what the consultants' fee is in relation to actual work done. If that is the sort of rate, it seems to me to be an extraordinary rate for consultants' fees, and it requires an explanation.

I would also be grateful if the Minister could outline to me what is the definition of the cost of the industrial disputation. What is included in the cost of industrial disputation of $41.5m that has been given as the impact of industrial disputation on this project? As far as I am concerned, $41.5m seems to be a ludicrously small amount in terms of the real cost to this project, and unless there is some curious definition which excludes the consequences of, for example, extending contracts, deferring contracts and all those other on-costs such as delays in completing things that involve a significant cost content, I cannot see how one could possibly have only $41.5m as the industrial disputation cost on this $1,000m project.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Baume's final supposition about $32m being subtracted from $149m to get the end result is right. I have been wading through it here too. It may help him to know that when we are talking about the preliminary costs, we are not just talking about design. We are talking about getting cranes on site, security and a whole range of factors. It works out at about 30 per cent, which is the normal preparation cost for any other commercial site. To laymen like Senator Baume and myself that seems a very high figure. The 30 per cent seems to be a very high element of the cost. I am told that it is normal practice.

—I must say that I am intrigued that the cost of getting those things on site should be related to a fee to be paid to the Construction Manager. How that is so really escapes me. I cannot see that that is a reality. I can see that the preliminary costs are related to the amount of $149m. If the Minister is saying that the Construction Manager's fee includes various preliminary costs related to bringing in cranes and so on, I can understand that. However, I certainly do not understand how, in the normal terms and meaning of the word `fee', that is a fee simply to the Construction Manager.

—Once it was decided to extend the new Parliament House-a whole range of extra rooms was added to it when Parliament was expanded-the Construction Manager was entitled to a 4 per cent additional fee in relation to those particular areas. I think that explains why he received the extra amount of money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the Minister could address himself to what I understand is a demarcation dispute on the new Parliament House site at the moment. The last paragraph of an answer given to Senator Short states:

SPEECH.PARA: The reference in the Authority response to the Efficiency Audit Report to savings from a close working relationship with Joint House Department applies to the short term only. The Joint House Department Staff are working with the Authority's Construction Manager up to and during the handover phase to reduce the costs of the Construction Manager's staff and to provide operating experience to Joint House Department staff in the new building. The Authority considers that this arrangement has resulted in overall savings to the Commonwealth.

I must say that I think that is an eminently sensible proposal. I only wish that it had worked as outlined. As I understand it, there have been some union standover tactics involved in this. Members of the Joint House Department staff who, in fact, have gone up to the Parliament House site to do this co-operative work have been forced to join an additional union, on top of the union they belong to here, because they have been told that if they do not join that union they will be denied employment. I thought that in fact there had been a statement by a commissioner of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to the effect that no one would be forced to join another union if he was already involved in a union.

I am asking these questions because those events took place only last week. In fact, I believe it is vital that this sort of on-site co-operation should take place in as many areas as possible to reduce the running costs and the costs of transition when we move to the new Parliament House. As it is, moving into the new Parliament House will involve multi-millions of dollars. Anything that can be done, as this sensible procedure was attempted to be done, should, I believe, be embraced by everyone involved.

I think that something has to be done about instructing unions that they cannot stand over members of other unions. We cannot run the risk of having demarcation disputes in this matter. I understand that the union involved on the site says that it is a convention that people who are involved in these activities on building sites should be members of this particular union. Whether that convention applies or not, as I said, I understand that there is a specific ruling against this in a recent decision handed down by the conciliation and arbitration commissioner that no unionist should be forced to join another union when, on moving to a new place of employment, he continues to do exactly the same job as he had been doing as a member of his own union.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 November, on motion by Senator Tate:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 contains a number of eminently worthwhile improvements and refinements to a package of legislation-in particular, the Christmas Island Act, the Crimes Act, the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act, the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act, the Proceeds of Crimes Act and the Transfer of Prisoners Act. I think it is only proper to say that the Government has acted expeditiously in relation to the Christmas Island Act, perhaps too expeditiously as it has transpired because a further amendment will need to be moved in the Committee stage. I indicate that we will not be opposing that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, we support the restoration of trial by jury in relation to Christmas Island. We believe that there are very real problems when only 300 people on that island speak English. Therefore, it can certainly become necessary for trails to be held on the mainland of Australia. Thus, we support moves to enable the court to adjourn to take evidence on Christmas Island or to conduct trials on the mainland, presumably in Perth.

The amendments to the Crimes Act embrace various provisions that basically tighten up a number of escape arrangements, that make the search warrant provision much more flexible, that put beyond doubt certain powers in relation to police officers breaking internal doors and receptacles in the execution of a warrant and that allow for warrants to be issued up to 72 hours before use. That last provision is especially necessary where information might be received that drugs are likely to be at a particular place at a particular time. It enables the operational arrangements to be put in place so that there is not a last minute dash to ensure that police are able to gain access to the premises. Therefore, those provisions are certainly reasonable.

The Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act tidies up some of the definitional provisions because of the problems that arise in relation to foreign countries. A definition of `foreign State' is substituted to remove doubts about the scope of the previous definition and to ensure that the Act proscribes hostile activity engaged in in places outside Australia, irrespective of whether the place is within a particular political area. This aspect of the Bill fills a gap whereby it is presently not an offence for an Australian to become involved in mercenary activities, per se, in a foreign State. The Bill does that by extending the definition of `hostile activities' to cover acts done for the purpose of engaging in armed hostilities in the foreign State.

It also very importantly protects people who provide humanitarian assistance to persons in other countries. Lest there by any doubt that they might be at risk of aiding and abetting foreign mercenaries or intervening in the political affairs of another State, their acts of good neighbourliness are protected. We therefore have no problems with that aspect of the Bill. So far as the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act is concerned, again several problems have arisen in relation to prosecutions brought against several persons because of the Status of the internationally-protected person. This Bill will extend the number and types of offences for which a person might be prosecuted, arising out of the destruction of or damage to the property of an internationally-protected person. The use of fire or explosives will attract a much higher penalty. In general, the question of whether a person is an internationally-protected person is made an object of assessment, rather than simply the subject of the intention or understanding of the accused person. Similarly, the amendment to increase the penalties for attacks on the property of internationally-protected persons is one we would support.

The Proceeds of Crime Act is in a slightly different category. The provisions are designed to ensure that the statutory forfeiture provisions extend to all proceeds of crime over which criminals exercise effective control, not simply those where they are legally entitled to the proceeds. It does away with demarcation disputes about the difference between legal and equitable title to goods. It also precludes arguments that a forfeiture order cannot apply to property other than that derived from the offence for which the criminal has been convicted. Again, widening the search and seizure powers seems to be an eminently sensible proposition. One matter we will deal with in the committee stage relates to the date of operation of this aspect of the Bill. We simply take the view that it should come into effect at the time of this Bill's passage and not be dated back to the Proceeds of Crime Bill. We also support the amendments to the Transfer of Prisoners Act. In conclusion, there will be several amendments moved in the committee stage but, in principle, we support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the Crimes Legislation (Amendment) Bill. As the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) pointed out in his second reading speech, this is part of the Government's range of legislation which is designed to improve the capacity of the law in its fight against crime. Australia has long suffered from serious defects in its approach to crime, particularly with regard to organised crime. It is only in recent times that we have managed to put together a more effective approach than was the case in the past. The Democrats have taken issue from time to time with certain aspects of the Government's proposals, but in general we have applauded the Government's initiatives in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: We take a similar view with this legislation which, as the Minister noted, is not quite as grand in scope as earlier legislation but nevertheless is important. I do not intend going through the various items in this legislation although I must admit I am very tempted to do so with regard to the amendments on the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, considering the events taking place in Queensland at present. However, due to the shortage of time I will refrain.

One of the items I would like to refer to is the amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act that Senator Alston referred to. This is an important area. It was understood when the legislation on the proceeds of crime passed this chamber that there would need to be modifications. These modifications have come forward very rapidly as the law has been tested in the courts. The Democrats have long held that this area ought to be part of the armory of government. This process has worked effectively and these amendments are sensible and provide additional powers so that people who profit by crime will have to pay back those proceeds. There is no way the community can be compensated in full for the activities of criminals but this goes a long way to redressing the balance with regard to criminals and the general community. For that reason we support the legislation the Government has introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Being beside myself with excitement at the prospect of getting a Bill through the Senate this week, I do not want to do anything to prejudice that prospect. So I thank Senator Macklin and Senator Alston for their support for this measure and wish the Bill a speedy passage.

I table two explanatory memoranda to the amendments. I also seek leave to have two explanatory statements incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statements read as follows-

The Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in Queensland has sought the urgent assistance of the Commonwealth in a number of areas. The Government believes that there is a genuine public interest, including from a Commonwealth perspective in the fight against organized crime, in the Commonwealth providing all the assistance it properly can to the Fitzgerald Commission. The inquiry involves the integrity of a State Police Force that is involved, in conjunction with police forces of the Commonwealth, the other States and the Northern Territory in a number of common police services including the ABCI. The NCA has also had to rely on the services of the Queensland Police Force. Accordingly the Commonwealth has a real interest in ensuring that the Inquiry is not impeded. The amendments which I propose to move on behalf of the Government, which were foreshadowed by the Minister for Justice on 24 November, will allow the Commonwealth to provide the assistance sought by the Fitzgerald Commission.

Parts VA and VB amend taxation laws to enable the Fitzgerald Commission to have access to taxation information on the same basis, and subject to the same restrictions on further disclosure of the information that applies to taxation information disclosed to a Commonwealth Royal Commission, with the exception that the Commissioner may disclose the information to State law enforcement agencies as well as to Commonwealth agencies and the information may be used in evidence in certain proceedings to restrain dealings in, and confiscate, proceeds of crime under State and Commonwealth law.

Part VIA amends the Royal Commissions Act 1902 to insert a new section 7D which prevents answers given by a witness to the Fitzgerald Commission from being used in evidence against the witness in Commonwealth criminal or civil proceedings. The Act already prevents the use of evidence given before a Commonwealth Royal Commission in subsequent civil or criminal proceedings.

The Queensland Commissions of Inquiry Act 1950 also precludes the use of evidence given before a Commission in subsequent civil or criminal proceedings. The Commonwealth provision is intended to supplement the Queensland provisions in relation to Commonwealth proceedings to ensure that persons cannot refuse to answer questions before the Commission on the basis of inadequate protection against self-incrimination.

Part VIB and VIC amend telecommunications interception legislation to enable certain types of information obtained as a result of interceptions of telecommunications to be given to Commissioner Fitzgerald, and for evidence to be given to the Fitzgerald Inquiry in relation to such information. The amendments will permit further use of such information for the purposes of investigating serious offences and any resulting prosecutions. The amendments will also enable the Australian Federal Police to continue to be able to obtain information obtained as a result of lawful interceptions, for a purpose connected with the investigation of serious offences. Under the Act as it now stands, this information is available to the AFP. As foreshadowed by the Minister for Justice on 5 November in his concluding remarks when introducing this Bill, further amendments being made to the Act will enable evidence to be given, in proceedings begun before the commencement of section 21 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act 1987, of information obtained by interceptions carried out before the commencement of that section whether or not in contravention of the Act. These amendments will not affect a court's discretion whether or not to admit illegally obtained evidence.
I present a supplementary Explanatory Memorandum and Commend the amendments to the Senate.

As a consequence of the decision of His Honour Mr Justice Gallop on 16 November 1987 not to proceed with the trial of two persons charged with murder on Christmas Island but, when legislation permits, to remove the trial to the mainland, the Government considers it expedient to amend the Bill now before the Parliament to enable His Honour to make such an order at a sitting of the Court on the mainland.

Proposed new section 11aa (2) would require the Court to sit on Christmas Island for the sole purpose of ordering the removal of the trial. There is no legal mechanism for the accused to be brought to the mainland for the purpose of ordering the removal of the trial. Legal representatives of both accused have made formal applications to the Court for the removal of the trial.

In the circumstances as they have developed, the most appropriate course is to amend the Bill to enable the orders to be made without the need for the Judge and all persons associated with the trial to return to Christmas Island.
I present a supplementary Explanatory Memorandum and commend the amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

On 24 February last the Attorney-General advised the Parliament that where there is evidence of serious war crimes being committed during World War 2 and there being no punishment of the offenders, then the Government has a duty to ensure that justice is done. No matter how long since the events in question have passed. Accordingly, this Bill is designed to ensure that any serious criminal activities committed in the course of World War 2, the commission of which is established beyond a reasonable doubt, by persons who are now residents or citizens of Australia, will not go unpunished.

The Bill is confined in its operation to the period of hostilities known as World War 2 and provides that certain criminal acts done during that period, whether in or out of Australia, which were during that period offences under a law in a part of Australia, are serious crimes for the purposes of the Bill. It goes on to provide that where a serious crime was committed in the course of the hostilities, in the course of an occupation of territory or, more generally, for the purposes of the war, then, subject to certain exceptions it is a war crime punishable under the Bill by prosecution in an Australian court.

The scheme therefore involves the hypothetical transfer of the act alleged to constitute the offence from outside Australia to some part of Australia. Most of the serious offences described in the Bill are such as are to be found in all Australian jurisdictions, so that it will not be possible for an offence to exist in relation to one jurisdiction but not another. However, deportation and internment in death camps and slave labour camps are serious crimes by virtue of an express provision to that effect. A serious crime will also be a war crime if committed in the course of political, racial or religious persecution or with intent to destroy, wholly or partially, a national, ethnic, racial or religious group.

The types of crimes which will always be of concern, no matter how long ago they were committed, include participation in police or so-called `security units', whether or not German controlled, which deported, ill-treated or murdered persons on racial or political grounds; and participation as guards or administrators in German-established death camps or similar places at which large numbers of persons were murdered or ill-treated.

The involvement of secondary parties in such activity either by attempting, aiding or abetting, or by being knowingly involved in the activity, is also addressed in the Bill. The exemption provided under sub-section 7 (2) will exclude the operation of the provision with respect to secondary parties whose involvement is incidental or remote.

The provisions concerning deportation to and internment in death camps and slave labour camps reflect the Government's concern that the Bill should extend to persons in national or local puppet Governments under Nazi direction at an executive level who had direct responsibility for the deportation, ill-treatment or murder of persons on racial or political grounds. The intention is to address crimes committed during the war at the `municipal' level, involving Nazi-controlled or influenced national or local puppet Governments, or persons acting pursuant to, for example, an anti-semitic policy, or on behalf of a puppet regime.

A war crime is to be an indictable offence if committed within the relevant period, irrespective of whether it was committed inside or outside Australia or whether it was committed by a person acting as an individual or as a member of an organisation. The words `member of an organisation' are intended to preclude a person distributing blame away from himself or herself by virtue of membership alone.

In the interest of justices and impartiality, the Bill makes no special provision in relation to persons who will be liable under it (beyond requiring residency or citizenship) or in relation to the standards and procedures adopted in dealing with alleged offences.

No distinction is drawn, for example, between members of the Allied or Axis forces, or between persons of different races or origin. Consistent with the Government's even-handed policy, the Bill applies to any person who commits a war crime as defined. Lest there be any confusion, the Bill specifically provides a defence where the act alleged to constitute the offence was permitted by the laws of war and was not under international law, a crime against humanity.

Although the Bill deals with events occurring over 45 years ago, no special provision has been made with a view to changing the normal rules governing evidence and procedure (including the operation of procedures under the Evidence Act 1905 for the obtaining of evidence overseas in criminal cases). Trials will be conducted in the ordinary courts of the States and internal Territories and, as in all criminal cases, the presumption of innocence will have full force and effect.

Any evidence sought to be adduced can be fully tested by defence counsel. The question of weight to be attached to any evidence will be a matter for the trial jury and the Government has complete confidence in the ability of our courts and the jury system to deal fairly and responsibly with such matters.

No person will be deported to any country on the basis of a simple allegation that the person has committed a war crime. Australia must, of course, honour its obligations under extradition treaties but the intention is that Australian citizens and residents accused of war crimes be dealt with in this country and this course is open under the treaties.

Customary International Law recognises the acts or omissions addressed in the Bill as war crimes. It has long provided for criminal responsibility to be imposed on persons committing the acts or omissions dealt with by the Bill, and for their punishment. The Bill therefore extends to Australian courts jurisdiction to try and punish crimes recognised at international law as war crimes. The Bill does not create offences retrospectively-the offences described in the Bill have existed for many years and many of them are cognizable by military courts under the War Crimes Act as it presently stands.

As I have explained, the basic scheme contained in the Bill for the prosecution of persons alleged to have committed war crimes during World War 2 involves selecting the most serious criminal acts encompassed within international law relating to war crimes and making them triable in our criminal courts in accordance with the normal rules, procedures and standards applying to our criminal trials. The Government believes that this approach provides the most comprehensive and efficacious answer yet devised anywhere in the world to the difficulties of prosecuting alleged war criminals in a jurisdiction other than that of the place where the alleged crimes were committed.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
