TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the interruption of this debate for the passage of a fairly urgent Bill, Senator Michael Baume raised a few questions in terms of demarcation disputes at the new Parliament House site. I have been given the following information: There are no union membership problems with operation and maintenance staff. We think Senator Baume may be referring to the security staff. Twenty parliamentary security staff are now on site. Of those, 16 were members of the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia, four were members of the Australian Public Service Association and four became members of the Miscellaneous Workers Union in order to be allowed on site. I am informed that they did this of their own volition. I understand that they also chose to remain members of the APSA. No one encourages demarcation disputes of any nature, and that is why in the broad and the long term we are trying to bring about as many union amalgamations as possible. We are also in a situation of uncertainty as to when the status of the site is to be transferred from a building site to a parliamentary site. These sorts of problems sometimes interrupt us. I hope that that answers at least the first series of questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —While thanking the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) for his answer, I must express my regret that the sort of pressure that was brought to bear on these members of the Australian Public Service Association was sufficiently strong to force them to join a second union when there seems to have been no moral or legal requirement that they do so. I take the Minister's point that one would rather have a quiet life in these matters. I certainly do not want to ferment a major issue about this. All I want to say is that I think it is very bad indeed that this principle has been allowed to triumph. I think it is wrong that one union has been able effectively to force members of another union to become members of two unions when they are doing exactly the same job at the new Parliament House site as they were doing here in the security area.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I am glad that cool heads have avoided what otherwise could have been a difficult industrial situation. It seems to me that something should be done, particularly in the context of what I understand to be a Conciliation and Arbitration Commissioner's determination that it is wrong to require a member of one union to join another simply because of a move in that person's place of work while he is doing exactly the same job. It seems to be an incredibly bad principle which, unfortunately, has been allowed to triumph. I just hope that the Parliament itself, the Parliament House Construction Authority or whoever is responsible for the employees concerned-I understand that they are employees of the Joint House Department-have had no part in this situation. Dealing with union power on that site, I now turn to the response to the following question asked by Senator Parer:
What would be the total cost, direct and indirect, of those people?
That is, the union delegates on the Parliament House site. The written answer to that, which we received recently, said:
Part of the site agreement reached in May 1984-
the site agreement which cost the employer, in other words, the Australian taxpayer, a fair amount of money, because there were benefits to the unions along with responsibilities to the unions-
covered the provision of full time union delegates for the site at a ratio of 1 delegate to cover approximately 250 workers, to a maximum of 8 full time paid delegates.
The number of paid full time delegates has varied in accordance with numbers of workers and contractors on site. Currently there are the equivalent of 7.5 paid full time delegates.
This is the bit that interests me:
The direct cost is $850 per week per delegate, to a maximum of $353,600 per annum.

That means that current expenditure is about $330,000 per annum. That is, the employers are paying the wages of union delegates who do not, as I understand it, do normal work; they do union work. The reply continues:

While there are no indirect costs, there are indirect savings. These result from the structure which channels potential disputes from shop stewards to delegates, thereby enabling the resolution of issues before they can escalate.

We will deal with whether or not they have escalated in a minute. The point I would like to make is in the context of a recent Willesee program in which a union official who operates on that site was given a series of free kicks at me and in which my responses were edited out. For interest's sake I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that $850 a week works out at about $44,200 a year, slightly less than a member of this place earns as his salary. Maybe this is an appropriate judgment on the relative merits of parliamentarians as against union delegates whose wages are paid for by the employer-in other words, the Australian public-or maybe it suggests a lot of other things, such as that parliamentarians' salaries are inadequate compared to the cost of such a delegate. If that delegate works the award hours he is being paid at roughly twice the hourly rate of most members of this chamber-and he is being paid that by the people of Australia. If I have a touch of resentment about it I guess it shows a human frailty but I find it objectionable that union delegates or union representatives on that site have the hide to complain about the wages of parliamentarians. There are eight of them with a direct cost of $850 a week or, as I said, an annual rate of $44,200 each, I think it works out at.

I have to have reservations about the way the system has worked. The site agreement in 1984 was aimed at creating a set of rules within which the building was supposed to be built and the unions were supposed to behave. In Senate Estimates Committee E, I asked whether it was possible to give an indication of the extent to which the list of disputes given to Senator Margaret Reid involved disputes that were contrary to the spirit of the November 1983 arrangement which then became the 1984 terms of employment. The answer was that the site agreement was formally settled in May 1984 and the majority of disputes recorded on site involved industry-wide stoppages and thus were outside the agreement. Of the disputes that were confined to the new Parliament House site only, many related to the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF) efforts to maintain its ascendancy and were outside the spirit of the agreement. A list was provided of the disputes confined to the new Parliament House site assessed as being outside the spirit of the 1984 agreement.

I will quickly rip through the list as it is fairly long. As was explained, back in September 1985 the stoppages basically involved the BLF. In fact, in each month listed until May 1986 all the disputes involved the BLF. For example, one was a stoppage in support of Australian Capital Territory nurses. In view of the current dispute in a nursing home in Canberra it is probably just as well that the BLF is not still on site. In May 1986 there was an Electrical Trades Union (ETU) ban concerning temporary power, which was claimed to be a safety issue. In June 1986 there were miscellaneous minor disputes. In July 1986 there were ETU bans on non-ticketed apprentices. There was a plumbers and gasfitters union strike on subcontracting. There was an ETU and Operative Painters and Decorators Union stoppage on contractual agreements. The answer noted that this period coincided with BLF deregistration with many unions vying to fill the perceived gap in the industry. Then there were ETU and Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association stoppages, a sprinkler fitters dispute, an all union stoppage, an ETU stoppage, another ETU stoppage and so on.

Senator Parer had also asked whether the Authority could provide a list of any stoppages resulting from health and safety issues. In this period we have had only six stoppages which have related to health and safety issues. In other words, all these other disputes we have been looking at were clearly breaching the agreement. Apart from the question of whether these health and safety issues were genuine-I am in no position to be able to judge that-what concerns me immensely is that there has been a clear cost to the construction of this building emerging out of industrial disputation which was an uncomplicated and unquestionable breach of arrangements made. There appears to be no capacity to impose any kind of sanction and apparently no penalties were involved in breaching this kind of agreement. The Minister may be able to assist me in this. In other words, the unions get the benefit of the deal but do not have to put up with its inconvenience if it involves restraint on their industrial action. The list I have read from seems to indicate that apart from the BLF there have been unions that have been prepared to have industrial disputation in the face of that commitment. I do not know whether that is above the normal sort of thing one expects at building sites where this kind of deal has been reached. However, I think the public ought to be aware, since it is paying the bill, of this problem.

I would like to raise one other question. We dealt earlier with another disagreement between the Auditor-General and the Parliament House Construction Authority on its annual report. We heard that we would not be getting that report until at least February. Could we be told whether this is a major or a minor dispute? What is the substance of the dispute and how far is it from resolution?

—The responsibility for tabling what Senator Walters has asked for does not lie with the Attorney-General's Department; it lies with another department. Normally, that would be infinitely bad news for Senator Walters, because we have probably already covered that department. She has picked up that fact straight away. She is much too quick for me. The Department which covers environmental matters will be considered soon and she will be able to ask the officials and the responsible Minister in that area.
—Can the Minister tell me whether an advertising agent has been engaged by the Government to promote the proposed constitutional changes next year?

—The Constitutional Commission has a public relations firm working for it at the moment. I do not have any information about a specific advertising campaign. As Senator Walters would know, if a direct constitutional amendment is put, there are fairly strict limits on how the matter can be advertised one way or the other. The firm that is doing the main work is Hill and Knowlton (Aust.) Pty Ltd. It was appointed as a public relations consultant to the Commission from 3 April 1987, initially until June 1987. The appointment now extends to June 1988. This firm has been engaged to assist the Commission with the promotion of the Commission's activities until the final report is presented to the Government in 1988. The Commission has budgeted $266,000 for public relations consultants costs, including disbursements, in the 1987-88 financial year. The remuneration is for services rendered rather than on a retainer basis.
—Does that public relations activity promote the proposed constitutional changes put forward by the Commission?
—I am informed that it promotes the work of the Commission rather than the changes the Commission is suggesting.
—There is a very big difference. Does it include promoting the constitutional changes that are proposed by the Commission?
—The specific answer is no, that is not what it is charged to do, nor is it asked to do that.

—So it does not talk about the proposed changes; it just talks about the role of the Commission, how the Commission is set up, why it is set up, et cetera. I cannot see why a public relations exercise would continue until June 1988 if it is not actually promoting the findings of the Constitutional Commission. The Minister might like to elaborate on that point for me.

—I can see the point that Senator Walters is getting at. Its job is to promote the reports of the Commission, the workings of the Commission. When a report comes out, it promotes the report. It does not argue one way or the other whether the conclusions are valid or invalid. It is purely aimed at that end and is being retained until June 1988 because that is when the final report of the Commission is due.

—I understand that, because if it were just promoting the report of the Commission, it would hardly give the cons; it would give only the pros. So it promotes the constitutional changes that are suggested. Can the Minister tell me whether Hill and Knowlton is a subsidiary of J. Walter Thompson, an American advertising agency?

—I do not have any information on that point. I will take it on notice and get someone from the Department to respond directly to Senator Walters on that matter. I do not have a great knowledge of public relations firms, in any event.

—If it is a subsidiary of an American advertising agency, I would ask further questions. I would ask the Minister why we had engaged that firm in preference to an Australian agency. Naturally, that would be the question that I would ask.

—I understand that it was chosen from five or six firms that were asked to submit applications. I do not know whether the premise on which Senator Walters's question is based is true or false. She then asked me to comment on it. That puts me in an invidious position. In general, one would much prefer contracts to go to Australian firms. I would never have that as an absolute policy, incidentally, but certainly a preferable result would be that that should occur. One cannot close the market entirely to any competition from overseas.
—How will the Government decide what proposals of the Constitutional Commission will be put to a referendum?

—No doubt in due course the Government will set up an interdepartmental committee, which will gain a range of views. The Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, will draw up a submission in the normal fashion, which will go to Cabinet. It will probably go first to the administrative committee of Cabinet, then to the legislative committee of Cabinet, then it will go to Cabinet. It will then be adopted in principle. The necessary legislation will be drawn up. It will go to the legislative committee of Cabinet and then to Cabinet. It will then go to the Australian Labor Party Caucus committee. It will then go to Caucus. It will then be introduced in the House of Representatives, where it will be passed, and it will then enter the realm of the unknown-a place called the Senate.

—I wish to continue the line that Senator Walters has been following. Can the Minister or his advisers tell me anything of the personalities of the directors or proprietors of the consultancy firm? Who are the people who are actually running it?
—Bob Cotton.
—No, the working people.
—The officer has given me some information, but as to the personalities--
—If I said personalities, I am sorry; I meant the persons.
—The Commission has been working with the firm. To find out more detail, we would have to take the question on notice and reply to Senator Newman directly.
—Senator Walters asked some questions in this area that I was planning to ask. Was this consultancy arranged through the Department of Administrative Services?
—No. It is a perfectly normal procedure for consultancies to be arranged direct, as long as the guidelines that have been set down are followed.
—Is it not so-and this was my understanding-that the Department of Finance guidelines require them to be arranged through the Department of Administrative Services?
—Apparently that is not so for consultancies. It may be so in other contract areas. The honourable senator is correct. But for consultancies, that is not necessarily so.

—I stand corrected then. Is it the required practice, then, when advertising is being arranged, that the body concerned go through the Department of Administrative Services which I understand has a central advertising body?

—I am advised that this is not a standard advertising procedure. It is a public relations procedure because the selected agency is advising the Constitutional Commission. But it is not a standard advertising procedure.

—I thank the Minister. However, I refer her to answers which we were given during hearings of the Estimates Committee that an additional estimate of $70,000 was sought and approved and was spent for the most part in publicising preparations for the launches of advisory committee reports and in the advertising of the hearings and work associated with those hearings of the five advisory committees of the Constitutional Commission. If that is not advertising as most of us would define it, I fail to understand what advertising is. Therefore, I ask again: was this consultant, or advertising agency, or advertising work, arranged through the Department of Administrative Services? If it was not, was this not in breach of the guidelines of the Department of Finance?

—Under the circumstances, I think it would be preferable for us to take these questions on notice. I am here this evening in a representative capacity and I am finding it a little difficult to differentiate between some of the points that are being made. If Senator Newman finds it acceptable, I will get the officer concerned to provide direct answers to her this evening, if necessary, in order to clarify the points about when advertising is public relations and when it is not public relations. Given the semantics involved, it might be preferable if this were put in writing. I will undertake to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am nearly finished this line of questioning. I thank the Minister. SPEECH.PARA: Just taking this line of questioning to its conclusion, I draw attention to the booklet published by the Constitutional Commission called Australia's Constitution: Time to Update. This booklet was not published by the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS). I am advised that it cost $52,406 for the printing of 100,000 copies. I understand that it is to be distributed to laymen, to citizens around the countryside. It is full of cute little cartoons designed to convince us that constitutional change is not only desirable but an absolute necessity. The front page of the booklet contains a quotation from Professor Hughes which sets our minds at rest as to the desirability of constitutional change. Readers are convinced before they open the booklet that that is what we should be aiming for. But that is by the by-no doubt that is my personal prejudice.

Did anybody in the Attorney-General's Department authorise the Constitutional Commission to go outside the Government guidelines to have such a booklet printed by somebody other than the Australian Government Publishing Service? Did the Constitutional Commission take it upon itself to do this? Who makes these decisions? Are not public moneys being used to publish this booklet? Why was this money spent in a manner which is not presumably acceptable to the Government-namely, through the AGPS?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman talks about being between the devil and the deep blue sea. I hope that she does not see me as the devil. —I thank the Minister. I want to point out that I am not being purely pedantic in this matter. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

—We will undertake to get them tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to spend a couple of minutes not so much asking questions but bringing to the Committee's attention a very important matter which came up in the consideration of the estimates for the Attorney-General's Department regarding the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). I bring it to the Committee's attention particularly in view of the fall in the stock market and the other issues in terms of stockbroking firms and other financial institutions that that has occasioned. It was revealed in the consideration of the estimates of the NCSC, as Estimates Committee E reported to this chamber, that because of a high staff turnover the Commission was unable to undertake certain areas of surveillance within its statutory responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: It was brought to the attention of Estimates Committee E that in the 1986 calendar year there was a staff turnover rate of 32 per cent. To date, there has been a separation rate in the 1987 calendar year, on a full year basis, of 36 per cent. The resignation rate among professional staff in the first 10 months of 1987 was running at an annual rate of 39 per cent. The Executive Director of the NCSC, Mr Schoer, said when he appeared before the Estimates Committee that the turnover was causing quite serious problems in terms of the efficiency of the Commission and that senior personnel were required to spend more time on recruiting and training, causing deficiencies in the implementation of the Commission's legislative responsibilities. He also said:

Because of the loss of staff, frequently some of the branches that do the processing would be operating with a third or half of their staff resources which means we simply have to make decisions not to undertake certain areas of surveillance.

That serious problem has been brought to our attention as we move into the uncertain months ahead in terms of our economic and related circumstances. Given the critical importance of confidence in the stability of our financial institutions, I ask the Minister to convey to the Government the concern on this side of the chamber that all necessary steps are taken in terms of the resources available to the NCSC to enable it to fulfil its statutory role, because that is a role of very considerable importance to us all in the future. It would be an enormous indictment on the Government if things went wrong in our financial securities industry because of an unwillingness on the part of the Government adequately to fund and source the NCSC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that the Minister for Local Government has no advisers present at the moment. —Filibuster.
—I am not the sort of person who speaks when he has nothing to say. I see that the advisers are now filing into the chamber.

—I am not that sort of a man. I have seen people in this very chamber-some of those who are laughing the hardest in fact-use up their entire allocation of time merely because it is allocated to them. However, I am far more frugal, in the temporal sense, than some of my senatorial colleagues.

—I thank the Minister. I would like to ask some specific questions about the World Heritage listings for the wet tropics. The Minister indicates that she does know something about this matter. —The first report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests in Tasmania has been handed down. —I am sorry; we do not seem to be able to advise Senator Walters of that at this point in time. As I said a little earlier to Senator Newman, I will ask the officers to try to get the answer to the honourable senator this evening.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I have been asking this question now of three different departments, and each time I have asked it I have been referred to yet another department. If the officers of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories had been listening at all they would know this question would be asked. If the secretaries to the Ministers had been doing their jobs they would at least have informed the Department that this question would be coming up. I am very surprised that on an evening when the Environment is up for questions in the Committee of the Whole-when a very controversial issue has been raging for months on the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests in Tasmania and when a report has been brought down very recently which has to be tabled within 15 sitting days-the Department does not know anything about it. It seems to me quite incredible that the Department should come before us saying that it does not know anything about this very controversial issue. I presume that we will have the information before this Department is dealt with.

—I am trying to be understanding of Senator Walters's frustrations, since she has, as she says, asked this particular question before. However, I am advised that, because this Department has come on earlier than was anticipated, not all the officers are available.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, how can the Department say that when the Government has told us that it intends to finish tonight? It now happens to be an hour and a half before finishing time. This Department happens to be one of the departments to be heard in the last hour and a half. The Government told us that it wanted us to finish tonight. But the Department tells us that it has come on early. It really is quite ridiculous.
—I am advised that the report was received last week and it will be tabled within the timeframe.

—That really is not good enough. Can any departmental officer please tell me on what date the report was received and when it will be tabled? It is a terribly simple question that I am asking. It is a very controversial report. It is of vital interest to the people of Tasmania. The Department is well aware of the controversy that has surrounded this hearing. It is quite well aware of the controversy surrounding the report. It has to be tabled within 15 sitting days and yet the departmental officers here tonight cannot tell me the date it was received by the Government and when it will be tabled.
—Don't blame the officers.
—Well, whom do I blame?
—Blame the Minister.

—I am sorry, but I do not see that I should blame the Minister. It is not her portfolio. She has not received the report. I blame the officers of the Department who cannot adequately advise the Minister.
—They cannot answer back.
—Yes, they can. They can give me the time and dates. They can answer that.
—All I can say is that the officers are trying to find out. As the honourable senator noted and observed, I am acting as the Minister this evening, so I am not in a position to have the information.
—You are acting all right; you are posing as a Minister.
—I am acting as a Minister.
—I have a question, which I have already asked, about the wet tropical forests. Will the Minister be able to answer it tonight?
—I am advised that the Department is looking at all significant areas, and detailed advice will be available in due course.

—I would like to ask an allied question. What is the Department doing to prepare for the establishment of a Commonwealth statutory management authority which will prepare management plans to take account of problems arising from land use? We certainly do not want another situation like we have in south-west Tasmania, which has dragged on for five years with no management plan. —I am advised that the Department considers that that is part of the normal process.

I would like to ask the Minister a series of questions on this. The strategy goes for, I suppose, 15 pages; the pages are not numbered.
—It does not say anything.

—It says very little. That is the purpose of my standing here tonight-to try to extract some information from the Minister. As this strategy details the number of jobs in the specific area, I would like to know whether any costing has been done on this regional development employment strategy. We had a shocking admission yesterday, or it might have been the day before, from Senator Walsh. He said that he had spoken to Senator Richardson and that neither of them had a clue on how much this World Heritage listing was going to cost. I would have thought that if the Minister had gone to the trouble of putting out a regional development employment strategy some costing must be involved.

SPEECH.PARA: In the strategy, it says that 250 potential jobs will be created to maintain and to establish a timber plantation. For 250 jobs to be maintained, it would require 2,000 hectares of land to be sown every year, and probably require an initial purchase of 12,000 hectares. I think the ruling rate is $3,000 a hectare at the moment, so that is $36m that the Government would have to outlay to sustain 250 jobs per year. Can the Minister give the Committee an assurance that the Government is prepared to spend $36m in acquiring land? I have another question. I know that Senator Reynolds is having a great deal of difficulty answering these embarrassing questions. She really has no answers, but she should be able to answer this one because it concerns her own ministry. The $36m worth of land that will have to be purchased by the Commonwealth Government to provide the 250 jobs mentioned in the regional development employment strategy will become Commonwealth Government land, as it buys the freehold title. I would think that once that became Commonwealth Government land, the local shire councils would not be able to rate that land. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters will be pleased to know that the question she raised earlier about the report can be answered. The Department has advised that the report was received this Monday and it will be tabled within the period required under the legislation. I am advised that Senator Boswell's question was answered in the Estimates committee hearings, but I will repeat the answer. The Government has given an undertaking to maximise job benefits and minimise the adverse impacts of listing. The Government will take the steps necessary to meet this commitment. The actual compensation figure will be dependent on the outcome of the public consultation process, discussions with affected parties and the results of independent socio-economic studies. The main form of compensation will be job creation. Papers released on 6 October estimated that up to 640 jobs could be created in the north Queensland region. It is expected that further job opportunities will be identified from socio-economic studies and from discussions with local groups. This Government will put its money where its mouth is, in stark contrast to the Queensland Government-not that I am sure that there is one at the moment-which has allowed the timber industry--
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Stone may well laugh, but I am not sure how he will survive himself once Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen has left the scene in Brisbane. He may find that his future preselection is much more difficult when he does not have Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen to support him, not to mention the support of Lady Bjelke-Petersen. I repeat that the Government has indicated that it will certainly put its money where its mouth is, in stark contrast to the Queensland Government, which has allowed the timber industry in the area to run down, without providing any assistance or proper long term planning for alternative plantation of timber resources.

SPEECH.PARA: Before Senator Boswell and other senators who are so eager to make some contribution this evening rise to their feet, I would like to take this opportunity to say something more, as they have chosen to ask questions about the World Heritage listing area. Part of that responsibility has fallen within my portfolio, so I am well briefed in terms of consultations with local councils. —I call Senator Panizza.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. The Minister made an attack on me. I think that I should have the call to be able to defend myself. The Minister challenged me on a number of issues and I should therefore have the call to take up that challenge.

Has a study been done in regard to that listing or any other listing that the Government may have in mind to give us the true cost of what Australia has forgone in order to bring these listings into being?

—I am advised that there are a number of economic studies under way. As I said earlier in response to Senator Boswell, the Minister directly responsible, the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), has commissioned a number of consultants' reports. A number of economic studies are under way. The Senate, Senator Panizza in particular, and Senator Boswell will be advised in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer again to my first question which the Minister did not answer. I ask it again. I am not interested in how wide the Government's mouth is, or how wide it is going to open it. —I would like to ask whether any portion of the rainforest conservation program funding has been allocated to Tasmania. If the Tasmanian Government has failed to apply for such funds, will the Commonwealth consider the allocation of funds to the industry or other applicants from Tasmania?
—I am unable to give an answer to that question.
—Can I get one in writing?

—We will certainly be prepared to take that on notice. We will not be able to give Senator Sanders an answer by the time we get up tonight but I will take the question on notice and give the honourable senator an answer.
—I have another general question. How have the funds for hardwood reafforestation programs allocated in the Budget been distributed? Does the Minister have any information on that?
—I am sorry, we do not have officers here with that degree of detail in their grasp. Again I will seek an answer and make sure Senator Sanders gets it in writing.

—I just have one last question. If we could have the same arrangement, I will just introduce the question into the system. What funds has the Government allocated for restructuring the timber industry in the Eden region of the New South Wales south coast? Have funds been set aside for, firstly, the conversion of mills to softwood resource or to the use of smaller logs or, secondly, assistance in introducing new technologies including scrimber?
—The answer is exactly the same. I will take the matter on notice. I would be delighted to assist Senator Sanders, particularly if that was his last question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I just ask a brief question? The response in writing to a question asked by Senator Short in Estimates hearings about funding of community groups and so on, states:

SPEECH.PARA: A full grants list for the 1986-87 financial year will be available shortly, and can be forwarded to Senator Short on request.

I ask that this list be made available to all senators who are interested. Can this be regarded as a formal request for such a list? I would really like the full list that used to be published regularly, without having to wait for the annual report. When will the annual report be released with the full list of grants?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about the Australia Council?

—Yes, I am. I note that the Australia Council appears to have money to put out interesting posters of a publicity nature, such as a selection of vital statistics on the Australian arts industry, which is very interesting. But I have also found it very interesting to read the regular inserts in Artforce that used to say who was getting grants. I regret that that list is no longer being made available. I do not now know how much money the Australia Council is saving by not putting out that list but if it ever has any spare cash one of the important things it should do is advise people of what grants are being made.

—The Australia Council report will be tabled before the end of this session. It is expected to be tabled in the week beginning 7 December. The information the honourable senator seeks is in that. If he wants a copy of those lists of grants in advance, he can get it. As he does not, that is fine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —At a somewhat earlier hour of the evening, when the Government side of the chamber was in the charge of the Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, who I think has now been sacked by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans)--
—If she hasn't, she should be.

—I think it is only a matter of time before she comes to that pass. I was really referring to this particular occasion. Very properly, Senator Evans has come into the chamber to dispose of the Minister for Local Government, who basically was sabotaging his attempt to bring this debate, in an orderly manner, to a reasonable conclusion by a reasonable time. I made the comment I did about the Minister for Local Government because in her inimitable manner she managed not only to lose her lines, or to forget them-if she had any lines to lose-but also to prolong this debate by something like five times what it might otherwise have been had it not been for her provocative remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The only reason I rise to my feet on this subject is that in the course of the Minister's particularly ill-chosen remarks, she suggested I should do so. Of course I am never one to refuse a challenge of that kind, as Senator Evans is well aware. I thought I should note that, having issued the challenge, the Minister has now departed from the chamber at the request of Senator Evans. Naturally she has gone out with her tail between her skirts-I hope that is not an inappropriate anatomical simile.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are an expert on skirts.

—I thank Senator Evans. I would like to address one question of substance. It relates to the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority. That body-and I had been resident in this city for some years until the last three years-has grown even more notorious today than it was even before I ceased to be resident in this city. This has happened, not necessarily under the control of its management but under the people who really run it; namely, the Hospital Employees Federation of Australia and, in particular, under the control of one notable bully boy who is in charge of that body, Mr Hedley Rowe. I go out of my way to note with great approval what the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, had to say in this chamber a few days ago about that gentleman in response to a question.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point out to the Senate and, in doing so, address a question to the Minister, that the vote for the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority this year is $140.9m compared with $119.6m of expenditure last year. That is a very significant increase at a time when, so far as I am aware, nobody can get any health care from the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority. The one thing the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority is not good at is providing health care. Notwithstanding that, there is a very major increase in this year's vote for that Authority. The Minister now has some advisers beside him. That is perfectly proper. The Minister is quite deserving of advisers as this matter does not relate to his portfolio.

I ask the Minister to address his mind to the question of how it comes about that a body which is notorious, even throughout a very bad national hospital care system under the effects of Medicare and so on, is seeking from this Parliament a major increase in its vote. As I said, this Authority is not being run by hospital administrators but by the Hospital Employees Federation, a particularly malevolent trade union. In conclusion, I would also like to ask the Minister whether the Government has any plans to restore the provision of health care in the Australian Capital Territory by, if necessary, doing something about the power exercised over the operations of this Authority by a person who in no way is elected or appointed, even by his own trade union members I should say, but who nevertheless exercises extraordinary power in this Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —The explanation sought by Senator Stone for the increases appears on page 743 of the explanatory notes: Increase in salary and related expenditure, $16.4m; allowance for other price increases, $4.8m; funding for population growth, $3.6m; transfer of nurse education to CCAE, $269,000; program of aids for disabled people, $230,000; less increases in Medicare funding, $926,000; sale of Allambee Nursing Home, $829,000; and increase in revenue, $1.7m. That adds up to the $20m. I think that is a sufficient explanation, if I can separate it out from any emotion in my response. That is the precise arithmetical explanation of the increase, which Senator Stone sought.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister quite properly said, that is an arithmetical explanation; that is to say, it is no explanation at all. I repeat to the Minister the question: How does it come about that in an Authority that is providing no health care we have an increase in the appropriation-including an increase in salaries which was the biggest element in the total purported explanation he gave? Will the Minister address that question again? Will he answer in any way the second question I asked; namely, what is the Government proposing to do about the situation in the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority whereby there is a state of absolute anarchy?

—I am afraid that I must confine myself to arithmetic. I will have to leave the metaphysics and other forms of explanation to others. The largest single component is the increase associated with changes to the nursing pay structure. That represents $16.3m of that $20m and I do not think the nurses should bear the brunt of Senator Stone's indignation about this matter. There is also another assumption that underlies argument that there has been a very significant increase in the utilisation of the hospital system in terms of occupied bed days. In fact, there has been only a one per cent decrease in the last year. For all practical purposes the occupancy has been pretty much the same. So there has been the same call on the health care resources of the Australian Capital Territory for all practical purposes. The other items I have mentioned, in particular the nursing pay structure increase, are the explanation for the increase which is sought. I will be happy to ensure that the relevant Ministers are made aware of Senator Stone's feelings on the subject. They can make such a response as they think appropriate at a time when they are better able to do so than I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some questions in relation to the imposition of a charge for pre-school education in the Australian Capital Territory. Some questions were asked on this matter in the Estimates committee hearings, but neither the answers nor, for that matter, the range of questioning were adequate. One question was asked, I understand by Senator Reid, which did not get a satisfactory response. The question is: Given that there is now a charge for government education, albeit non-compulsory education-but there is a compulsory fee-what satisfaction can Australian Capital Territory residents have in the statement that there will not in the future be a charge for other non-compulsory elements of Australian Capital Territory education? If the Government is prepared to make a compulsory charge for pre-school education, why should it not introduce such a charge for some other element of education which is not compulsory? That is my first question.

SPEECH.PARA: My second question relates to the implementation of this fee. As I understand it, the parents of potential users of pre-school education have been advised of the manner in which they are to pay their fees and the manner in which they are to pay a deposit. That deposit is to be paid by a date early in December, I think 4 December, before we come back to this chamber after our break-not a very considerable amount of time for people to make financial arrangements to pay an $18 deposit. I ask why the Government has put the Public Service in the position of having to engage in this administrative rush. Surely this matter was thought out before the Government insisted on its being implemented in the Budget. This will, I predict, create some difficulties for public servants. There is enormous resentment in the Australian Capital Territory about the implementation of this charge and the sudden announcement of the administrative arrangements for its collection, and the short time that has been given for collection of the deposit may also create some trouble. It is unfair and inappropriate for the public servants to be blamed for that because it is, on the bottom line, a Government decision.

My third question relates to whether the Government can advise of what will happen next year, deposits having been paid or otherwise, when parents, male or female, arrive with their children, put them through the door of the pre-school and leave without paying. What will the Government do if this happens over a number of days? Which public servants will be used as the strong-arm money collectors for pre-school education? Are the pre-school teachers going to be the ones who have to say, `You are not leaving your child here'? If a family leaves a child or children without the fee having been paid, are the pre-school teachers to put the children outside the physical boundaries of the pre-schools and leave them at risk? In other words, as this is obviously not an appropriately thought out policy decision, what will the Government do next year when Australian Capital Territory residents refuse to pay? Which levels of the Public Service and which sectors of the Public Service will be responsible for implementing the Government's decisions with respect to what happens when someone refuses to pay?

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason for the imposition of the pre-school fee was, as I understand it, very simply to bring the Australian Capital Territory into line with the situation prevailing in the States generally pursuant to something in the nature of a direction from the Commonwealth Grants Commission that that be so as part of the general equalisation arrangements that are a pre-condition for the effective operation of State and State-analogous grants under the Grants Commission formulae. No proposal for the imposition of any other such fee is presently before the Government. The pre-school fee is self-contained and I have given the explanation for it. I am told that the reason for the imposition of a deposit was to enable the Australian Capital Territory to better manage its staffing arrangements for this year. The million dollars or so that flows from it was necessary for that purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) can tell us how much it will cost the Government to administer this fee and to carry out all the functions associated with it. I would also like to know what fees are paid for pre-school children in the other States. Does the Government take into account the fact that the only facilities provided by government in the Australian Capital Territory are the premises themselves and the teachers and that all other facilities in the pre-school system are already, and have always been, provided by the parents? They raise money in various ways and in some cases levies are imposed. A significant contribution is already being made.

SPEECH.PARA: I also ask what is happening with the Montessori pre-school at Yarralumla. The fact is that the Montessori program runs for children from the ages of three to six years. The Schools Authority so far, presumably on the demands of the Government, has declined to allow the pre-school to have three-year-olds in its program. The parents are totally prepared to pay the cost of the three-year-olds participating in the program. There is no suggestion that taxpayers pay the costs of the pre-school children in the three-year-old section of the Montessori program. Prior to the introduction in the Budget of the tax for pre-schoolers, the Government refused to allow the parents to pay for the three-year-olds to participate in the program. There is now a government fee for pre-school children attending a government pre-school, but when I last heard of the matter the Government was still refusing to allow parents of three-year-olds to pay. The inconsistency in this, to use the Minister's favourite expression, is breathtaking. I would like to know whether the Government has changed its mind and has agreed to allow the Montessori program to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question concerning the cost of collecting the deposit or the fee in question, the answer is that that is next to nothing because it is being collected through the banks.
—And no cost whatever to the Authority? Don't be absurd.
—Absurd though it may be, that is my advice.
—No officers in the Authority have anything to do with this fee? Now, come on!

—The cost of the typing of invoices, I am told, is the extent of the cost involved. We will be happy to quantify that for the honourable senator if she likes. That counts in my lexicon as pretty close to next to nothing, if not precisely so-but we are getting into metaphysics and I do not think Senator Stone would appreciate my pursuing that.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the second question, which was about comparative data on pre-schools elsewhere-a very complex question because there is a whole variety of fee structures, depending on whether the pre-schools in question are State run, privately run, a mixture or something of that kind-the Department will take that on notice and supply Senator Reid with an answer if that would help.

As to the honourable senator's last question about the situation of the Montessori pre-school in Yarralumla, I am advised that the $6 per week pupil charge for pre-school education announced in the September Budget is fundamentally different from the request by the Yarralumla Montessori Pre-School Parents Association that parents be allowed to contribute financially to the cost of providing staff to enable the enrolment of three-year-old children. The new charge will be applied to all students to maintain the equity of pre-school provision across the system. There is a bit more that I could add about the Montessori system generally but I think that answers the particular point Senator Reid made.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may answer the question but it is totally unconvincing from a philosophic point in explaining why the Government charges four-year-olds in the government pre-schools system but will not allow parents to contribute the cost of three-year-olds being in the system so there is no cost to the taxpayer. This is not the only place where outside funds are available. In the Telopea pre-school the French Government provides teachers and I fail to see why the Government is deliberately discriminating against the Montessori program. It just cannot have it all ways-having the French Government providing teachers in the Telopea pre-school and requiring parents to fund four-year-olds in pre-schools but not allowing about 20 three-year-olds to be a part of the program with the parents contributing. How does the Government justify that sort of discrimination? How does it explain it?
—I will just read Senator Reid everything I have here.
—I think I have already heard that. I want a better explanation from the Government.
—I think I would like to ask Dr Willmot to get to his feet to give you an answer.

—I know what Dr Willmot says. I appreciate his embarrassment and his difficulty. He understands what an education system should be. I am asking the Government why it will not let us have an education system with some variety in it, with some diversity in it and with some scope for parents to have something a bit different if they wish to participate.
—Basically--
—Just tell us you are a good socialist government and sit down.
—We are a good socialist government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I first take up a point made by Senator Reid as to the cost of the administration of this pre-school fee. As I understood the answer that was offered, it is that there is not much administrative cost, simply the cost of public servants writing out invoices. I ask whether it is true that the agency through which payments are made is not making any charge at all. Is it collecting this money as a sort of goodwill arrangement? If it is, what other agencies will be prepared to collect money for the Government on a goodwill basis? There must be some arrangement for that. That is the first question.

SPEECH.PARA: The second question comes back to my three questions which the Minister purported to answer. I have heard the Minister and other Ministers saying that they do not want the debates on the appropriations to go on ad infinitum, that answers could be given and that everybody could sit down and we could all go home. That is true, of course, if answers were given. But let me go through the three questions I asked and indicate why I feel I have not been given answers and why I am entitled to get up and have another go.

The first question I asked was whether, as a consequence of the Government having decided to charge for state education, albeit non-compulsory education, a compulsory fee, the principle was thus set that the Government was happy to charge for other non-compulsory sectors of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) education. All the Minister said was, `Oh, there is no proposal before us to do that'. I want an in-principle answer to the policy decision the Government has made. There may be no proposal before the Government at the moment-I understand that-but there could be one next week or next month. Can we take it from the decision to charge a compulsory fee for this element of non-compulsory education that in the ACT at least, if one is undertaking any education that is not compulsory, one may expect that the Government will impose some charge? Is that the principle that is behind this? It is not a question of whether there is now a proposal or otherwise.

Secondly, I asked about the rush with the administrative arrangements and why people who have to pay the deposit to receive the benefit of pre-school education have been given so little time. What was the administrative mess-up that had been forced upon the Public Service? The answer the Minister offered was, `We are asking people to pay a deposit so that we can figure out what our staffing arrangements will need to be'. In response to that I ask: How were staffing arrangements worked out in previous years when there were no fees and no deposits to charge? This is simply not an adequate answer as to why there is a deposit in the first place and it is certainly not an adequate answer to why, if it has been decided in principle to have a deposit, it has to be imposed in such a rush. It has been inflicted on the poor tax paying, and now pre-school fee paying members of the community, within a matter of weeks because the Government has not had its act together. I would like that aspect of my second question answered.

The third question I asked, which was the one I most wanted to ask, was completely ignored by the Minister. It is: What is going to happen when any ACT resident puts a child into a pre-school centre, slips the child through the gate or front door and refuses to pay? Which staff will be responsible for implementing the Government's decision with respect to what should happen when parents put their children in and refuse to pay? I am not talking about a parent who, as a matter of principle, writes to the Government and says, `I am not paying. You can all go and jump off'; I am talking about a parent who leaves a child at the centre. Who at the centre is going to be responsible for handling that? Will the child be simply put out the front gate? Will the parents be rung up at work and demanded to come? The Minister completely ignored that aspect of my question. My third question was: What happens when people refuse to pay? Who will be responsible for implementing the Government's decision then? That is the question I would really like an answer to this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, as to the rather breathless expression of disbelief that any bank could possibly be collecting this fee for nothing, let me say that that is indeed exactly the case. The bank in question, Civic Advance Bank, is doing it as a goodwill exercise, if you like, designed to get people in the door just as some of the building societies collect rates for similar reasons. I appreciate that it is one of those numerous phenomena in the real commercial world that are unknown and unappreciated, or underappreciated, by some honourable senators opposite despite their claims to understanding the finer dimensions of the free enterprise system. We are seeing those dynamics at work in this instance and I think we all ought to be duly grateful for the way in which it is operating in this instance. It took a little longer to get the system into operation, as I understand it, because of the time that was necessarily taken up in getting expressions of interest from institutions that might have been interested in doing the collection in question.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the further anxiety with my answer about the Government having no plans to impose fees in other situations, that remains the case. I cannot anticipate any decisions that might be made at some time in the future, but there are no plans, proposals, interests or intentions on the part of the Government at the moment for going down that particular track. This was a particular response, as I have tried to describe it, to the Grants Commission requirements and was constructed as an exercise on that basis.

Questions were asked about what happened before, why this deposit system is so important and what it is designed to do. It is designed essentially to be a firm statement of intention to assist the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority with its planning of its staffing rate. Of course, it is also to make some additional money on the side, as is undoubtedly necessary and desirable. That sort of planning was done in the past simply on the basis of census data, statistics and so on-necessarily less complete and certain than the kind of data that flows from a system of the kind that is now being introduced.

As to the final question about responsibility at the centres in situations where someone refuses to pay, we simply say that the Authority has well trained staff who will deal with such situations as they arise with common sense, discretion, tact and charm.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just how does someone faced with the responsibility of caring for a child left at a centre, knowing that that child has been left in contravention of the Government direction that a pre-school be paid, acting with common sense, discretion, good grace and charm--
—And tact.
—And tact. What does someone with all those gifts do?

—I have had a number of responsibilities during my ministerial career, but none has equipped me to answer that sort of question. I have great confidence that the trained staff of the Authority, which has a professional, dedicated commitment to caring for young people, will respond appropriately in the circumstances of each case. I am sure that if members of the staff are confronted with a parent who comes at them like Senator Vanstone, they might be forgiven for making some response. I do not want to speculate on that hypothesis, any more than I want to respond to the hypotheses that Senator Vanstone has offered for my consumption tonight.

—On another aspect of education, has the Department been asked whether it has a view on the development of a Presbyterian school in the Tuggeranong area? Has any opinion been asked for? Has any opinion been given? If so, what is it about the proposal that it would want such a school in the vicinity of a church in the Tuggeranong area?
—It is being considered by an appropriate committee in the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the opinion has not yet been finally given.

—I know that there is a committee in the Department of Employment, Education and Training. I was asking whether the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories or the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority has been asked whether they have any view upon it and, if so, what that view is.
—The Department is represented on that committee, as is the Authority. They are determining whether funding will be provided, and it is still to be decided.

—I ask about a cycling centre. A decision was taken by the Federal Government earlier this year to place the Australian Institute of Sport cycling centre in Adelaide. Has the South Australian Government yet made a decision on the building of a cycling velodrome in Adelaide? If no, why was a decision taken in February by the Australian Institute of Sport to place the cycling centre in Adelaide? If the answer is yes, when is the velodrome to be commenced; when is it to be finished; and at what cost? Will the Commonwealth contribute to the cost? If so, how much will the Commonwealth contribute and on what basis? Will it be a covered velodrome? If it is to be a covered velodrome in stage 2 of the project, when will stage 2 be commenced and finished, and at what cost? Will the Commonwealth contribute to stage 2? If so, how much will the Commonwealth contribute to stage 2 and on what basis?

—We are not aware of any decision having been made on this matter to this point. It is essentially a matter for the South Australian Government as to timing and so on. Questions as to cost, cost sharing and so on, remain, as I understand it, to be resolved. If any further detail can be given in answer to that question, on the basis, perhaps, of greater knowledge in the Department than the officers who are present possess, I will be happy to ensure that it is supplied.
—I call Senator Michael Baume.
—I defer to Senator Newman.
—Aren't you a gentleman. I call Senator Newman.

—I thank Senator Baume for his courtesy. I find the Minister's answer quite unacceptable. I have been following this matter up hill and down dale through Estimates committee hearings since I first became a member of the Senate. I seem to get a different answer every year. At the time of every Estimates or Additional Estimates we get a different story from the Commonwealth. We have been told that a decision has been taken to build a velodrome in Adelaide; that stage 1 will be uncovered and stage 2 will be covered: that the Commonwealth may or may not contribute to stage 2; that when the decision was taken to place the centre in Adelaide, a commitment had been given by the South Australian Government that a velodrome would be built. Equivocal answers-that is the only way I can describe them-were given recently during Estimates committee hearings to Senator Puplick. The Minister's answer finally caps the lot. Who is telling the truth? Who is not telling the truth? I am sick and tired of being told first this and then that. Somebody is misleading the Parliament.
—As I am neither a South Australian nor a cyclist, I find it difficult to get quite as steamed up as Senator Newman about this.
—More as an eccentric wheel.

—I acknowledge the interjection. I am beyond all capacity to deal with it at this time. I am unable to give any further or better answer. I have no idea why Senator Newman is so steamed up about this matter, why she has pursued it over so many years and, apparently, with such unsatisfactory results. I am told that the South Australian Government has given a clear commitment and a clear indication of its intention to do this, but I do not know why there have been holdups and why the matter has not been resolved to Senator Newman's satisfaction. I will endeavour to find out and ensure that she gets a proper written answer.

—As the Minister is obviously not aware of the importance of this matter, I will very briefly tell him, and all other honourable senators as well, about it. Taxpayers' dollars, many millions of dollars, have already gone into the building of a most excellent velodrome of world class standard in Tasmania. It is the only covered velodrome in Australia. For very peculiar and suspect reasons, a decision was taken to locate the centre in Adelaide, where there is currently no velodrome, either covered or uncovered. I am concerned that taxpayers' dollars will be spent once more to build a velodrome which is not needed but which it appears will be placed in Adelaide for reasons which have nothing to do with economy or careful expenditure of the nation's resources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister will be overjoyed to know that this is positively my last question in the Appropriation debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators-Oh, no!

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not tempt me. This question concerns the Minister's territorial role. What is he doing about graffiti? I raise this problem because the Government has allocated $50,000 to deal with graffiti on the walls of the new Parliament House. That was mentioned in the estimates for the Parliament. We were told that the retaining walls around the new Parliament House and the tunnels under the roadways to the new Parliament House are under the control of the Department which deals with Territories. They appear to provide a great expanse of tempting walls for the enthusiastic spray cans of the capital. Is the Department making any similar allocation to that being made by the new Parliament House? Are any measures being taken to prevent damage to the structures by the use of different surface sprays and finishes which, I understand, have added some considerable cost to some of the walls of the new Parliament House?

—The Australian Capital Territory Administration, I am told, removes graffiti within its normal maintenance budget, confronting problems as they arise and dealing with them accordingly. Some experimentation is going on with better protective surfaces and other technological wizardry of that kind which I do not propose to retail now, even if I could. It is a tricky matter in any public administration with large building areas. The Administration is doing the best that it can, without additional cost to the taxpayer.
—Without additional cost?
—That is as I understand it. It is within the ordinary maintenance budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few remarks concerning the arts section of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and to raise a question which I raised initially in the adjournment debate concerning the Sydney International Piano Competition of Australia. On that occasion I drew the Senate's attention to the fact that in the years that the competition has existed, that is, since 1977-I acknowledge a vested interest in the competition which is of great importance to young Australian musicians-there has been a philosophical problem with the Australia Council, and in particular the Music Board, which considered that competitions were bad for artistic endeavour and, accordingly, no assistance was ever given by the Music Board to assist the competition per se.

SPEECH.PARA: On that occasion the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson, pointed out that the Australia Council had been restructured and that the Music Board as such no longer exists on its own. I would seek from the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) some sort of reassurance that the philosophical bar that existed in the artistic field to rewarding young Australians who are prepared to take part in competitions to prove their skill and ability and to give themselves an advantage in the international sphere, will be lifted because, far from being a disadvantage, competition is indeed an advantage.

When I look at the appropriation that is made for the Australia Council of nearly $52m, I am concerned that not only are the friends of the Australia Council, if you like, rewarded with sympathetic hearings and allocations of funds, but also institutions such as the Sydney International Piano Competition of Australia, which enhances the standard of performed music and offers to young Australians the opportunity to compete and young Australian audiences--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would honourable senators on the Government side please lower the level of noise.
—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I am directing my remarks to the Minister for Transport and Communications who is on duty, is he not?
—Yes, he is.

—Thank you. I could have been forgiven for doubting he was on duty. Can the Minister give some reassurance that the philosophical-I think the Minister is interested in philosophy-that used to be applied by the Music Board to competitions in artistic endeavour shall no longer be applied following the restructuring of the Australia Council? I specifically ask the Minister to give me an indication of whether or not that is so.

—The most I can offer to do in this respect is to ask Senator Richardson to raise the points in issue with the Australia Council which exercises independent authority and has decision making power in this matter. I will ask him to act accordingly.
—I have just two or three more matters to raise. Is there still in existence an ordinance to establish a schools authority council?
—The answer is yes.

—It was announced in the Budget that the Government would abolish the Schools Authority Council. Is the Government intending to rescind the ordinance, is it intending to reappoint people to the Council or is it planning to re-establish some other means by which the community can communicate with the Government on education matters by way of some sort of representative council. If not, is it going to leave this ordinance in existence? What is to be its future?
—The Government has a new ordinance in the process of preparation. That will be brought forward shortly and that will answer the questions just asked by Senator Reid.

—The next matter I wish to raise does not concern education. It is directed to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and concerns the sewerage rates ordinance. I refer to a letter which has been sent to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) in relation to commercial corporate properties. The ordinance seems to be interpreted in such a way that unit owners who may not have a flushing unit within their area are charged a sewerage rate as if they did have such a unit if it in fact is in the corporate area. But at the same time, the corporate body is also charged for the same number of flushing units in the corporate body area. Does the Government have any plan to surrender this double dipping which it is presently indulging in?
—I will take that question on notice.

—The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) has had this matter before him for some 10 days or so. Is this matter not being looked at or taken seriously? When might this question be answered?

—I am sure that the matter is being taken very seriously. Ten days is hardly a reasonable time within which to expect an answer from a Minister, even on a matter of momentous importance as this matter manifestly is. I will ensure that he acts very quickly to give Senator Reid an answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My last question-and I ask it while Mr Turner is still available to advise the Minister-relates to policing which I recognise to be within the responsibility of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). Recently I have spoken a number of times on the subject of police numbers. I have pointed out that there are fewer police per thousand now than there were when this Government came to office. That is a matter that needs to be addressed. In particular I wish to say something about the legislation under which police operate in the Australian Capital Territory. I noted the announcement the other day that an amendment would be made to the legislation to allow the police to have greater powers with respect to under-age drinking. But I point out that the problem of vandalism and violence in the Territory is not just something which involves young people and under-age drinking. It goes further than that.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had many representations and complaints from individuals, shopkeepers and representatives of Neighbourhood Watch. They have pointed out the need not only for a greater policing capacity but also for the ordinance to be changed to enable police to require people to move on and to be able to act in relation to what I think are loosely called street offences over which these days they have virtually no power whatever. The changes that have been made in recent years have been seen very widely in the community as having contributed to the number of street offences and violence which occur at present. Are there any plans to change the ordinance to enable police to deal with some of the things which are happening on the streets of Canberra and to citizens of Canberra?

TALK.START.PARA: —The view that is taken by the Department, I am told-and I do not know whether it is shared by the Minister or not-is that the present legislation is adequate. Nonetheless, I will draw Senator Reid's remarks to the Minister's attention to see whether he wants to make any further response, or give the matter further consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I am absolutely astonished that the Department would give advice to the Minister that the present situation in Canberra is satisfactory or adequate. There were 13 brawls in Canberra last Friday night, and that is just the tip of the iceberg. Everybody knows that it is just not safe to attempt to walk from the Woden Valley shopping centre through the parking lots to suburbs such as Lyons. The situation is very significantly different from what it has been in the past. Police officers will tell you the same thing. I want to know on what basis the Department comes to the conclusion that everything in Canberra is just fine and that there is no need whatever to do anything to improve the safety of the people of the Australian Capital Territory as they go about what ought to be legitimate acts of walking about Canberra, visiting clubs and going to shopping centres. They should not be molested or abused. They should not fear for their safety as they do at present. This sort of thing has increased greatly in recent times.

SPEECH.PARA: It is certainly the view of many people that the ordinance is not adequate. If the ordinance is deemed to be adequate, one must draw the conclusion that the problem lies in the lack of police numbers. I draw the attention of the Committee to Senator Tate's answers to my questions in which he says that the numbers of police are adequate. He just cannot have it both ways. If the number of police is adequate, the legislation under which they are trying to operate is inadequate. I suspect that it is a bit of both. We need to bring the percentage of police to the population back to what it used to be. I suggest that the changes that took powers from police have caused the situation to occur whereby people are no longer safe to move about as they have in the past. I could go on with the examples of violence and the time it takes for police to answer calls. Nobody suggests that the police are not doing their job efficiently or to the best of their ability; but the situation in Canberra at present is far from satisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Reid needs to draw a distinction between the situation itself and the basic powers available to the police under the legislation. It ought not to be assumed that there is any complacency about the situation to which she adverts. As I have already indicated, the Minister will certainly look at the powers question to see whether there needs to be some legislative review. I think that Senator Reid will appreciate that these situations can occur notwithstanding the most broad-ranging powers notionally available on the books with which to deal with them. That is the basis for my giving the response I did on the part of the Department. As I have indicated, it is a question which I will look at again and I will advise the Minister to have another look at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one very brief question about the allocation of grants by the Performing Arts Board of the Australia Council. This question is in connection with grants for opera training funds. I speak specifically about the fact that the application by the Western Australian Opera Company for these funds has failed, whereas $75,000 has been given to the Lyric Opera of Queensland for the next three years. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that in 1987 the Western Australian Opera Company benefited from special project funding which supported its community program. It received $45,000 for that and $16,000 for its touring program. Those relatively small amounts, together with State funding, enabled the Western Australian Opera Company to set up an integrated program of training for eight young singers, two repetiteurs and two stage managers. From its own resources it contributed $103,000 over and above the Australia Council funding to make that integrated training program possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The grants from the Australia Council, together with State moneys, for the 1987 program facilitated its endeavours to obtain sufficient sponsorship to make three tours. It toured the south-west of Western Australia, the near north and the north-west of the State. In all, the company gave 243 performances, which included 153 school performances to over 30,000 children. There were comprehensive programs for the company's singers, repetiteurs and coaches.

This fully integrated program of training must now be cancelled for 1988 because of the lack of some minimal funding by way of special project grants from the Australia Council over and above the $20,000 granted to the schools program. While the Western Australian Opera Company is the most remotely based opera company in Australia, it has some knowledge of the operations of the Queensland Lyric Opera and it has informed me that it would be very surprised to hear that the Queensland one has a training program which is comparable with the Western Australian one or that it could make full use of the training grants in such a positive way.

It is the view of the Western Australian Opera Company that the company was not dealt with fairly as far as the appropriation of this grant was concerned, due to lack of appropriate representation from Western Australia. It has also drawn my attention to the fact that it is quite apparent that no one has investigated the work that it has done during the year in the area of training. I ask the Minister whether, in the appropriation of these grants, the Arts Board is asked to take into consideration past programs and how they are proceeding. Also, what hold does the Government have on the allocation of these grants? It certainly appears from the information that has been given to me that there is some unfairness. I would like the Minister to comment on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
