TALK.START.PARA: —I draw Senator Jenkins's attention to the fact that, as I am sure most honourable senators are aware, the Australia Council is an independent authority and makes its own decisions based on its own criteria, analysis and comparisons. The most that we as a Government can do, because of the arm's length relationship we have with it as an independent authority and because of the desire and principle to separate us from the details of the granting activities of the Council, is bring these issues to the Council's attention and ask it to have regard to them. As I said in relation to a previous question of this kind, all I can do is ask Senator Richardson to draw the honourable senator's remarks to the Australia Council's attention. I am sure that he will do just that.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Dairy Produce Act 1986 prescribes criminal penalties for the export of dairy produce in breach of International Dairy Arrangement (IDA) price minima. The purpose of this Bill is to substitute economic penalties for such breaches.

The Principal Act, inter alia, establishes the Australian Dairy Corporation (ADC) and provides it with export control powers. It recognises the Australian commitment to the IDA established under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and provides the basis for fulfilling the Government's commitment to the minimum prices which are set under the Arrangement.

The main objective of the Arrangement is to expand and liberalise world trade in dairy products under as stable market conditions as possible, on the basis of mutual benefit to exporting and importing countries.

Australia as a signatory of the Arrangement is committed to ensuring that its obligations are fulfilled. However, there are concerns that the measures embodied in the Dairy Produce Act for ensuring compliance with the international price minima are inappropriate in practice and should be more comparable with the measures adopted by other major exporter members of the IDA.

The IDA requires countries participating in the Arrangement to `take the steps necessary to ensure' that export prices of dairy products are not less than the IDA prescribed minima. However, mechanisms for ensuring observance are left to individual participants to develop; they are not prescribed in the IDA.

The European Community uses its export refund system to meet its obligations for observance of IDA minimum prices. We have had repeated assurances from the EC Commission that the refunds are set at levels that would make it impossible for EC traders to export dairy products at less than IDA minimum prices and still make a profit on each sale. Nevertheless the Commission does concede that its refund system does not impose an effective price discipline and that it is technically possible for its traders to enter into `loss' contracts or manipulate products and currencies in order to trade below IDA minima.

In New Zealand, another major IDA participant and exporter, the sole exporter of dairy products is the New Zealand Dairy Board. The legislation governing the operations of the Board provides for it to comply with the general trade policy of the Government. This in turn `requires' that the Board's performance be consistent with the provisions of the IDA.

By comparison Australia's current method of observance seems inappropriate and somewhat out of touch with commercial realities. Under the Dairy Produce Act a trader exporting in breach of IDA minimum prices is liable not only to a fine but also a term of imprisonment of up to two years, in addition to suspension or cancellation of his or her export licence. However, criminal prosecution is a difficult course and is not a practical way of pursuing breaches of IDA minimum prices where they may come to notice. There have been no prosecutions under the legislation.

In the current competitive international environment an economic approach to observing the IDA is considered more appropriate than an observance mechanism based on criminal penalties which are difficult to enforce. The provisions of the Bill which I will now elaborate are designed to bring about this change.

Under the new arrangements it will continue to be a condition of licence that exporters comply with IDA minimum prices. The ADC will in the event of a detected breach of a IDA price minimum, require the exporter to pay the difference between the actual sale price and the appropriate IDA price minimum to the Corporation. Payments by exporters are to be credited to the Market Support Fund of the Corporation which is used to support the prices of manufactured dairy products.

In the event that an exporter is detected to be in breach of a minimum price and fails to pay the Corporation the difference between the minimum and the actual sale price, the Corporation may suspend or cancel the exporter's licence.

Where a breach is an unavoidable breach or where the exporter did not knowingly export dairy produce below the appropriate IDA price minimum, clause 3 of the Bill (sub-section 51a (5)) provides the Corporation with the power to determine if a breach of IDA minimum price resulted from `exceptional circumstances'. If a determination is made by the ADC that such circumstances exist, then the exporter will not be required to pay the difference between the IDA minimum and the actual sale price. I will be stressing to the ADC that this provision is not to be used to try and justify sales below the IDA minimum price that do not accord with the circumstances I have already outlined covering unavoidable or unknown breaches.

The Bill also incorporates appropriate review and appeal provisions. Section 118 of the Dairy Produce Act dealing with reconsideration and review of decisions of the ADC will be amended to include decisions made under section 51a dealing with the payment of the difference between the selling price and IDA minimum prices and determinations of `exceptional circumstances', and those under sub-section 59 (4) dealing with suspension and cancellation of export licences. These changes will enable exporters to appeal against decisions made under these sections with such decisions to be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Another important change that the Bill provides is the automatic adjustment of GATT IDA minimum prices in the Regulations made under the Act relating to exports. At present when the International Dairy Products Council (the governing body of the IDA) agrees to changes in the minimum prices for dairy products there is an inevitable lag between the new minimum prices being adopted and the incorporation of these new prices in the relevant Regulations. Clause 3 of the Bill (sub-section 51a (9)) provides for the automatic incorporation of changes in IDA minimum prices in the Regulations. This will ensure that the Regulations reflect changes in minimum prices as and when they occur and will eliminate current lags in their implementation.
The Corporation will continue to provide all licenced exporters with details of IDA minimum price changes as they occur, to ensure that exporters are fully aware of their minimum price obligations.

The ADC's role in the proposed observance measures I have just outlined will not be greatly changed from its existing role; the approach is a logical extension of the Corporation's existing responsibilities to ensure IDA compliance though its export control powers. The Corporation will be required to maintain close scrutiny of export price movements and to ensure that exporters are meeting their obligations under the Act. Moreover, the Corporation will be required to make determinations under subsection 51a (5) should the need arise.

Since the ADC can export dairy products, the Corporation and its subsidiaries are required to comply with IDA minimum prices, just as are other exporters. Subsections 51a (6) and (7) deal with situations where Australia's trade in dairy products could be severely disadvantaged by the actions of others on the world market. In such circumstances the Bill provides for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to authorise the Corporation to trade at prices below the IDA minima. I envisage such an exemption being granted with the concurrence of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade after a review of all aspects of the situation.

The Australian Government as a signatory to the IDA accepts fully the responsibilities that membership of the Arrangement entails. The changed observance mechanism embodied in the Bill in no way reduces the Government's commitment and intent to ensure observance of IDA price minima by Australian dairy product exporters. Rather, the amendment has the objective of aligning the nature of Australia's observance mechanism more closely with that of other major participants. It is completely consistent with the rights and responsibilities of signatories of the IDA to determine and adopt appropriate national measures to ensure that export prices are not less than IDA prescribed minima. The Bill removes the unnecessarily restrictive penalty structures which are not suited to a commercial environment and substitutes measures that still ensure the preservation of integrity of the industry and Government. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Puplick) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ASIAN DEVELOPMENT FUND BILL 1987INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION BILL 1987INTERNATIONAL FUND FOR AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speeches in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
ASIAN DEVELOPMENT FUND BILL 1987
The purpose of this Bill is to authorise a contribution by Australia of $A410m towards the fourth replenishment of the Asian Development Fund.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION BILL 1987
The purpose of this Bill is to authorise a contribution of $A335m towards the eighth replenishment of the International Development Association, or IDA as it is commonly called.

Grouped with this Bill are two further Bills, dealing respectively with Australia's contribution to the fourth replenishment of the Asian Development Fund and the second replenishment of the International Fund for Agricultural Development. I propose to discuss the substantive issues in respect of each of the three Bills in this speech, as there are a number of matters which overlap the Bills. I will then proceed to move the second reading of the Asian Development Fund Bill 1987 and the second reading of the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill 1987, and make a short statement specific to each of those Bills.

In late 1986, in the context of considering Australian contributions to the current replenishments of the Asian Development Fund and the International Fund for Agricultural Development, a number of questions arose as to the effectiveness and efficiency of those international financial institutions to which Australia belonged, namely the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank, and the International Fund for Agricultural Development. A review of these IFIs as a basis for determining further Australian contributions to IDA, ADF and IFAD replenishments was carried out internally by AIDAB.

AIDAB concluded that the IFIs are, in general, effective institutions and that Australia's participation in their activities complements our own bilateral aid program. I feel that, with regard to IFAD, a rigorous assessment needs to take account of views such as expressed by Professor Helen Hughes. In an article in the Canberra Times of 24 October, she points out that:
IFAD depends upon the World Bank and other agencies to do much of its project preparatory work;
IFAD's projects are highly risky as a result of poor preparation and support by host countries;
IFAD's examination system is not yet systematic;
IFAD is weak on infrastructure and institutional support.
She concludes, as I do, that:
`It would be wise to cut aid to ineffectual organisations and retain sufficient interest in the more effective ones to be able to have something of a say in their running.'
I turn now to the eighth replenishment of IDA.

IDA, was established in 1960 as the concessional lending affiliate of the World Bank. It assists its poorest member countries by providing long term, interest-free credits for sound development projects, utilising mainly grant funds provided by donor countries.

The poorest countries have great need for development assistance on concessional terms, which include lengthy repayment and initial grace periods. Honourable senators will recognise that IDA, in turn, depends on developed donor countries like ourselves to provide most of the resources to carry on its work: donor funds are critical to the development needs of these countries.

The eighth replenishment of IDA, (IDA-8), is designed to cover concessional lending operations over the three fiscal years (FY) 1988-90. Negotiations on the size and modalities of the replenishment began in January 1986.

The substantial needs of IDA recipients were viewed against the background of the budgetary resources available in donor countries to finance multilateral aid. Donors, including Australia, argued that every effort should be made to achieve an IDA-8 of at least $US12 billion, a level of replenishment which would maintain the real level of operations under previous replenishments.

After extensive deliberations, on 15 December 1986 donors agreed on a basic $US11.5 billion IDA-8 replenishment with traditional burden sharing arrangements. In addition, five countries agreed to provide voluntary special contributions totalling $US731.7m. Switzerland, a non-member, made an united grant of $US165m.

During negotiations Australia argued that our economic circumstances precluded us from increasing our relative share of IDA. Australia pledged a maximum contribution of $A335m to IDA-8. This figure maintains our IDA-7 share of 1.98 per cent of the basic replenishment.

The financial impact of the IDA-8 contribution is shown in the explanatory memorandum to this legislation. As in previous replenishments, Australia has the option of paying its contribution either in cash or by lodging non-negotiable, non-interest bearing promissory notes encashable on demand as and when funds are actually required by IDA for loan disbursements. In accordance with past practice, and in line with the practices of most other members of IDA, payment will be made in promissory notes, which will be encashed over a period of eight years, beginning in this financial year, as per the schedule in the explanatory memorandum.

IDA contributions represent a major share of Australia's aid to Africa. Donors have agreed that 45-50 per cent of IDA-8 resources will be allocated to countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. China and India are the other main beneficiaries; these two countries will receive about 30 per cent of IDA-8 resources.

Honourable senators will know that Australia has a solid record of support for IDA since its inception. There has been general agreement, on all sides of the House, that IDA is a highly effective channel for disbursement of development assistance to the most impoverished countries of the world. The recent major re-organisation of the World Bank initiated by the President of the Bank, Barber Conable, will I believe result in an even more efficient and responsive organisation. Indicative of the changes taking place at the World Bank is the significant increase in bank resources to be devoted to environmental assessment and the integration of environmental policy and developmental strategies. The bank has also increased its emphasis on women-in-development activities.

This Bill provides an opportunity to demonstrate support for IDA and our willingness to recognise, through our support for this institution, the Development Assistance needs of the poorest developing countries.
I turn now to the proposed Australian contribution to the fourth replenishment of the Asian Development fund. As indicated, the Bill will be presented immediately following the IDA-8 legislation.
Honourable senators will know that since the Asian Development Bank was established in 1966 Australia has been and remains a strong supporter.

The Asian Development fund, or ADF, is the `soft' or concessional loan arm of the ADB. ADF resources complement our limited loan arm of the ADB. ADF resources complement our limited bilateral aid program to the poorest countries of South Asia, and supplement our bilateral aid to PNG and the South Pacific.

The fourth replenishment of the ADF is intended to cover concessional lending operations over calendar years 1987-90. Negotiations on the modalities of the replenishment commenced in June 1985, with Australia, Japan, Italy and the Nordic countries arguing for a $US4 billion replenishment level. This figure represented the level required to maintain the ADF's real level of operations during the 1987-90 period.

The ADF-V negotiations were concluded in April 1986 with donors agreeing to a replenishment level of $US3.6 billion. Australia pledged $A410m, which represents a 7.98 per cent share of the replenishment. The basis for this level of contributions is that it would have been the equivalent of a 7.19 per cent share (i.e. our share of the previous replenishment) if the fourth replenishment had reached the $US4 billion level which we had initially advocated.

As with IDA-8, payment to the fourth replenishment of ADF will be made in the form of non-negotiable, non-interest bearing promissory notes. These will be encashed over a period of 12 years beginning in this financial year, as per the schedule in the explanatory memorandum to this legislation.

Despite our strong and continuing support for the ADB there have been concerns over some recent trends at the bank. Our main concerns have centred to some extent on personnel practices such as the handling of staff grievances, but more importantly on certain project proposals which appeared to be of doubtful value. It has appeared at times that the bank has been prepared to sacrifice quality control in order to maintain its level of lending. The bank has to be careful that it does not become guilty of `monumentalism' at the expense of rigorous quality control and economic justification.

Australia has been quick to voice its concerns in an open and frank manner, at the executive board and at other fora. Indeed, at the 1987 annual meeting in Osaka, Australia's Governor Ad Interim, the Hon. Chris Hurford, outlined our concerns with the bank, and joined with a number of other members in calling for a comprehensive external review of the management and organisation of the bank.
I note that the bank has acknowledged its concern and declared its responsiveness to the criticisms of Australia and others.

A panel of five eminent persons has been set up as an external panel to study the role of the Bank in the 1990s and provide a basis for the bank to formulate its operational directions, strategies and policies for that decade. We shall monitor the work of the panel closely, and make known to the panel our views on the future of the bank.

The Asian Development Bank and its Asian Development Fund have an important role to play in continuing to foster economic and social development in the region of immediate interest to Australia. Our contribution to the fourth replenishment will confirm our willingness to continue helping the poorest developing countries in our region with highly concessional assistance. We will continue to provide constructive criticism and comment where we feel this is necessary to ensure the continued effective operation of the ADB.
The last of the institutions which comes before our attention today is the International Fund for Agricultural Development, or IFAD.

The primary objective of the fund is to help increase agricultural production in developing countries. Australia's membership of IFAD has been predicated on political and humanitarian considerations. Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) donors supply 60 per cent of IFAD's resources, and Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) the remaining 40 per cent.

IFAD has had considerable problems in attracting regular replenishments from donors, more particularly from OPEC donors whose contributions set the base for the fund and therefore the total to be subscribed. The second replenishment (IFAD-2) negotiations took nearly three years to complete. Agreement was finally reached in January 1986 on a replenishment of $US460m, considerably below the original target of $US1 billion. The low replenishment level partly reflected the OPEC group's limited capacity to contribute in the wake of substantially reduced oil prices.

Australia pledged $A8.48m to IFAD-2. This contribution represents our assessed burden share of 2.15 per cent of OECD donor contributions. Although Australia's share has increased from our 1.68 per cent share of IFAD-1, our contribution in both real and nominal terms has actually declined because of the low level of the overall replenishment.

In the present circumstances the Australian share of OECD donor contributions maintains our support of IFAD programs through to fiscal year 1991-92 when the last encashment of the Australian contributions is scheduled. As the explanatory memorandum to the legislation shows, payment of the IFAD-2 contribution will be by way of promissory notes, to be encashed over a period of three years beginning in 1989-90.

The Government has taken into account the low level of the IFAD-2 replenishment, and the protracted nature of the negotiations required to conclude the replenishment. There clearly are difficulties in terms of the commitment of some donor countries, particularly in the OPEC group, to provide a viable level of funding to IFAD.
The Government also has concerns over the developmental effectiveness of IFAD and there are questions regarding IFAD's overlap with other developmental agencies.

As honourable senators are aware, the current climate of expenditure restraint has led to Australia's overseas aid program being reduced in real terms over the past three years. This cutback has required a rationalisation of the number of international organisations that Australia supports.

It is in this context that the Government has decided to make no further contributions to IFAD after honouring our current commitment to IFAD-2. Australia accordingly will not participate in the replenishment negotiations for IFAD-3, due to start in 1988.

In summary, I have taken the opportunity whilst speaking to the International Development Association Bill 1987, to canvass also the issues involved in contributing to the fourth replenishment of the Asian Development Fund, and the second replenishment of IFAD. I believe that it is both in Australia's national interest and in the interest of the international community as a whole that we should contribute to these organisations on the basis which I have outlined.
Specifically, in respect of the IDA Bill, it is proposed that Australia contribute an amount of $A335m to the eighth replenishment.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
INTERNATIONAL FUND FOR AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT BILL 1987
The purpose of this Bill is to authorise a contribution by Australia of $A8,472,570 towards the second replenishment of the International Fund for Agricultural Development.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Puplick) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
GROUP F
Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories
Proposed expenditure, $958,593,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are returning to the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. At this deathly hour I rise to make my first contribution on the Appropriation Bills and to draw attention to a couple of matters, including the final report of Estimates Committee F. Perhaps that would be a convenient place to start. For the first time, to the best of my recollection, a reservation has been included in the report of an Estimates committee. These reservations, I understand, are fairly unusual additions to be made to Estimates committee reports, and this particular reservation, which is signed by me, Senator Reid and Senator Vanstone, is an important one because it draws attention to a very important principle in terms of public administration and the conduct of public service in Australia. The reservation is fairly short and I propose to read it:

SPEECH.PARA: During its hearings, the Committee raised with two Statutory Commissions their participation in the political activities associated with the General Election on 11 July 1987.

In relation to the Australian Sports Commission, the Committee was informed that the Commission had taken outside legal advice after intimating that it might take legal action against the then Shadow Minister for Sport who had announced, as part of the Opposition's election policy, that the Commission would be abolished and had, in the process, made criticisms of the Commission. As the Commission had full access to the advice of the Australian Government Solicitor, but chose not to use this service, on the alleged grounds that the matter was ``urgent'', it can only be concluded that this represents an attempt by the Commission to involve itself in the election campaign in a political and partisan fashion.

In relation to the Australian Film Commission the Committee took evidence from its Chief Executive. He admitted, that together with the Chairman of the Commission, he had sought to play an active, public role in the election campaign opposing and criticising the policies of the Federal Opposition which called for the abolition of the Commission.

Both the Australian Sports Commission and the Australian Film Commission were designated for abolition by the Opposition during the federal election campaign. Senior officers of both Commissions involved themselves in the partisan controversies of the election campaign, actively and publicly supporting one Party's policies against another's.

These senior officers are officers of the Australian Public Service and they participated in the election campaign, not as private citizens (which is entirely their right) but as senior public servants.

We regard this behaviour as quite improper and totally at variance with the apolitical and non-partisan standards of behaviour which are properly to be expected and required of senior public servants acting in their official capacity.

I believe that this is an important reservation. It establishes an important principle in terms of these statutory commissions, which are, after all, proliferating under this Government. I make only two comments about that reservation. I have already detailed in this Parliament the attempt made by the Chairman of the Australian Sports Commission, Mr Harris, to threaten to apply pressure to me through my political Party because of the criticisms that I made of the criticisms made by the Commission of the views expressed by the Opposition during the election campaign. I repeat that I regard this as improper behaviour. May I say that I have no malice against individual officers of the Australian Sports Commission, the majority of whom discharge their responsibilities and functions in an admirable fashion. But that does not in any sense excuse their active participation, or their perceived active participation, in partisan politics.

One of the excuses given by the Chief Executive of the Australian Film Commission was that he felt that he had to participate because he had been told by `a previous shadow Minister'-and they were the terms that he used-that he would be requested to vacate his office if the Opposition parties were elected. I have checked with both of the previous shadow Ministers, former Senator Stan Collard and Mr Alexander Downer, the honourable member for Mayo, who is my predecessor as shadow Minister in this portfolio. Both of them assure me that neither they nor anybody on their behalf made any comments to the Chief Executive which would imply that his removal would have been sought if the Opposition had been elected at the last election. That is an important matter, and I wish to place it on the record.

I wish to place another matter on the record. It relates to the continuing impost on the heritage commissions around Australia, and the national trusts in particular, by the Government's fringe benefits tax. The fringe benefits tax is being levied on the national trusts in respect of the curators whom they put into their buildings to look after security. Very often, these curators are retired persons and the rent, if any, that they are charged is quite nominal. Nevertheless, the trusts around Australia have been faced with a number of burdens as a result of the imposition of the fringe benefits tax on some notionally calculated value of the accommodation being provided by the trusts to these curators or caretakers.

In a Press release numbered 115, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) indicated that he was prepared to look at this anomaly and take some steps to clear it up for the national trusts. But he has consistently refused to take any action in that regard and the trusts around the country are now being faced with substantial bills from the Deputy Commissioners of Taxation. The relief which was promised by the Government has not been forthcoming and these bodies, which after all are largely supported by public donation and subscription, are finding the imposition of the fringe benefits tax particularly burdensome.

The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) wrote to the Australian Council of National Trusts, welcoming the Treasurer's decision as `relief' for the national trusts from the effect of the fringe benefits tax. The word given by the Minister on that occasion has not been honoured by the Government. This matter has been consistently raised in Estimates committees and there is still no satisfactory response from the Government as to whether the original assurance given by the Treasurer that relief would be provided to the national trusts will be honoured by the Government.

Finally, I want to make one comment very briefly about funding for the arts. That is to indicate that Senator Jenkins is not alone in the complaint that she makes about support for opera around the country. I am a very great supporter of the Australian Opera, and I would not in any sense wish to derogate from the kind of money that it receives. But it is also a fact that the Victorian State Opera (VSO) and the State Opera of South Australia present excellent performances. The recent performance of The Flying Dutchman by the Victorian State Opera, in fact the world premiere of the 1841 original version of that opera, and the production by the South Australian State Opera of Sweeney Todd, were both very good not only in terms of their artistic standards but also because they brought opera to a large number of people who would not have had access to it in Sydney. Nevertheless, neither the VSO nor the South Australian State Opera has been funded by the Australia Council on this occasion. There is a very substantial argument to be addressed about the equity of access for people who wish to be able to hear operatic performances. The Council should be discharging its responsibility in a national sense, with a greater degree of sensitivity than it is showing at the moment.

Finally, I wish to proceed to a number of matters arising from the very unsatisfactory answers provided by Senator Richardson to a number of comments and a number of questions which have been asked by me regarding the Government's approach to World Heritage listing. I have asked Senator Richardson a series of questions and it has become apparent that he lacks the technical capacity to deal with the answers in a proper fashion.

I will refer to only two of those questions, one regarding the very important question of the provision of buffer zones in relation to World Heritage listing, and the other an extraordinary answer given to me about assertions that he makes about the actual biology and floristic development of the rainforests. As far as the question of buffer zones is concerned, there is a clear conflict between the advice being given by the Department and the advice that is coming from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO). A reading of the guidelines for the implementation of World Heritage listings, which is to be found in section 14 of the document regarding guidelines, which section was adopted by UNESCO at its meeting last January--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other day, I drew the attention of the House to assurances given by persons on behalf of the rainforests unit that there would not be buffer zones included in the World Heritage Listing. Mr von Droste, the senior officer of UNESCO, has flatly contradicted the statement that these buffer zones would be required, and Senator Richardson has been unable to deal with this matter in a satisfactory fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: The last point I make is in relation to the answer that Senator Richardson gave me the other day about non-indigenous plants invading the rainforests. As he had put an advertisement in the newspapers, over his own name, making claims about the invasion of logged areas in rainforests by non-indigenous plants, I asked Senator Richardson what plants he had in mind. It was clear from the answer that he gave about how outraged he was that somebody had sent him a stinging leaf, with some sort of suggestion as to exactly what he should do with it, that he was unable to provide any scientific or technical answer to my question. Therefore, on 23 November, he sought leave to incorporate into Hansard a list of some 12 plants that he allegedly had in mind. The table is headed:
Non-indigenous plants which have been observed to invade rainforest following disturbance by logging.

The 12 are given both in their Latin name and their familiar name. An analysis of that information shows that it is highly suspect. For instance, four of the plants-I will forbear from using the Latin names-namely, devil's apple, wild tobacco, Anzac weed and lantana are the only non-indigenous species commonly found in rainforests which have recently been logged. All of those species are short lived, shade intolerant shrubs which die out as the forest canopy closes. That is to say, none of them will persist for more than about 10 years after logging. None of the giant brambles found in the region are introduced. They are all indigenous, yet that species appears on Senator Richardson's list. On the list is also the African tulip, which appears to be confined to a few rainforest regrowth areas around old settlements. It could not be considered a problem in logged areas. Two further plants, the camphor laurel and guava, are woody weeds found in pastures. They are rarely, if ever, observed in logged areas and do not appear to have the ability to invade successfully logged rainforest.

Another one, guinea grass, may temporarily invade logging road edges and road ramps. It is rarely found along snig tracks or in small gaps. The species is a shade intolerant type of grass, which rapidly dies out as the canopy begins to close over the larger gaps. Two further plants-the giant sensitive weed and the climbing nightshade-and various, unnamed, presumably climbing, pasture legumes are nearly always found on rainforest edges where rainforest borders on farmland. The species are rarely seen in logged areas and, even where they are, they do not seem to be able to survive for more than a few years after logging.

Finally, one of the invasive vines which appears on the list is sometimes observed in rainforests along streams. Although this species is a pest in national parks, and in particular along the Mulgrave River, its distribution is currently quite restricted, and since Queensland logging proscriptions do not permit the removal of trees along streams it is not envisaged that logging would increase the rate of its spread. Senator Richardson's answer, which he proceeds to give after the table, is equally at error. For instance, he says `invasion by non-indigenous plants is only one of the many structural and holistic changes which result from logging'. I presume, in fact, he means floristic changes. Nevertheless, an analysis of the answers given by Senator Richardson either to the legal questions about buffer zones or to the scientific and technical questions about plants and introduced plants-what is an indigenous plant and what is not an indigenous plant-quite simply indicates that Senator Richardson is unable to provide the sort of information which he ought to be able to provide before he contemplates so significant a step as he is proposing so far as World Heritage listing of this area is concerned.
The Minister has an obligation to be better informed about his own portfolio, and it is an obligation that he is clearly not discharging.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick has raised a number of matters to which I am sure he does not want me to respond at great length, given the lateness of the hour. In fact we are now in our forty-second hour of debate on these Estimates which exceeds the previous record by some twenty hours. I think he will acknowledge under those circumstances that the issues have been reasonably well canvassed.

SPEECH.PARA: There are five matters raised and I will respond to them briefly as follows. The first matter is about the Australian Sports Commission and so on. All I can say about that is that the issue raised by the reserving senators was canvassed extensively in the Estimates Committee and I have certainly noted the points he has made again tonight.

In respect of the fringe benefits tax issue, I will ensure that the matter is raised again with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson. In relation to the Victorian State Opera and related matters, the most I can say is, as with answers to previous questions, I will see whether Senator Richardson can be persuaded-I am sure he will be-to raise the matter with the Australia Council in the terms in which Senator Puplick has put it to us.

As to the question about buffer zones, the short answer is this: the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation guidelines say that the buffer zones should be provided, where necessary. Senator Richardson has said that areas within the boundaries will serve as buffer zones, where necessary. In the particular circumstances of this case, there is no intention of bringing into contention as buffer zones areas outside the forest as such. The final question is about the introduction of non-indigenous species. The basic element in the answer here is that such species are introduced by vehicles and by fauna. It is a technical question. However, as Senator Puplick acknowledges, it is one better dealt with by a question and answer on notice rather than by extended debate in this place by people who, in this instance, unlike the case with Senator Richardson, are manifestly ill-equipped to deal with the technical matters involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to continue on a question I asked earlier this evening. I asked whether there was a study done of the income forgone from minerals, timber or farm or agricultural produce out of any World Heritage areas that the Government might have in mind. I was given the answer that various reports were coming. But I ask again: have any specific inquiries and studies been done into what will be forgone from those areas in minerals, forestry or agriculture?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that studies are addressing those issues and that the results from them will be obtained in the December-January period. I will make sure that Senator Panizza is advised accordingly.
